IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonribosomal peptides are an important class of natural products which display great structural and functional diversity, and many possess important bioactivity. This project proposes to elucidate the structure and biosynthesis of several nonribosomal peptides containing α,β-dehydroamino acids produced by a unique C domain, the CmodAA domain. Discovering novel nonribosomal peptides and expounding their biosynthesis will provide a base of knowledge that can lead to the discovery of other α,β-dehydroamino acid containing natural products and expand our current library of bioactive therapeutic peptides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The aim of this research is to develop multimodal delineation algorithms capable of accurately and reproducibly delineating radiation therapy gross target volumes and clinical target volumes in a variety of head and neck cancer locations, as well as target volumes specific to recurrent disease scenarios. Our approach will use deep learning and multimodal PET/CT imaging, while capturing inter- and intra- observer variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: -Project Narrative- Dendritic anomalies are a prominent clinical feature across neurodevelopmental disorders, indicating that impeding dendrite development can have long-lasting consequences on neuron and circuit function. This project seeks to elucidate the mechanisms that guide dendritic development, which is critical to understanding disease pathology and informing early treatment strategies. Specifically, a portion of the proposed research investigates potential dysfunction in dendritic development caused by mutation of a gene called FRMD7 that is responsible for most cases of idiopathic congenital nystagmus in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Circadian disturbance is a well know hazard of shift work and has been linked to the development of long-term negative health outcomes such as cardiovascular and cardiometabolic diseases. While this link is known, there are not quantitative frameworks for measuring disturbance of central and peripheral body clocks in humans in real-world settings. This proposal seeks to further our knowledge of circadian rhythms in the real-world using wearable sensors, advance our technologies for quantitating synchrony of central and peripheral body clocks, and translate this information into actionable models to help shift workers maintain synchrony.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SCN8A encephalopathy is a severe epilepsy syndrome caused by gain-of-function mutations in the sodium channel Nav1.6. It is unknown how these mutations affect the physiology of parvalbumin-positive (PV) inhibitory interneurons, a critical inhibitory interneuron subtype that expresses Nav1.6. By electrophysiologically recording neurons from two patient-derived mouse models of SCN8A encephalopathy, this proposal aims to clarify the contributions of PV interneurons to SCN8A encephalopathy and better understand if these interneurons may provide a novel therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in mitochondria morphology negatively affect cellular health and are observed in a wide range of diseases such as in Parkinson’s disease and fatty liver disease. Understanding how mitochondria regulate their morphology is a critical component in recognizing causes of mitochondria dysfunction within those diseases. This proposal aims to explore a new pathway for regulating mitochondria morphology through sensing defects in mitochondria proteostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma ranks among the deadliest of all human cancers, with no effective treatment. I will study roles of a tRNA modification enzyme in maintaining stemness and promoting growth of cancer stem cells in glioblastoma. This study will inspire the design of potential new treatments for patients afflicted with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Alcohol misuse (e.g., binge and high-intensity drinking) adversely affects psychosocial well-being across development. While social influences (i.e., the quality, frequency, and specific nature of social interactions and social relationships) can protect against alcohol misuse, they can also exacerbate risk. Research investigating both longitudinal and proximal social influences on alcohol use is required to identify precise intervention targets.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis infects a quarter of the global population and the prevalence of multidrug resistant strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is on the rise. Understanding Mycobacterium tuberculosis physiology and identifying the pathways involved in antibiotic resistance are key to developing novel anti-tuberculosis drugs. This research is relevant to the NIAID mission to support basic research that advances our understanding, treatment, and prevention of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Monoaminergic systems in the brain play critical roles in the regulation of a wide variety of neural processes, and are heavily implicated in the etiology of numerous mood-related disorders in humans, including major depressive disorder (MDD). While mood disorders are highly heritable, it is clear that environmental factors also contribute significantly to disease, with chronic stress representing one of the most common precipitating factors for mood-related diagnoses; however, little remains known concerning the precise molecular mechanisms mediating mood disorder/stress vulnerability or individual responsiveness to antidepressants. This proposal thus aims to comprehensively examine a novel molecular mechanism recently implicated in stress vulnerability and MDD – i.e., histone H3 monoaminylation in brain, a protein modification discovered and characterized by our laboratory – with respect to its contributions to cell-type specific transcriptional plasticity and its roles in the mediation of stress susceptibility and/or antidepressant efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RESEARCH NARRATIVE Flaviviruses are a large family of RNA viruses that are significant global pathogens, infecting up to 400 million people a year. The flavivirus protease is an essential non-structural protein that is an attractive target for antiviral therapeutics; however, the intracellular molecular determinants for flavivirus protease cleavage of substrates and how these factors affect viral fitness is unknown. The purpose of the proposed study is to understand the proteolytic determinants of flavivirus infection to uncover potential pathways that can be exploited in the development of antiviral therapies targeting this viral protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differential RNA-sequencing of temporal cortex autopsy samples from typical and atypical forms of the neurodevelopmental disorder Rett syndrome (RTT) has uncovered elevated heat shock signaling as a highly conserved aspect of the disease. Here we describe a strategy to delineate whether inhibition of HS signaling is therapeutic through genetic and pharmacological manipulation of the HS response in mouse models of RTT and determine the underlying mechanisms driving cellular stress responses. We posit that our findings may uncover novel mechanisms for RTT pathogenesis which will aid in drug-discovery efforts for the disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While rates of Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) and Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH) continue to rise worldwide, the mechanisms that govern fatty liver disease onset and progression remain poorly understood. We have shown that loss of the mitophagy receptor BNIP3 leads to spontaneous lipid accumulation in healthy liver, and contributes to NAFLD and NASH severity in mice and to hepatocellular carcinoma in humans. Here, I propose to elucidate the mechanism by which BNIP3 works to clear lipid from the liver, with the goal of contributing to the development of novel therapeutic options for NAFLD and NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal investigates the role of visual exploration in forming map-like representations of our surroundings. The knowledge gained from this research will be important for developing rehabilitation strategies, assistive devices, and accommodations for those with impaired sight or differences in sensory processing (e.g., from autism and ADHD), who often suffer from navigational difficulties. Moreover, because the brain regions that we plan to study are often impacted by normal aging, stroke, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, knowledge about the role of visuo-spatial processes in these regions will be useful for predicting, diagnosing, understanding, and treating these conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Gordon Research Conference on Mammalian Reproduction aims to promote the understanding of fundamental processes guiding reproductive functions in mammals, foster new research collaborations and enhance the career development of trainees and junior investigators. We will promote the participation of trainees, women, and individuals from underrepresented groups in all aspects of the program. The overarching goal is to assemble a diverse and international community of experts in reproduction to share cutting-edge discoveries that advance the frontier of research that impacts reproductive medicine and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, the decision to continue using bimodal hearing or pursue a second cochlear implant (i.e., transition from bimodal hearing to bilateral cochlear implant use) is highly subjective, and no clinical guidelines exist to support this decision. Assessing the patient-reported benefits of each listening configuration has been understudied; however, previous literature and our preliminary data suggest that patients hold valuable insights into real-world listening benefits that may differentiate bimodal hearing and bilateral cochlear implants. In this study, we will investigate the patient-reported advantages and limitations of each listening configuration using a novel research approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Actin is a key component of the cellular cytoskeleton that enables cells and tissues to control their shape, and thus is essential for force generation (for example, during embryonic development) and migration (for example, during cancer extravasation), yet we lack the knowledge of how actin structures are coordinated across multiple levels of organization. This project aims to determine how the protein Bitesize, in the Drosophila fly model system, directly interacts with the actin protein to enable the individual actin molecule to assemble into filaments, and to organize these filaments into larger, more intricate structures. Thus, this research seeks to advance the NIH’s mission by establishing knowledge of how cells regulate the hierarchical actin structures that are fundamental to tissue development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol and cannabis misuse are associated with significant harm in young adult populations, including all three leading causes of death (accidents, suicide, homicide). Sleep impairment is also common and costly among young adults, and research indicates significant comorbidity among alcohol misuse, cannabis misuse, and sleep impairment with evidence of bidirectional causal relationships that can exacerbate related harms. The current application uses a rigorous and efficient trial design to test an integrated brief alcohol, cannabis, and sleep intervention in comparison to two monotherapies (for alcohol/cannabis misuse and for sleep) to address this important and often overlooked comorbidity among young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is aimed at engineering a novel longitudinally-detected electron paramagnetic resonance system for inexpensively and noninvasively quantifying iron oxide nanoparticles in tissues. This system will be used to determine concentrations of nanoparticles in rat kidneys that have been cryopreserved for transplantation. The measurements from this system will be used to address bottlenecks in kidney cryopreservation research, thus increasing the number and quality of kidneys available for transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons rely on proper control of gene expression to make appropriate connections during development and to mediate experience-dependent plasticity and memory formation. These gene-expression pathways are tuned by microRNAs (miRNAs), short RNA molecules that modulate gene expression by targeting mRNAs for translational repression and degradation. This proposal will address how neuronal miRNAs themselves are governed, thereby opening a new window into the mechanisms underlying neurological disorders that arise due to mis-regulation of neuronal gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Neuroinflammation is a hallmark of brain aging and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s and may serve both protective and pathogenic roles. We have identified a highly consistent microglial induction of Major Histocompatibility Complex I (MHC-I) and paired immunoglobulin receptors families with age and AD in mouse and man. This project will explore the hypothesis that MHC-I signals non-canonically (e.g., non-T cell receptor mechanisms) to regulate microglial reactivity with aging and Alzheimer’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney resident macrophages (KRM) are known accelerators of ADPKD as their depletion slows cyst progression. In this application, I will study the kinetics and mechanism of KRM niche filling after temporary depletion in an ADPKD mouse model to identify possible means to achieve long-term, kidney specific resident macrophage depletion. This work may provide a template to develop long-term, tissue specific, resident macrophage depletion in the kidney, something that will be of broad interest to the macrophage and kidney community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Research Narrative Investigating the neural mechanisms of anxiety and behavioral responses to danger is essential to understanding the pathology of anxiety-related disorders and developing novel treatments for these afflictions. This proposal will describe DRN projections and serotonergic receptors in the insula using innovative viral-genetic tracing methods, visualize insular serotonin activity in response to danger signals using in vivo fiber photometry, and manipulate the DRN-insula tract during exposures to danger signals using chemogenetic techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Chronic hepatitis B virus infection (CHB) causes almost 1 million deaths annually through chronic liver injury, liver failure, and primary liver cancer. These outcomes can be prevented by clearance of the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), a clinical cure that is rarely achieved with existing antiviral therapies. Using cross-species analyses of a mouse model that recapitulates human age-dependent differences in hepatitis B virus response and data from an antiviral therapy withdrawal clinical trial, I propose to unravel mechanisms that underpin immune-mediated termination of CHB and identify actionable targets for interventions that change the hepatic immune environment to promote clinical cure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adherence to antiretroviral therapy is vital for prevention of AIDS-related deaths and comorbidities in children living with HIV, but pediatric populations face greater challenges to adherence compared to adults including difficulties with medication tolerability. Pediatric trials and evidence generated from these trials have lagged behind adult trials, especially in regard to use of modern causal inference methods to address analytic challenges. This proposal will use data from a pediatric randomized trial of dolutegravir-based ART compared to standard of care and novel epidemiologic methods to demonstrate how to improve evaluation of evidence generated from pediatric trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding neutrophil development and the regulation of their effector functions is essential for advancing treatments of various infectious and sterile inflammatory diseases. The goal of this proposal is to gain comprehensive insights into the functional significance of PSTPIP2 in neutrophil biology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT), a blood vessel disorder that can be passed from parents to children, affects about 1 in 5000 people worldwide. In HHT, enlarged shunts (arteriovenous malformations, AVMs) and entangled surface-level vessels (telangiectasias) form and can bleed, causing anemia, stroke, and even death. The goal of this project is to develop a more effective mouse model to understand the mechanisms underlying AVM formation in HHT.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adaptive optics (AO) imaging represents a powerful instrument for the assessment of ocular diseases and disorders, as well as a means for diagnostic and therapeutic evaluation. Despite its advantages, this method has many mechanical and logistic limitations; this project aims to increase the image quality and general accessibility of AO imaging to a broader patient population. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused on autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which is mostly caused by reduced polycystin-1 or polycystin-2. Numerous evidence suggests that the normal functionality of polycystins requires them to be positioned in cilia and the reduced functional dosage of polycystins triggers compartmentalized increase of cAMP and PKA activity in cilia to initiate ADPKD; however, how the ciliary trafficking and function of polycystins are regulated remains vague. The major goals of the proposed studies are: (1) dissecting the ciliary modules that mediate the targeting of polycystins into cilia and (2) understanding how polycystins maintain the homeostasis of cAMP and PKA activity in primary cilia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. is a global leader in the incidence of major depressive disorder (MDD), a common, often recurring mental health problem associated with lifelong health implications; however, current available treatments do not provide adequate relief for a large portion of those affected. The proposed project will seek to understand how childhood maltreatment, which is a major risk factor for the development of MDD in adulthood, as well as an overall worse course of illness, “gets under the skin” to affect inflammation signaling. I will explore the effects of childhood maltreatment on inflammation and MDD from adolescence into middle adulthood using a nationally representative U.S. sample, devoting specific attention to the roles of sex and gender differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Conference GENE EXPRESSION AND SIGNALING IN THE IMMUNE SYSTEM  April 16-20, 2024 PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune system provides the body’s major defense against both infectious diseases and cancer. It employs a wide variety of strategies to recognize and remove microbes and distressed cells, as well as providing the protective immunity against future infections that forms the basis of vaccination. The immune system may also respond aberrantly or too aggressively, as in various forms of allergy, or may attack the body’s own cells, as in autoimmune diseases. The cells of the immune system have to interpret a wide variety of signals to respond in an appropriate manner to a given challenge. How these signals are received, transmitted, and interpreted forms the scope of this important conference series. The series is notable because it attracts a unique group of immunologists focused on genes and their mechanisms of action whose research is at the cutting edge in defining how the immune system functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Gut microbiome modulation alters the repertoire of gut microbiome derived antigens that traverse from the gut to the liver and has been shown to augment anti-tumor immunity in pancreatic cancer liver metastasis (PCLM). Mucosal associated invariant T (MAIT) cell are a unique subset of invariant T cells which can be modulated to switch from a “pro-tumor” MAIT17 phenotype (suppresses cytotoxic cells) to an “anti-tumor” MAIT1 phenotype (activates cytotoxic cells) by specific activation pathways induced by microbial derived antigens. The goal of this project is to harness the gut microbiome to modulate MAIT cells in the PCLM tumor microenvironment towards a MAIT1 phenotype to promote anti-tumor immunity and reduce PCLM tumor burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide and develops through a series of stages in the stomach lining, including SPEM cell-containing metaplasia. Our lab has identified a significant upregulation of the transcription factor SOX9 in SPEM cells, which are essential to the progression of gastric carcinogenesis. Identifying the role of SOX9 in SPEM cells and their contribution to carcinogenesis will move the field forward by discovering and understanding the mechanisms of gastric cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While malaria control efforts have focused on other species, infections by Plasmodium ovale spp. are more common than previously thought and rising in prevalence in sub-Saharan Africa. This proposal aims to employ genomic and epidemiological methods to characterize the parasite population and determine relapse patterns of this neglected malaria parasite. The foundational knowledge gained will inform relapse treatment guidelines and provide essential genomic details for future research and surveillance of ovale malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication along the brain’s sensorimotor axis appears critical for the integration of sensations and movements associated with skilled behavioral learning. Yet, the neural circuits that integrate motor, sensory, and goal-related signals to detect errors and guide sensorimotor learning in mammals remain unidentified. This project will uncover the function of these circuits and provide insight into how the brain drives behavioral adaptions in dynamic sensory environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) are the most common nosocomial infections, with the majority being polymicrobial in nature. Proteus mirabilis is one of the most common causes of CAUTIs and it is frequently found to be co-colonizing with Enterococcus faecalis, with patients colonized by both pathogens suffering a significant increase in disease severity and risk of developing secondary sequelae, such as bacteremia. Understanding how these two disease-enhancing pathogens interact, defining the important factors and their role in biofilm formation, persistence, and pathogenesis of polymicrobial CAUTI has the potential to drive novel therapeutic development and inform best medical intervention practices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Injuries to the central nervous system are devastating to human health and the limited regenerative capacity of the central nervous system is a primary cause for the long-term disability caused by such injuries. In the short- term, this work will identify cellular and genetic programs that are required for regeneration in the central nervous system. In the long term, this work will contribute to our growing understanding about how cells in the central nervous system respond to injury and inform our future treatment strategies for improving regeneration and ultimately functional recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Normal brain vascular development during pregnancy is crucial for healthy brain function after birth, and disruptions to this development can result in lifelong health complications or death. We aim to uncover how a crucial component of the brain vasculature, the blood-brain barrier (BBB), develops during gestation and how this barrier regulates immune cell entry into the brain. This work will advance prenatal and infant care by informing the development of targeted therapies for brain-related disorders with prenatal or early onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to test whether particular features of the voice are indicators of the slowing and agitated movements that are characteristic of depression. The project will also test whether these abnormalities in movement (a) are only present in individuals with current depression or are also present in those whose depression has remitted, (b) change over time as currently depressed individuals recover, or as remitted individuals relapse, and (c) can be measured outside of the lab, more naturalistically. Taken together, understanding these movement abnormalities may lead to path-breaking early detection strategies, that help to predict the course of depression, and inform treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to better understand the structural mechanisms of intercellular channels known as gap junctions that are linked to cataracts and various retinopathies. We will apply cutting-edge technologies in single particle Cryo-EM to define unique structural features of lens and retina gap junctions by the latest biomolecular tools in structural biology. These insights can be used to guide the rational design of next- generation pharmacological tools in vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Sex differences in nicotine effects combined with blunted responses to treatment approaches combine to lead to worse treatment outcomes for nicotine addiction in women. Nicotine acts through hijacking endogenous acetylcholine signaling, which ultimately leads to the increases in dopamine release that drive nicotine reinforcement. This grant focuses on outlining how ovarian hormones contribute to sex differences in dopamine release regulation by acetylcholine in female subjects, and will provide a better understanding for pharmacotherapeutic approaches for nicotine treatment in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disease modifying drugs have greatly improved the treatment of autoimmune arthritis, but patients can experience recurrent and uncontrolled intervals of disease flares. This project aims to validate an agent for modulating inflammatory immune cells associated with flares and thereby potentially sparing joints from further damage. If successful, the approach has the potential to pave the way for a treatment that achieves durable arthritis flare control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the past decade, the number of large multi-center neuroimaging studies has skyrocketed due to growing investments by federal governments and private entities interested in brain development, aging, and pathology. This has led to the accumulation of vast amounts of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data acquired using various study designs, but the statistical methodology necessary for harmonizing these data for integrated analyses is currently lacking. In this project, we propose to develop, implement, and apply next-generation imaging harmonization methods and harmonization in the context of diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers, which has become a central issue for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to develop and test a framework describing the multimodal affective environment that supports language development in early childhood. Using computational analyses of infants’ at-home environments in the first years of life as well as a series of tightly-controlled experiments, we ask (1) how affective contexts shape word learning and (2) how children with depressed caregivers adapt their learning strategies to the decreased affective information in their environments. Understanding how children with depressed caregivers use affective information to learn new words may inform tailored efforts to promote equity in educational outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative As of 2021, 8 million people in the US are suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a psychiatric disorder causing behavioral and functional impairment, and we report an increased incidence of PTSD among individuals with chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). Yet, little is known about the pathological underpinnings of PTSD or its interaction with Alzheimer’s Disease related dementias. This proposal compares neuroinflammatory pathology of PTSD subjects with or without CTE to improve our understanding of disease development, which follows the NIH mission to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain to reduce burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While microbiota alterations and selected metabolites have been implicated in the regulation of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), our current knowledge regarding the mechanisms that regulate host-microbiota interactions, their potential alteration due to intestinal inflammation, and their specific mechanistic impact on immune cell activation in CVD is quite limited. Here we propose to investigate previously underappreciated in the field of CVD role of IL17RC cytokine signaling as key regulator of intestinal epithelium metabolism, microbiota and immune cell function in atherosclerosis and identify its contribution to neuroinflammation in the aorta. The results from this innovative study will establish novel IL17RC-dependent mechanisms of CVD and will aid future preventive and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurological injuries, such as stroke or motor neuron disease, can lead to loss of speech, significantly limiting communication abilities and negatively impacting quality of life; however, speech neuroprostheses offer hope in restoring communication by directly decoding cortical activity into intended speech. Despite over half of the world's population being bilingual and each language contributing unique dimensions to bilinguals' personality and worldview, previous decoding studies have predominantly focused on monolingual speech. In light of this, the proposed project will investigate the precise cortical activity patterns that underlie bilingual speech and use these findings to develop a bilingual speech neuroprosthesis capable of decoding cortical activity into language- specific phrases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social drinking contexts are frequently associated with negative consequences, including binge drinking and an increased risk of developing Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD). The proposed study seeks to improve the understanding of neurocognitive mechanisms underlying alcohol reinforcement in social contexts. Understanding these mechanisms has important theoretical and clinical implications, including advancing theoretical models of AUD vulnerabilities and improving treatment and prevention programs by identifying “high-risk” settings associated with heightened alcohol reinforcement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the main functions of the kidney is to match water output (urine volume) to water intake (drinking volume). I discovered that a receptor, known as GPR39, is found in specialized cells in the kidney that control how dilute or concentrated the urine is. In this proposal I will uncover how GPR39 influences the function of these cells (Aim 1), and how GPR39 contributes to our ability to maintain water balance (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid evolution of seasonal influenza A viruses results in new variants that require our vaccines to be updated each year. There is currently a lack of understanding of how these variants arise amongst individual hosts to then go onto circulate globally. This research aims to address this gap with the goal of improving our ability to anticipate the evolution of influenza A viruses when designing seasonal vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is associated with worse morbidity and mortality of pulmonary viral infections like SARS-CoV-2, however the effects of obesity on intestinal viral infections, specifically norovirus, remains poorly understood. My new preliminary data reveal that human and murine obesity are associated with protection from norovirus infection in association with enhanced norovirus-specific antibody production. In this proposal, I will determine how the adaptive immune response (Aim 1) and interferon signaling (Aim 2) mediate protection against norovirus infection in high fat diet-induced obese mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases of all types – and especially Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias – represent an ever-increasing public health crisis as our society ages without effective therapeutic interventions. Recent advances in both biological and genetic studies implicate changes in cellular compartments known as endosomes and lysosomes in the onset and/or progression of these diseases. The goal of the Lysosomes and Endocytosis conference and seminar is to assemble a multidisciplinary group of researchers to discuss and debate the molecular mechanisms responsible for formation and function of these compartments with particular focus on their contribution to neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) is the second most common progressive neurodegenerative disease and has been linked to movement abnormalities, rapid reduction of synaptic function, and sometimes memory impairment. This proposal will examine the role of T-lymphocytes in PD in the periphery at different disease phases, in the brain where synaptic loss occurs, and from a genetics perspective linking PD risk loci to T-cell-mediated disease mechanism. Understanding how T-cells impact PD is critical for understanding the pathogenesis of disease and informing future diagnostic and treatment efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The fidelity of cell division is critical for the accurate alignment and segregation of chromosomes, but malfunctions in this process can introduce mitotic errors, contributing to uncontrolled growth and tumorigenesis. Protein phosphatases have recently emerged as promising targets for cancer treatment due to their ability to regulate critical signaling pathways involved in cell division. The proposed research will investigate the mechanistic functions of the newly identified phosphatase DUSP12 in cell division with the goal of advancing our understanding of human cell proliferation and facilitating the development of novel therapeutic interventions in proliferative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils are the predominantly infected cell in active tuberculosis patients; however, it is unknown why this innate immune cell is unable to kill Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). The type VII secretion system, ESX-1, is required for Mtb survival and growth in neutrophils but it is unclear what neutrophil function(s) are dysregulated due to this secretion system. This proposed research will uncover the neutrophil pathways affected by ESX-1 activity and how this activity promotes Mtb growth, providing critical insights into the mechanisms Mtb uses to reprogram the immune system during tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  With the rising prevalence of antibiotic-resistant infections, traditional antimicrobial approaches are facing increasing limitations, necessitating careful study of the factors underlying these infections and innovative strategies for their treatment. This study aims to investigate how bacteria can utilize reverse transcriptase enzymes to overcome their viral predators, bacteriophages, in the course of infecting their human hosts. The results of this investigation will illuminate how antiviral immune systems in bacteria contribute to their pathogenicity, and guide novel intervention strategies to combat antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Enteric infections, specifically the resulting diarrheal disease, are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality for children under 5 years old in low-income settings. Drinking water contamination, a key source of exposure to enteric pathogens, can be influenced by various household water handling behaviors and seasonal variation in water resources. This project will investigate if and how household water handling practices impact enteric pathogen infection in 12-month-old children in Beira, Mozambique, and the effect of seasonality on these pathways, which will allow for a better understanding of the pathways through which drinking water impacts acute health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Oxidation of the thiol (–SH) of select protein cysteines can act as a molecular switch to adapt protein function and modulate cellular signaling events in response to metabolic changes and stress conditions. Excessive levels of cellular oxidants as a consequence of genetic alterations, environmental exposure, inflammation, or aging can disrupt thiol-based redox signaling with a range of pathological consequences, including cardiovascular and lung disease, neurodegeneration, and many cancers. This conference brings together world class scientists from across the career spectrum to exchange the newest research and ideas centered on the spatial and temporal aspects of thiol-based redox signaling within and between cells, with the goal to advance our understanding of these events and to translate this knowledge into new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The stagnant therapeutic development in peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and lack of success of angiogenic therapies warrants further investigation of non-vascular cells contribution to limb functionality. Experiments outlined in this predoctoral fellowship seek to understand how the accumulation of intramuscular adipose tissue (IMAT), an understudied hallmark of severe PAD, contributes to ischemic limb function using genetic and pharmacological approaches in preclinical models. This fellowship will provide thorough technical and intellectual training to a promising young scientist in several areas including stem cell, muscle, and vascular biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The objective of this F32 is to assess the psychological experience of chronic stress and dynamic functional connectivity within the brain’s stress coping network in a clinical sample with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and matched controls. To advance the translational impact of the science of the stress neurocircuitry in AUD, this proposal will integrate psychological and neural levels of analysis to elucidate the relationship between chronic stress and temporal variability within brain’s stress coping network AUD versus matched controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) patients suffer from elevated levels of brain iron with levodopa (L-DOPA) commonly used by clinicians as a first-line antiparkinson drug. This project will research how our standard administration of L-DOPA impacts critical properties of iron homeostasis with the goal of identifying key iron mechanisms in the blood-brain barrier which will be confirmed by utilizing an in-vitro blood-brain barrier model and in-vivo murine model. This research will allow for the understanding of the mechanism of iron transport after L-DOPA exposure and target critical regulators to reduce brain iron accumulation and improve antiparkinson drug therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite the improved short-term outcomes in kidney transplantation (KT), comparable progress in long-term allograft survival has not been achieved with chronic allograft injury (CAI) accounting for most of the cases of graft loss. Results of our planned studies will identify early molecular pathways predating eventual graft repair or deterioration which will allow for the exploration of new therapeutic targets that have the potential to prevent irreversible kidney damage. Novel prognostic biomarkers will enable the early identification of patients at higher risk for progression to CAI, allowing for the development of new therapeutic modalities that have the potential to avoid irreversible graft injury and improve long-term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative A subset of commensal microbial antigens is trafficked to the thymus in early life and presented to developing thymocytes to expand microbiota-specific T cells. This proposal seeks to identify the microbial and immunological signals that promote microbe trafficking to the thymus during this developmental ‘window of opportunity’ and provide insight into the establishment of the commensal-reactive T cell repertoire. As microbe-specific T cells are implicated in protection against enteric infections, and the pathology underlying Inflammatory Bowel Disease, this project will advance our understanding of how the microbiome influences the development of the mucosal immune system.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well known that genetics play an important role during development, and genetic mutations can lead to neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs). It is not well understood how coding and non-coding mutations in certain genes cause a wide range of phenotypes seen in NDDs. A better understanding of how mutations in these genes affect gene expression and chromatin accessibility during neuronal development will provide further insight into the causes of NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This Project Summary/Abstract was originally submitted with R01 AG073193 and is included here unchanged to satisfy submission system requirements. PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease affects 1 in 9 Americans over 65 years of age, is the 6th leading cause of death, and costs $355 billion annually. Herein, we aim to understand how viruses interact with an aging olfactory system to accelerate Alzheimer's disease. This proposal will identify potential biomarkers and therapies (e.g. vaccines and antiviral agents) that may slow or halt progression to clinical dementia, disability, and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arthritis has affected numerous patients and caused long-term disabilities and morbidities. Joint instability precedes the onset of symptoms, i.e., when these progressive degenerative diseases are most treatable, but is oftentimes undetectable through the existing diagnostic imaging tests. This work will provide a novel CT imaging tool that will provide new anatomical and functional information on dynamic joint pathologies and facilitate early diagnosis of joint instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Utilizing advances in human interactome structural characterization and covalent inhibitor development against reactive cysteines, this project proposes Artificial Intelligence methods to identify hyperreactive cysteines on protein-protein interaction (PPI) interfaces and explore covalent targeting of these cysteines with electrophilic molecules. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related tauopathies currently have no cure or robust treatment plan. Understanding the molecular mechanisms driving neurodegeneration are vital for increasing our ability to accurately diagnose and treat patients suffering from neurodegenerative disorders. The proposed study will investigate basic mechanisms regulating mechanotransduction in neurons and will test the hypothesis that pathogenic tau drives neuronal death by disrupting neuronal nuclear mechanotransduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent years have seen the development of the concept that gut microbes provide a wealth of bioactive small molecules toward the host, and that these small molecules can consequentially influence diverse physiological processes. Our research group demonstrated that supplementation of mice fed a high fat and high sugar diet (Western-style diet) with a novel beneficial microbe, namely Lactococcus lactis subsp. cremoris (LLC) lowers total cholesterol, decreases hepatic adiposity, and lowers the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in the liver, but the mechanisms whereby this beneficial effect occur is unknown. We will identify LLC-induced shifts in the metabolome of mice fed a Western style diet and identify the therapeutic targets of LLC mediated cytoprotection in the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common cause of autism due to an epigenetic silencing of the X-linked FMR1 gene. In this project I propose to study the developmental deficits of FXS in 3D cortical organoids derived from patient induced pluripotent stem cells. This project should uncover the role of FMRP in neuronal differentiation and maturation throughout cortical development and uncover novel molecular mechanisms to be used for the development of FXS treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, approximately 8% of the civilian and up to 30% of the active military and veteran population will experience post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and, in the absence of diagnostic biomarkers and targeted therapeutic interventions, the costs of PTSD are staggering. We will study the genomic architecture of PTSD, with a focus on (i) gene expression, DNA methylation and protein expression of whole brain regions, (ii) gene expression and epigenetics in individual brain cells, and (iii) SNP-specific CRIPSR-editing of iPSC derived cul- tures exposed to glucocorticoids. Finally, we will characterize phenotypes associated with identified variants and networks to better understand how molecular mechanisms underlying PTSD are linked to specific symptoms, to improve PTSD prevention and treatment long-term.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the limitations in current parenting assessments by introducing innovative approaches and advanced psychometric methods. The objectives include revising the Multidimensional Assessment of Parenting Scale (MAPS) through qualitative interviews and text mining analyses, developing and cross- validating revised MAPS versions for self-report (MAPS-S), coparent-report (MAPS-C), and youth-report (MAPS-Y), and developing optimal ecological momentary assessment (EMA) versions of the MAPS for parent- coparent and parent-youth dyads. Capitalizing on ethnoracially diverse national samples including fathers and piloting Spanish measures will further ensure the scales’ robustness and generalizability, thereby advancing parenting research and interventions aimed at improving youth health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability of human gut microbes to produce bioactive metabolites may provide a conserved signaling pathway for host-microbial communication. Microbial carbohydrate-active enzymes (CAZymes) are an exciting target for altering host-accessible glycan metabolites, which have been shown to be translationally relevant in a number of immune-active states including inflammatory diseases and certain cancers. Deciphering host- microbial dynamics through the chemoproteomic discovery of highly functional CAZymes could lead to the development of novel, engineered probiotics to selectively control glycan metabolite output in human host systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies aim to elucidate the chemical logic of neuromodulation by determining the implications of co-expression of receptors in primary neurons and intact brain tissue. This proposal utilizes the latest tools in transcriptomics, genetics, and live microscopy to better understand the diversity of cell types and neuron communication. The cellular understanding of neuromodulation gained will have important translational ramifications as neuromodulation is key to unlocking the brain in healthy and diseased states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hippocampal long-term synaptic potentiation (LTP) is critical to learning and memory. The execution of LTP requires activity-dependent transcription, but how a dysregulation of that contributes to intellectual disability remains elusive. Supported by our preliminary data, we will study the mechanisms by which tumor suppressor p53 mediates long-term synaptic potentiation and how defective expression of p53 and p53-dependent transcription contributes to intellectual disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Harmful DNA breaks caused by exposure to radiation, chemicals, or as a result of mistakes that occur when DNA is being duplicated are usually repaired accurately through a process called homologous recombination (HR). When a DNA break occurs in an HR-deficient cell, it triggers a highly error-prone, cancer- inducing backup DNA repair pathway called microhomology-mediated end joining (MMEJ), and cells produce large amounts of the protein that performs MMEJ: DNA polymerase theta (PolQ). My project will uncover the step-by-step mechanism of how PolQ performs MMEJ and inform new strategies for discovering molecules that inhibit PolQ function to be investigated as potential HR-deficient cancer drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative CMV colitis is an increasing problem in clinical practice, especially in individuals who are immunosuppressed through treatment for Inflammatory Bowel Disease, cancer, or organ transplant. This project aims to understand the effect of CMV infection/reactivation on the colonic epithelium. These foundational studies of the epithelium are fundamental to identifying mechanisms of CMV colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The interaction between MCL1 and the rBH3 motif positions MCL1 as a bridge between apoptotic signaling and other cellular homeostasis pathways. The proposed project will elucidate how MCL1 interacts with rBH3 motifs, and elucidating how MCL1 may modify bound protein structure and therefore function will lead to new insights in rBH3 function. Specifically, this proposal will elucidate how MCL1 interacts with the glycolytic enzyme hexokinase 2 to lead in an increase in the rate of glucose catalysis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decreased MeCP2 signaling has been proposed as pathogenic across a broad range of neurological diseases and cancers; however, pharmaceutical and genetic targeting of MeCP2 is challenging because even a modest increase in expression over normal levels results in toxicity. Here we describe a strategy to prevent the binding of negative regulators of MeCP2 expression as a means to fine-tune MeCP2 dosage in increments that plateau at sub-toxic levels. Using the neurodevelopmental disease Rett syndrome as an example, we will demonstrate how this novel approach is a potentially safe and effective mechanism to treat MeCP2-associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The heart relies on specific nutrients like fatty acids to function normally and demonstrates metabolic flexibility (e.g., glucose utilization) in heart failure and altered nutrient environments. Multifactorial diseases like heart failure may be better understood in the context of inborn errors of metabolism (IEMs), a class of monogenic diseases caused by mutations in metabolic enzymes. Uncovering the consequences of LIPT1 deficiency, an IEM that can cause severe multi-organ dysfunction including cardiac failure, will enhance our understanding of the mechanisms driving heart failure and potentially uncover novel therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol misuse is a leading cause of chronic liver disease; accordingly, rates of alcohol-related mortality have increased 23% since 2019 and progressive scarring of the liver is the main predictor of patient outcomes. The goal of this project is to elucidate novel mechanisms of alcohol-induced fibrotic gene reprogramming in the liver and identify specific factors amplifying liver scarring and disease progression, to provide a foundation for future clinical interventions to prevent or treat liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a poorly understood progressive and fatal age-associated disease. This project will examine the role of senescent cells in matrix remodeling and tissue forces in a 3D bioengineered microtissue culture model of lung fibrosis. The results of this study will elucidate the role of fibroblast senescence in the development and progression of pulmonary fibrosis and identify potential druggable targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Monoterpenoid bisindole alkaloids are a diverse group of natural products that display a rich assortment of bioactivities, including the ability to modulate protein–protein interactions in human cancer cells. The proposed research will develop strategies for the modular and convergent syntheses of bisindole alkaloids and non-natural analogs to enable biological investigations and structure activity relationship studies. The project will positively affect public health by granting access to this highly bioactive class of compounds to further our fundamental understanding of their bioactivity and facilitate the discovery of new anticancer lead compounds.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing interest in whole genome sequencing of newborn genomes as a way to expand NBS to include hundreds of pediatric and actionable diseases (newborn sequencing, NBSeq). In order to reduce false negatives due to variants of unknown significance (VOUS), we will develop two massively parallel, rapid, and inexpensive methods to biochemical annotate the degree of misfolding and degradation of all versions of a protein in which each amino acid is substituted by all possible 19 other amino acids at one substitution per protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dissecting the function of circuits controlling feeding is of vital importance to understand both adaptive eating as well as conditions such as obesity and anorexia. Here, we propose to investigate the function of a cell population in the midbrain that is not well-studied, but is a key control node of food-seeking, as shown in our preliminary data. Successful execution of these aims will provide deep functional characterization of a previously unknown circuit dedicated to food-seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Small molecule bioregulators are reactive species that are utilized by biology to regulate physiological functions through cellular signaling and molecular crosstalk. For some of these species, such as SNO– and SSNO–, the interconnectivity and their involvement in biological signaling pathways are still poorly understood due to their complexity and high reactivity in biological systems. This project will provide insight into how these reactive species can be stabilized which can inform on the reactivities and pathways these molecules engage in in physiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and patients have less therapeutic options compared to other subtypes due to the lack of well-defined, targetable endocrine receptors. Efforts towards targeting other key components of this aggressive tumor subtype, namely macrophage-centered modalities, have had modest success due to TNBC distinct molecular subtypes and diverse macrophage heterogeneity. This research proposal will elucidate a link between the molecular profile of TNBC and macrophage origin and function to establish the tumor's molecular signature as a proxy for macrophage function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial Ca2+ signaling controls important cellular functions and is implicated in the pathogenesis of heart disease, but the regulation of mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake is not well understood. This study will investigate how key signaling molecules regulate mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake. Results obtained here will improve our understanding of mitochondrial Ca2+ signaling and inform the development of therapeutics designed to treat mitochondrial Ca2+ related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A key driver of cardiac bioenergetic abnormalities in heart failure is mitochondrial dysfunction, linked to depletion of mitochondrial NAD+, a vital metabolite required for aerobic metabolism. This proposal seeks to use cutting- edge biochemical, biophysical, and chemical biology approaches to interrogate how mitochondria maintain adequate NAD+ levels to preserve energetic homeostasis through the actions of an essential mitochondrial NAD+ transporter. This work will shed light on a pivotal mechanism dysregulated in disease and may suggest opportunities for countering mitochondrial dysfunction in the treatment of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the loss of substantia nigra dopamine neurons, but our understanding of how their activity state contributes to their selective vulnerability is lacking. Using novel chemogenetic models to manipulate dopamine neuron activity in combination with mice that have disrupted dopamine storage, this proposal will deeply examine the role and mechanisms of neural activity in dopamine neuron susceptibility to dopamine-induced toxicity. Results from the proposed research will aid in the development of therapies to slow or prevent the loss of dopamine neurons and related motor symptoms in PD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal brain injury remains the most common cause of infant mortality and morbidity in infants and children and is a tremendous public health problem. The Hershey Conference on Developmental Brain Injury brings together an international group comprised of leaders in this field, esteemed scientists from outside but related fields, as well as a high proportion of young trainees to continue the important discussions and dissemination of information constantly geared towards finding new and better modes of intervention and neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ASXL1 is one of the most mutated genes in hematological disorders, but it is poorly understood how these mutations are mechanistically linked with these disorders as very little is known about the protein itself. In my preliminary studies, I discovered a degron that regulates the levels of ASXL1 protein, and this proposal will test if and how it regulates hematopoiesis. In the long term, this knowledge will advance our fundamental understanding of ASXL1’s role in primary hematopoiesis, how clinical mutations disrupt that process, and propel the development of new therapeutic strategies for a wide array of hematological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOE4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for sporadic Alzheimer’s disease and affects some genetic ancestries more than others, yet the definitive genetic sources of these clinically-relevant differences are unknown. This proposed work employs an in vitro functional genomics pipeline to comprehensively identify causative ancestry- specific noncoding variants that putatively underlie this differential penetrance. This work will greatly enrich our understanding of genetic predisposition to sporadic Alzheimer’s disease, enabling early identification of the individuals most at risk, stratification of patients into disease-relevant subgroups, and tailored therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In sub-Saharan Africa, malaria and growth failure continue to threaten child health and survival. Intermittent preventative treatment in pregnancy (IPTp) and childhood (IPTc) are promising strategies for malaria control that may also improve growth outcomes through the prevention of mediating factors such as low birthweight, systemic inflammation, and gut microbiome dysbiosis. In this proposed study, we will use causal inference methods to estimate the direct and indirect effects of IPTp and IPTc on child growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Typhoid fever is among the most common invasive bacterial illnesses worldwide, and new conjugate vaccines have demonstrated a high degree of effectiveness in preventing this disease. There is a need for improved tools to understand where typhoid fever burden is greatest, to prioritize vaccine introductions and monitor their impact. This project leverages a cluster-randomized typhoid conjugate vaccine trial to investigate three novel tools—serological, wastewater surveillance, and phylodynamic—to characterize typhoid transmission intensity and evaluate vaccine impact, with a goal of identifying scalable strategies to monitor typhoid burden worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall objective of this in-lab randomized controlled trial is to test the efficacy of multi-day interruptions in sedentary behavior vs. single bouts of sustained exercise on metabolic, cognitive, and affective responses in overweight and obese children at risk for type 2 diabetes. The use of continuous glucose monitoring will provide insight into the daily and cumulative metabolic effects of each condition that have thus far not been studied. In- lab studies demonstrating sustained efficacy of this approach in ameliorating negative effects of sedentary behaviors in children are necessary for the optimization of field-based interventions. Given the lack of success of interventions to prevent obesity-related diseases and increasing rates of type 2 diabetes in children and its related healthcare costs, our proposal addresses a critical public health need by testing of novel intervention strategies to reduce obesity-related diseases in overweight and obese children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Latino Ancestry and other minority populations have been poorly represented in large-scale genomic studies, and yet these populations suffer the largest disparities in health care and outcomes and have the potential to broaden our knowledge of human genetics. The Latino Ancestry-Genomic Psychiatry Cohort (LA-GPC) will combine the Latino Ancestry (AA) participants in this study, the VA-CSP study, the Colombian study and the NeuroMex study creating a study population over 76,000 LA participants. This analysis has the potential for significant novel discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression and anxiety in youth are serious public health concerns for which more targeted prevention efforts are needed. This study tests the efficacy of an app-based mindfulness intervention that specifically targets skills for regulating negative affect in order to prevent anxiety, depression, and associated impairment in at-risk adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Many bats can harbor viruses for prolonged periods of time without developing disease, but the immunological mechanisms that support such asymptomatic chronic infections are unknown. We have recently developed enteroid cultures as a novel in vitro model to study viral infection in the Jamaican fruit bat intestine, which is a key target organ for multiple viruses. In our study, we will infect enteroids derived from Jamaican fruit bat or human tissue with three different RNA viruses and investigate how viral infections impact epithelial antiviral responses and intestinal epithelial cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA and RNA nucleobase modifications are relevant for fundamental biochemical and biophysical experiments and are widespread throughout biology. DNAzymes are catalytic DNA sequences, analogous to protein enzymes as catalytic amino acid sequences, that unlike protein enzymes can be identified from initially random DNA sequence populations by in vitro selection. The proposed Focused Technology Research and Development seeks new DNAzymes for in vitro site-specific acylation and alkylation of the nucleobase amino groups of cytosine, guanine, and adenine, which will enable a range of biochemical, biophysical, and biological experiments involving site-specifically modified DNA and RNA nucleotides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection, even when controlled with antiretroviral therapy, is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD), which occurs at younger ages in persons living with HIV than in the general population. Women living with HIV are at an even greater relative risk for CVD than men when compared to women and men of similar ages in the general population, possibly due to differences in estrogen levels and estrogen receptor function in women with and without HIV. The proposed research will explore the effects of HIV on estrogen receptor gene expression and translation in women, and will look the associations of estrogen receptor gene expression and translation with prevalent and progressive subclinical CVD in women living with and without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the disproportionate morbidity and mortality associated with mental and behavioral health problems in American Indian and Alaska Native communities. Access to culturally competent and effective behavioral health services is limited in these communities. We aim to address this gap by testing the effectiveness of a transdiagnostic secondary prevention program that can be embedded within home visiting services. Our study is grounded in participatory processes and led by a team of Indigenous and allied researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is among the leading causes of death in the US (the second leading cause of death among those 15- 34 years). Approximately 50% of those who die by suicide visit a healthcare provider in the month before they die (often to an emergency department of inpatient psychiatric unit); however, current clinical methods have proven insufficient to reduce the rate of suicide. The proposed Center will implement our most innovative and effective suicide prediction and prevention methods in these settings and rigorously test their ability to decrease the rate of suicidal behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  The internal body clock, our circadian rhythms, control a broad range of processes in humans, timing our sleep cycles, metabolism, the immune response, and many other physiological functions to be optimally coordinated with our persistent day/night cycle. Due to the widespread integration of circadian control over many essential biological processes, the disruption of circadian rhythms has been linked to numerous medical conditions, including chronic inflammation, metabolic disease, and cancer, making an appreciation of clock control over physiology vital to human health research. Given the strong functional conservation between the fungal, murine, and human clocks, our investigation of the fundamental mechanisms and effects of circadian post-transcriptional regulation will broaden the understanding of circadian regulation over human physiology, paving the way for the development of effective chronotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Gene regulatory networks underlie animal development and physiological homeostasis, and perturbations in these networks cause developmental defects and pernicious diseases such as cancer. The key to curing such conditions is to elucidate underlying mechanisms, particularly regarding transcriptional regulation. Here we propose to uncover the rules governing one of the most fundamental aspects of transcriptional control—the role of chromosome organization and nuclear architecture on the dynamics of gene activity—with the goal to control and re-engineer the transcriptional programs underlying developmental and disease processes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rare but lethal disease that is highly associated with bone morphogenetic protein receptor II (BMPR2) mutations. Here we seek to develop therapies that rescue the aberrant hypoxic response using exogenous extracellular vesicles, and pursue strategies toward improved pharmacokinetics and therapeutic index.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and obesity are more frequently seen in postmenopausal women, but causes of these conditions are not clear. Work proposed in this grant aims to test the overall hypothesis that P21-activated kinase 1 (PAK1) regulatory activities in the heart and the adipose tissue are governed by estrogens and that PAK1 dysregulation, due to decreased estrogen levels, affects cardiac and adipose tissue function. These studies will explain, at least in part, the higher incidence of HFpEF and obesity in women and will provide new targets for future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative Despite evidence linking chemotherapy treatments to cognitive impairments and accelerated aging, these phenomenon (and potential interventions) have remained understudied. This area of research would benefit greatly from the establishment of a primate model with neurological, cognitive, and aging characteristics more similar to humans. Therefore, we are proposing further characterizing brain and cognitive aging in a nonhuman primate model (Olive baboons), determining if cisplatin impairs cognitive functioning and accelerates aging as it does in human patients, and testing a promising intervention which has only been tested in mice.

PHR: Project Narrative The overall objective of this proposal is to develop a new, endocannabinoid-based treatment for the related but distinct inherited metabolic disorders, Type A/B and Type C Niemann-Pick disease. No treatments currently exist for the life-threatening central nervous system (CNS) manifestations of these diseases, and we will address this important unmet medical need. We will explore the mechanism(s) underlying this new treatment approach, continue to examine its efficacy using animal and cell models, and use genomic, computational and other technologies to compare the CNS pathologies and relatedness to common neurodegenerative diseases.

The results of this study will be essential in determining parameters for antimicrobial use in the treatment of animals, and for developing “One-Health” interventions to reduce the spread of antimicrobial resistance between animals and humans.
