IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PAR-20-124, NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens (U01)  MD Department of Health, 2020 PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotics have inexorably changed the landscape of public health as they play a significantly role in the treatment of infectious diseases. However, antimicrobial resistance caused by excessive or incorrect use of antibiotics has become one of the major public health issues. Foodborne pathogens can also develop resistance to certain antibiotics via the exposure of antimicrobials agents primarily from inappropriate use within agricultural practices, leading to circulation within our current food production system. These pathogens can also serve as reservoirs for antimicrobial mobile genetic elements that may transfer to other pathogens. As a result, the growing trend of antibiotic resistance of foodborne pathogens continues to elevate concerns of food safety within the United States. The main goal of the FDA NARMS cooperative agreement project with Maryland Department of Health is to isolate and characterize foodborne pathogens including Salmonella, Campylobacter sp., E. coli, Enterococcus sp., Vibrio sp., Aeromonas sp. from several retail food products purchased from stores across Maryland. After the pathogens have been isolated, they are subjected to downstream phenotypic and genotypic characterizations as well as whole genome sequencing. The isolates and data are submitted to the FDA monthly. The Maryland Department of Health, Laboratories Administration has the capability and capacity to implement the current project and future pilot projects using advanced technologies to further characterize these isolates including speciation, serotyping, and whole genome sequencing.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative  Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens in Kansas as a Part of the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System  As a key activity in combating bacterial antimicrobial resistance, the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) has since 1996 monitored resistance in foodborne pathogens and other enteric bacteria of food-animals at the time of animal processing; in red meat, poultry, and seafood sold in retail; and in human foodborne infections in the U.S. The monitoring in food products sold in retail is coordinated by the Food and Drug Administration – Center for Veterinary Medicine. This project will strengthen and ensure continuation of the antimicrobial resistance monitoring in food products retailed in Kansas, which is one of the major food producing states. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens in Kansas as a Part of the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: The Minnesota Department of Agriculture (MDA) has been working with the Minnesota Department of Health (MDH), CDC, and FDA on the Retail Food Study since its inception in 2002. In Minnesota, MDA and MDH are culturing fresh meats from retail locations for Salmonella, fresh poultry for Campylobacter and participating in the seafood pilot study. This study has contributed substantial data to our understanding of the species, serotypes, and antimicrobial resistance types of Campylobacter and Salmonella found in various retail meats and has helped guide foodborne disease outbreak investigations where meats may have been the source of infection in humans.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Khulani Siphile Siphuhle Training Program (KiSS-TP) will to train South African researchers from historically disadvantaged institutions (HDIs) of Eastern Cape Province in HIV research among adolescents, men, and those with co-morbid TB or Mental Health. We will offer intensive, mentored PhD training to select Masters-level faculty and staff at University of Fort Hare (UFH), Walter Sisulu University (WSU) and the Desmond Tutu Health Foundation’s (DTHF) Eastern Cape office; UFH and WSU are two of South Africa’s eight designated HDIs. We will also strengthen PhD training capacity through professional and career development of UFH and WSU faculty. Consortium include: DTHF, UFH, WSU, University of Cape Town & University of California Global Health Institute.

PHR: Project narrative One bottleneck in the treatment of heart attacks is the efficient retention of cellular therapies to the site of infarct, even when locally delivered via direct injection. Here we propose to develop an injectable, living drug depot that crosslinks into a scaffold at the infarct site to enhance the accumulation and retention of cardioregenerative drugs and allow for subsequent, customizable drug refills. This will personalize and improve treatment by providing opportunities for dose control and drug manipulation in response to disease evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Following rotator cuff tear, injury-related physical burdens and financial costs can be substantial, and the success of surgical intervention (reattachment without future rupture) and post-surgical functional outcomes cannot currently be accurately predicted. This research will investigate the impact of clinically relevant parameters measured pre- and intra-operatively on surgical success and post-surgery shoulder function. Investigating the factors that determine surgical success and post-surgery shoulder function will improve the treatment of individuals with rotator cuff injury and support their independence and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In recent years, understanding the neurobiological basis for substance use disorder (SUD) has been on the forefront of scientific agendas, which has elucidated sex as a significant biological variable in vulnerability to addiction. Females represent a particularly vulnerable population in developing cocaine use disorder and circulating gonadal hormones have been elucidated as key regulators of the dopamine system, drug responses, and motivated behavior associated with SUD. Defining the factors that underlie female-specific drug responses are critical to effectively treating them; however we must first elucidate how these sex differences fit into the comprehensive framework of dopamine regulation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Compelling reasons exist to both aggressively evaluate injured children for intra-abdominal injuries (IAI) and to limit abdominal CT evaluation to solely those at non-negligible risk. The focused assessment sonography for trauma (FAST) examination can help focus patient evaluation in just this manner by potentially decreasing CT use in low risk children, and therefore the overall objectives of this proposal are 1) to determine the efficacy of using the FAST examination during the initial evaluation of children with blunt abdominal trauma, and 2) to identify factors associated with abdominal CT use in children considered very low risk for IAI after a negative FAST examination. The long-term objective of the research is to determine appropriate evaluation strategies to optimize the care of injured children, leading to improved quality of care and a reduction in morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a debilitating symptom of mid to late-stage osteoarthritis causing patients to avoid activities of daily living due to pain during loading. Osteoarthritis is a complex disease involving cartilage, immune cells, and neural cells, however no study to date has tried to tease apart the relationship between mechanical loading and immune activation in osteoarthritis pain. This project will be a step forward in understanding how mechanical signals interact with immune cells to induce mechanically activated pain thus providing a potential new avenue for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: SUMMARY NARRATIVE Low- and middle-income countries experience a high burden of gender-based violence (GBV) and violence against children (VAC); yet, institutional and investigator research capacity is limited, and large data gaps limit the ability to monitor violence-related Sustainable Development Goals. To address this need, Emory University, Hanoi Medical University, and a multidisciplinary network of experts will create CONVERGE, The Consortium for Violence Prevention Research, Implementation, and Training for Excellence. We will implement a four- component program to train a critical mass of long-term post-doctoral fellows (n=15), short-term mid-career research trainees (n=40), and short-term practitioner trainees (n=60), creating a pipeline of professionals skilled in research mentorship, research in GBV and VAC, implementation science, leadership/science dissemination for sustained capacity in GBV and VAC research and practice in Vietnam.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some types of cancers, as exemplified by estrogen receptor positive breast cancer, can recur as metastatic disease many years or even decades following a dormancy period where the patient displays no clinical symptoms. This proposal seeks to engineer T cells as ultrasensitive biosensors to detect dormant cancer and when they reawaken.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease is a chronic illness that represents a significant public health and economic burden, and there is an urgent need to improve our understanding of modulators of intestinal inflammation in order to identify novel therapeutic targets. Recent studies from our lab have demonstrated that specialized immune cells known as group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) respond to neuronal-derived signals to promote expulsion of intestinal parasites, but whether or not these same signals activate the tissue protective functions of these cells is unclear. The focus of this proposal is to dissect the role of this neuro-immune signaling pathway in the regulation of intestinal inflammation.

PHR: We propose to develop a comprehensive set of statistical methods for analyzing data collected from spatially resolved transcriptomics studies to advance biological discoveries. IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: CONNECTICUT STATE DEPT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: The State of Connecticut Department of Public Health PAR-20-124 NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens(U01) Clinical Trials Not Allowed Project Narrative The purpose of the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) Retail Meat Surveillance Program is to protect and promote public health by strengthening and sustaining antibiotic resistance surveillance in retail food samples. The goal of this surveillance project is to determine the prevalence of antibiotic resistance among Salmonella, Campylobacter, Escherichia coli, Enterococcus, Vibrio, Aeromonas, and other lactose positive bacteria isolated from retail food samples purchased from grocery stores in the United States. Data from this project will contribute to improving the detection and surveillance of resistance among foodborne bacteria, promote interventions to reduce drug resistance by determining limitations for antibiotic use in veterinary medicine, and by assisting in the development of pre-approval safety evaluation for new animal antibiotics.

PROJECT_TITLE: The State of Connecticut Department of Public Health Retail Food Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Parasitic nematodes remain a significant public health problem in many parts of the world, with Ascaris alone infects upwards of 1 billion people and hinders socioeconomic development in endemic areas. We will carry out molecular and genomic studies on an unusual form of genome re-organization and mechanism of gene regulation in Ascaris, programmed DNA elimination. These studies have the potential to identify novel molecular mechanisms that may represent novel drug targets in these organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Histones are highly-conserved proteins that regulate gene expression and are mutated in cancers. We recently identified a testis-specific histone variant, H2A.B, that is aberrantly upregulated in a broad array of common cancers and mimics cancer-associated mutant histones. This proposal is designed to identify the mechanism by which H2A.B contributes to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant examines how liver cells damaged due to excess fat release small particles called extracellular vesicles which contain a danger signal called S100A11 to activate white blood cells termed macrophages, via a receptor called RAGE. These macrophages, in turn cause liver damage. This research is important because increasing obesity has resulted in large numbers of people with fatty liver disease, for which there are no proven treatments, and with these studies we aim to identify new potential treatments.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: MISSOURI STATE DEPT/ HEALTH & SENIOR SRV
PHR: Project Narrative The Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS), Missouri State Public Health Laboratory (MSPHL) proposes to support the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) Retail Meat Surveillance Program by continuing its current sampling of retail meats and testing for Salmonella and Campylobacter, Enterococcus, Aeromonas, Vibrio and other lactose positive bacteria.,. This project will enhance the collection of data on the occurrence of antibiotic resistant bacteria in the nation’s retail meat supply, and further the aims of NARMS through data sharing with state and federal epidemiologists. In addition, the sharing and review of testing and antimicrobial data will be used by epidemiology programs to detect food borne disease outbreaks and coordinate investigations; educate state and local public health officials and the general public on current and emerging health hazards; support food safety program awareness of antimicrobial resistance among the public; analyze for trends to inform state health agency management and assist with policy development; and data will be used by the laboratory to assess accuracy of testing results and quality assurance practices. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with sickle cell anemia (SCA) lack fundamental information about their reproductive lifespan and whether SCA or its therapies reduce ovarian reserve. This research measures ovarian reserve in women with SCA and investigates if SCA or its primary treatment, hydroxyurea, is associated with diminished ovarian reserve. A qualitative study of how women with SCA consider treatment choices which may compromise fertility augments the quantitative aims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative:  Natural enzymes present exquisite control of efficiency and selectivity of chemical reactions, but how to predict enzyme variants to transform non-native chemical processes is broadly recognized as a “Holy Grail” in chemistry and biology because it will allow researchers to find effective enzyme variants to degrade environmental pollutants, conduct late-stage functionalization of drug molecules, and treat food allergies. Directed evolution has been widely applied to identify optimal enzyme variants for non-native reactions, but how to accelerate the screening cycles remains a critical roadblock due to the unknown relationship between sequence, structure, and kinetics for enzyme catalysis. My research program emphasizes developing computational platforms for the identification of function-enhancing enzyme variants to transform non-native enzymatic reactions, with an ultimate goal of delivering enabling computational tools for virtual prediction and design of function-enhancing enzyme variants for biomedical and biocatalytic uses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Signal transduction pathways underlie the very basis of life and are often critical targets for disease therapeutics. This work focuses on the molecular events of Notch signaling, which exerts a critical influence on cell differentiation in mammals and its misregulation is associated with diverse diseases, including the pathogenesis of many human cancers. This work will use two emerging technologies, proximity labeling and lattice light sheet microscopy, to provide unprecedented resolution in both space and time of the fundamental events required for transmission of physiologic Notch signals in living cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Current U.S. guidelines recommend a daily “baby” aspirin, begun after the first trimester, to prevent preeclampsia. However, data suggest that a higher dosage of aspirin and initiating treatment immediately upon pregnancy recognition, instead of waiting until 12 weeks' of pregnancy, may have a greater beneficial effect, while additionally protecting against pregnancy loss. We propose a randomized trial of 162 mg aspirin (equivalent to two “baby” aspirin) begun by 6 weeks' gestation in a diverse population to evaluate its effect on preventing pregnancy loss and preeclampsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a condition that persists beyond the time required for normal tissue healing or arises in the absence of a discernable tissue insult, suggesting that it is a phenomenon mediated by the central nervous system. This work will therefore provide a potential target for novel pain therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances of spatial technologies enable the elucidation of single-cell spatial heterogeneity, with unprecedented opportunities to decipher the underlying mechanisms of disease etiology and drug therapeutics. However, there is a lack of computational methods that leverage the strengths of data from different sources (e.g., genomics, epigenomics, clinical data) to achieve multi-modal insights into the spatially distributed cells. In this project, we propose to develop a series of computational methods to recover the full picture of spatial profiles, unleash the power of spatial profiles for deciphering the regulatory mechanisms underpinning diseases and drug response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many cardiac arrest (CA) patients now survive neurologically intact, but evidence from the new field of CA survivorship research suggests that cardiac anxiety, physical inactivity, and poor sleep are common—and may increase survivors' high cardiovascular and mortality risk. This will be the first cohort study of CA survivors to comprehensively assess psychological distress, objectively monitor physical activity and sleep, and rigorously adjudicate cardiovascular events and mortality at 12 months after hospital discharge. In a diverse group of CA survivors, we will estimate the prospective association of cardiac anxiety and behavioral factors with CVD event-free survival and quality of life, to provide the most rigorous data to date on psycho-behavioral contributors to secondary risk in CA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive cell therapies using receptor engineered cells have been highly effective at curing cancers of the blood and are currently being extended to the treatment of a wide range of diseases including chronic viral infections, autoimmune diseases, and other cancers. Cell-based therapeutics are living drugs, and a major challenge to creating them for new disease indications is a lack of precise control, leading to off-target effects and overactivity, potentially causing deadly toxicities. We are developing general strategies to precisely control receptor engineered cells through chemical ON- and OFF-switches that enable temporal control by pharmacological agents and added specificity through sensing of distinct disease signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The drive to be “person-centered” in the care of patients in advanced cardiac care is both intuitive and politically popular – enjoying explicit support from the IOM, AMA, AGS, ACC, FDA, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, in the Patient Protection & Affordable Care Act, and elsewhere. Optimal means by which to be patient centered in the real-world, however, is unknown. Critically examining the ways in which healthcare providers assess patient values will be necessary to innovate the manner in which this assessment occurs and is integrated into care for patients. The overarching objective of this career development award is to continue the professional and methodologic growth of Christopher Knoepke, PhD, MSW, LCSW, into an independent clinical social work scientist leading the field of cardiology toward improved patient-centered care by means of 1) contextually-appropriate qualitative assessment of patient values in clinical settings; 2) understanding what clinical providers need in order to actually implement improved values clarification methods into practice; and 3) studying the effectiveness and implementation integration of new models of patient decision support using pragmatic trial techniques.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Narrative: Chronic pain remains a significant clinical problem. Current treatments have limitations such as development of tolerance and abuse potential. Thus, there is a need to identify new therapeutic targets. The pathways via which brain perceives pain undergo significant functional changes during persistent pain. However, the key components of synapses within these pathways and their roles in persistence of pain are not well understood. We propose to understand the role of a type of glutamate receptor which appears to be critical for maintaining key nodes in the pain pathways.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: SC DHEC PHL-NARMS Narrative The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (SC-DHEC) , Public Health Laboratory (PHL), serves as the state public health Laboratory, working towards improving the quality of life for South Carolinians by protecting and promoting the health of the public and the environment. The purpose of this project is to increase surveillance for antibiotic resistance in enteric bacteria from retail meat and seafood samples. During this cooperative agreement, the Food Microbiology Laboratory will maintain laboratory capacity by continuing to implement NARMS retail meat and seafood surveillance protocols. Testing will be performed bimonthly with 20 retail meat samples being tested at each time point and 8 seafood samples being tested monthly. The SC-DHEC PHL will follow all protocols provided by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Bacteria isolated from retail meat and seafood samples will be characterized where appropriate by serology, whole genome sequencing (WGS), and sent to the FDA Center for Veterinary Medicine (FDA-CVM) for antibiotic sensitivities. Results will be shared with the Center for Disease Control (CDC), the FDA, and DHEC Foodborne Epidemiologists. Data will be used to drive identification of foodborne disease outbreaks. Antibiotic resistance data collected, as a result of the surveillance activities, will be analyzed and monitored for trends. Data will be disseminated to state epidemiologists, and when appropriate, State Sentinel Hospitals. These activities performed in support of this cooperative agreement will strengthen national efforts to monitor antimicrobial resistance among enteric bacteria isolated from retail meats and seafood and provide data to drive public health policy and program development.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: NARMS Cooperative Agreement Program to Strengthen Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance in Retail Food Specimens

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 25% of Veterans have type 2 diabetes compared with 8% in the general population in the U.S. Diabetic Veterans are at a higher risk for complications from numerous infectious diseases, including severe viral respiratory tract infections, such as those caused by SARS-CoV-2 (COVID), influenza and adenovirus. For example, diabetic patients account for over 30% of the hospitalizations from influenza and are more likely to have worse clinical outcomes from other severe viral respiratory tract infections. Survival from these severe infections often results in altered lung structure which can impair lung function and increase the long-term risks of pneumonia, hospitalization, and death in diabetic Veterans. The goal of this project is to develop a diabetic animal model to study the basic mechanisms of the damaging inflammation associated with human respiratory virus-induced lung injury in diabetics. This increased understanding can be used as a basis for advances in therapeutic interventions to prevent related short-term and long-term lung dysfunction in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The Add Health Parent Study (AHPS) is an innovative project in which a multiethnic/racial and interdisciplinary team of scientists will collect longitudinal cognitive, social, behavioral, and biological data on parents of the members of the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health). The proposed Phase 2 of AHPS will increase the samples of Non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic parents in AHPS, consent and ad- minister an Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) Assessment, collect DNA, link longitudinal AHPS data to longitudinal Add Health data, harmonize cognitive measures across the two generations, assemble a multigenerational genomic database, and make these new data available to the scientific community of 50,000+ Add Health and AHPS users. This project will facilitate the study of racial/eth- nic disparities in cognitive aging, caregiving, and AD/ADRD risk across two generations with longitudinal, na- tionally representative data collected from adult children and their parents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to understand the potential and mechanisms of germline mutagenesis induced at meiotic DNA double-strand breaks. Double-strand breaks are introduced genome wide during meiosis to initiate recombination between chromosome homologs in preparation for the reductional division to give rise to haploid gametes, but they are also known to be genome destabilizing lesions in somatic cells. Following up on our recent discoveries of germline deletions and duplications at meiotic breaks, this project pursues aims to understand the mechanisms that give rise to these events, the range of events at meiotic breaks, and the effect of age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a lethal cancer with a 5-year survival rate ~10% and is predicted to become the second deadliest cancer within the next 10 years. Epigenetic changes regulating gene expression have become a focus of intense research to help in the development of new treatment for this dismal condition. This proposal will investigate the role of nuclear myosins in chromatin organization leading epigenetic silencing of gene expression during PDAC transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to make available to scientists a uniquely powerful 7 Tesla brain MRI scanner, located at UC Berkeley, which achieves unprecedented spatial resolution in human brain research. We will create infrastructure to allow broad and efficient use of this scanner, by enabling in-person and remote access for international teams of neuroscientists, physicists, engineers, and clinicians to use the NexGen 7T MRI scanner. The proposed dissemination of the scanner will allow higher granularity in human neuroscience research with the capability of showing circuitry and neuronal activity at different cell layer depths in the neocortex.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Achieving Maternal Equity and Transforming Health through Implementation Science and Training (AMETHIST@Penn) The Achieving Maternal Equity and Transforming Health through Implementation Science and Training (AMETHIST@Penn) Hub will support the vision of the NIH IMPROVE initiative by providing consultation and technical assistance to Maternal Health Research Centers of Excellence and other IMPROVE investigators. The AMETHIST@Penn team will work closely with NIH staff and the Data Innovation and Coordinating Hub/Resource Center and will support equity-focused maternal health implementation research through five Cores: (1) Administration, Leadership, and Evaluation; (2) Equity, Community, and Stakeholder Engagement; (3) Design, Methods, and Analysis; (4) Policy, Dissemination, and Communication; and (5) Training and Capacity Building. AMETHIST@Penn will advise IMPROVE investigators in engaging diverse and sometimes marginalized communities; guide the process of implementation research including the selection of theories, models, frameworks, strategies, and outcomes; accelerate implementation skills development in emerging and established maternal health scientists; and advance knowledge about successfully conducting implementation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging clinician-scientists need translational science training to translate evidence to practices and policies that are critical in improving population health. This K24 award will use the RE-AIM framework to examine the reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation (fidelity and cost) and maintenance of drinking water promotion and access interventions in schools and childcare centers that are being examined as a childhood obesity prevention strategy through two large cluster-randomized trials. This award will: 1) generate new research that will help adapt and translate these interventions to community settings, 2) provide rich training experiences in translational patient-oriented research, and 3) enhance Dr. Patel’s career development in research, leadership, and mentoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Carriers of the APOE4 gene are at a significantly increased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and recent epidemiological studies have shown that APOE4 carriers who are infected with the herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) have an even higher risk of AD. In order to investigate the potential synergy between APOE4 and HSV-1 in AD susceptibility, we will perform a series of experiments where APOE mice and cells are infected with HSV-1 for long periods of time, and the effects on memory and pathology are assessed. We will also test the effects of an antiviral medication to prevent these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  The overall goal of this proposal is to obtain a better mechanistic understanding of resilience to aging at the molecular, cellular, organ, and systemic physiological levels in order to identify therapeutic targets. The public health significance relates to the ability to therapeutically enhance resilience to aging and age-related diseases in individuals predicted to be less resilient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to colonize and inhabit the human microbiome, both pathogenic and commensal microbes must adapt to withstand complex stressful conditions, such as oxygen and nutrient limitation. Investigation into how the interaction of stresses influence microbial evolution is important for a deeper understanding of the infectious disease process and can lead to future targets for antimicrobial therapies and novel approaches to disease prevention.

PHR: Project narrative Mitis group streptococci are recognized as causative agents of a variety of human diseases and have shown to be resistant to numerous antibiotics. This study aims to identify how cellular stress and immune responses contribute to bacterial recognition and clearance during infection. In addition, the study could potentially identify new target strategies to combat the action of these pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project seeks to examine population-level clustering of syndemic factors (stigma, depression, material insecurity, polysubstance use, intimate partner violence, and police and other violence) and HIV-associated noncommunicable diseases (HIVNCD) in a population of sexual and gender minorities living with HIV/AIDS in Nigeria. It will provide critical data for informing the development of integrated, multilevel interventions intended to remediate disparities in HIVNCD and their outcomes among sexual and gender minorities in sub-Saharan Africa and other similar settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We lack sufficient data about the complex relationships at the intersectionality of disparities, aging and cancer, perpetuating health inequities and leaving older survivors and their oncology teams with insufficient evidence to guide care, especially older racial/ethnic survivors for whom data is virtually lacking. My population science laboratory will lead teams of transdisciplinary researchers and advocates to fill this gap by providing a mechanistic understanding of the role of cellular aging in the relationships between social determinants of health and quality of life of diverse older cancer survivors. We will use this paradigm to conduct human and animal studies to Identify and test aging mechanistically-based interventions that can support efforts to tailor clinical care for the growing older minority survivor population and transform how we approach cancer disparities in the context of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The risk of assigning an inaccurate diagnosis of Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) is high among older Chinese Americans due to language barriers and cultural differences. Although the English and Spanish versions of the National Alzheimer’s Coordinating Center’s Uniform Data Set assessment battery have been successfully created and utilized for AD/ADRD research, the battery is not available in Chinese languages, despite being the third most spoken languages in the US. The availability of appropriate cultural/linguistic test batteries and corresponding normative data will yield more accurate interpretation and diagnosis of AD/ADRD for older Chinese Americans, which can lead to improved health equity and reduced disease/treatment disparities in this underrepresented group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will establish the feasibility and acceptability of a dyadic mind-body intervention, “Recovering Together after Cardiac Arrest (RT-CA).” RT-CA aims to improve emotional distress and quality life in cardiac arrest survivors and their informal caregivers (i.e., family or friends who provide the majority of support), which is an under- resourced population that experiences chronic distress (40-61%). RT-CA has the potential to improve cardiac arrest survivorship for survivors and their caregivers by teaching mind-body skills and providing necessary resources to navigate survivorship challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The tobacco use burden in Lebanon is exceptionally high: 35% of adults are current cigarette smokers and 39% are current waterpipe smokers. The evidence for smoking cessation interventions comes primarily from high-income countries and they have rarely been tested in low-resource settings. The objective of this proposal is to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of promising multi-component interventions for implementing evidence-based cessation treatment in Lebanon’s national system of primary healthcare centers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children living in rural regions of the United States (US) have reduced access to medical care and few chances to participate in research. This project will address this problem by working in collaboration with a group of pediatric researchers to develop and conduct research studies that improve general knowledge of diseases common in children in rural areas, such as asthma, opioid addiction, and obesity. By enhancing the research skills of junior researchers and supporting research interactions with communities, this project will increase research participation and enhance the health of children living in rural regions of the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African-American women have disturbingly high rates of CHD relative to women of other racial/ethnic backgrounds, and sleep disturbance is hypothesized to be an important driver of this excess risk. Yet the determinants of sleep disturbance in African-American women remain poorly understood. The goal of the proposed research is to determine whether and how “shifting,” a commonly described, but understudied phenomenon with high relevance for African-American women, might be associated with sleep disturbance and elevated CHD risk in this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple myeloma is a cancer of bone marrow plasma cells that remains virtually incurable, partly to interactions with the bone marrow microenvironment, which promote colonization, progression, and survival of myeloma cells. During the F99 phase, I will develop biomaterials-based strategies to deliver nucleic acids to the bone marrow microenvironment, as a novel form of multiple myeloma therapy, to disrupt interactions between myeloma cells and the bone marrow. For the K00 phase, I propose to study cell-cell interactions in the tumor immune microenvironment that promote myeloma progression and drug resistance employing high-dimensional single-cell approaches and tissue-engineered models, to ultimately uncover novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability, and accounts for more than 5.5 million deaths each year worldwide. The ability to noninvasively image brain oxygenation in these patients is a critical unmet need that will help stratify patients for emerging therapies. This project develops novel MRI methods to quantify brain tissue oxygenation, and enhances these measurements with simultaneous [15O]-oxygen PET on a hybrid PET/MRI scanner. PET/MRI also is optimally leveraged to assess oxygen metabolism dynamics that support functional brain connections at rest. Our study will provide innovative, accessible imaging tools to understand altered cerebral oxygen metabolism in cerebrovascular patients and how it relates to brain network dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic is caused by the Sars-CoV-2 coronavirus that has infected over 40 million people worldwide, has resulted in >210,000 deaths in the U.S., and is expected to cost the U.S. health care system $8 trillion. The primary goal of the proposed research is to define the mechanisms by which dysregulation of the blood clotting system mediates severe COVID-19 disease. This research program is highly relevant to public health because it will foster creative discoveries for targeting clotting factors to develop improved therapies for treating Sars-CoV-2-infected patients to reduce COVID-19 morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study is important to public health as it will be perhaps the first study to rigorously test a network-based intervention designed to increase cervical cancer (CC) screening and treatment in sub-Saharan Africa by empowering women who have been screened for CC to be critical change agents for CC screening among women in their social network. In settings of high HPV and CC prevalence such as Uganda, where virtually every family is touched by someone living with cervical cancer risk, successfully mobilizing screened women to be advocates for CC screening and treatment could have a significant impact in the fight to control CC. The study will also assess the ability of diverse clinics to integrate, implement and sustain the intervention over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood disorders that exhibit overproduction of blood components develop upon the acquisition of genetic mutations in genes such as CALR and result in disease states called myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN). A major gap in our understanding of treating patients with MPN is the patient-to-patient variable outcome, including therapy-resistance to treatments such as interferon-alfa. Here, by applying novel tools that can sequence many genes in individual cells (`single-cell sequencing') on patient samples and mouse models, we seek to uncover the mechanisms of therapy-resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a complex cardiac disease is a leading cause of heart failure. The emergence of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology offers an experimental human-based model to predict and model individual disease manifestations. The goal of this project is to study the underlying mechanisms of DCM by investigating the intricate crosstalk between cardiomyocytes and endothelial cells using bioengineering tools and next generation sequencing. Results from this work could potentially lead to new strategies that could lower morbidity and mortality, but also improve the management of DCM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), continues to be a leading cause of cancer-related death in HIV-infected individuals. Notably, those with DLBCLs that are infected with the opportunistic cancer-causing Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) suffer from worse overall survival compared to their EBV-negative counterparts – highlighting the importance of focusing on EBV-associated factors and pathways. In this application, we address how EBV rewires cellular DNA repair to make DLBCLs vulnerable to innovative synthetic lethal therapies with the ultimate goals of developing clinically actionable signatures to predict therapeutic responsiveness of individual tumors and improving outcomes for those with EBV+ HIV-DLBCL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use is a common risk factor for both HIV acquisition and poor uptake and use of effective biomedical HIV prevention options, including pre- and post-exposure prophylaxis, in sub-Saharan Africa. Moving HIV services out of health facilities and into community settings is a key innovation that has increased reach and engagement in HIV testing and treatment services, but remains underdeveloped for biomedical HIV prevention services. This K24 award will support Dr. Chamie by providing him protected time to mentor early career researchers with an interest in patient-oriented research at the intersection of HIV prevention and alcohol use, including community-based HIV prevention for adults at alcohol drinking venues, in East Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance/Narrative: There is growing evidence that cellular senescence plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of chronic liver diseases. Our studies will dissect the role of the activin A/p15INK4b axis in inducing senescence and how it impacts chronic liver disease progression. Uncovering mechanism(s) and identifying essential mediators of hepatocyte senescence will provide fundamental new information for developing novel therapeutic strategies to halt progression of chronic liver diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consent, assent, and decision-making are regularly encountered in the clinical and research settings but can be stymied in youth and adults with Down syndrome (DS) because of their intellectual disabilities, their receptive and expressive communication differences, and their providers' and potential research partners' limited expertise in the self-efficacy arena. This national patient-centered study seeks input from a diverse group of people with DS and caregivers on the use of multi-media materials to promote understanding/ appreciation of study purpose, procedures, risks/benefits and will be complemented by discussions surrounding decision-making involvement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every year, nearly 400,000 Americans rupture their anterior cruciate ligament and more than half of them develop post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) within 15 years. By objectively capturing movement during both natural environment ambulation and physical therapy, the proposed research will inform the development of more effective rehabilitation therapies assisted by wearable technology and computer vision/machine learning, promising to halt PTOA and extend the lifespan of natural joints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Diet-induced obesity (DIO) is the most common form of obesity in humans. This research project will test a novel concept that truncated TrkB receptors (TrkB.T) in astrocytes play a critical role in the development of DIO. Our studies will likely show that attenuating TrkB.T-mediated Ca2+ signals in astrocytes can be a novel and effective strategy for therapeutic interventions of DIO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to precisely target human disease relies on knowing what genes in what cells are dysregulated, yet current approaches using bulk tissue often lack cell-type information. We will develop innovative methods to identify disease-associated gene-cell pairs by integrating large-scale molecular data of patient and cell cohorts. The proposed approaches can be applied across human diseases to find new diagnostic markers and treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insufficient sleep is a prevalent health issue that is associated with metabolic, psychiatric, and neurodegenerative diseases and disorders among others. Understanding the role of different types of brain cells in the regulation of sleep and wakefulness is fundamental to understanding the cellular and molecular basis of normal and disordered sleep. This proposal focuses on identifying how non-neuronal brain cells (i.e. astrocytes) interact with neurons to regulate sleep need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite a strong evidence-base for the efficacy of asthma care intervention programs in reducing asthma morbidity among low-income minority children, gaps remain in our understanding of how best to translate and scale up these efficacious interventions into sustainable, broad-based programs that reduce known asthma health disparities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal outlines plans for the development of new methods and general strategies for chemical synthesis of complex, bioactive organic compounds. The results from this endeavor will produce new synthesis “tools” that will enable medicinal chemists in academia, government labs, and the pharmaceutical industry to more easily access intricate molecules that are needed for biomedical studies and for the development of pharmaceutical drugs. The challenging projects that will be examined will provide excellent problem-solving skills and training in synthetic organic chemistry for graduate students and postdoctoral associates and prepare them for careers in biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Most research to date has focused on transcriptional, epigenetic, electrophysiological and morphological adaptations within neurons to understand drug addiction and relapse. The experiments described in this proposal seek to elucidate important changes occurring in a less well-studied cell type, the astrocyte, and are supported by my recent data that demonstrate a dynamic role for astrocytes within the brain reward circuitry during heroin relapse. The proposed research will address the mechanisms by which astroglial plasticity is triggered by and associates with the local circuitry to attenuate cue-induced heroin seeking and provide me with training in techniques required to more clearly define the role of astrocytes in shaping neural signaling during drug relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer immunotherapies are often focused on activating of engineering a subset of T cells that exhibit selective recognition of Class I or Class II tumor neoantigens. We propose to develop an integrated nanotech, biomolecular engineering, and microtech suite of tools towards identifying and characterizing CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses against neoantigen, with a focus on those neoantigens that have the potential to be presented by every cancer cell in a tumor. The proposed methodology, as well as data set, will be of high value to the fundamental and clinical immuno-oncology communities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  County governments in the U.S. passed policies during the COVID-19 pandemic that led to job loss, as well as policies that provided economic support. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Aged individuals are prone to intervertebral disc degeneration and there is no intermediary treatment between palliative care and invasive surgery to stem its progression. We propose to clarify the molecular mechanisms underlying intervertebral disc degeneration and to establish the promising viability of FDA-approved bone prophylactics anti-sclerostin antibody and raloxifene to reverse/attenuate intervertebral disc degeneration in aged mice. Completion of this proposal will (1) bolster the potentially safe application of pharmacological therapeutics in the elderly for whom habitual maintenance of the spine by strenuous exercise can be limited and (2) will potentially prolong the need for invasive surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will optimize the dosing concentration and timing of treatment initiation of a promising, novel, orally available TREM2 (Triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2) activating compound, Sob-AM2. It will also evaluate the effects of TREM2 activation by oral Sob-AM2 on Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology, cognitive function and neuroinflammation using mouse models of beta-amyloid accumulation and tauopathy. By conducting these essential preclinical experiments, this project will provide critical information about the therapeutic utility of this recently discovered drug for use in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NK cell deficiency (NKD) patients have abnormal NK immune cell defenses, leading to severe viral infections, cancer, and often death. We have assembled the world’s largest group of NKD patients and, using advanced genomic, analytic, and NK cell biological techniques, have discovered over 12 gene mutations responsible for their disease. This grant aims to identify more NKD genes and in so doing learn more about how NK cells work and protect us from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most cancer patients die when their tumors “progress” by metastasizing or becoming resistant to therapy. We developed techniques to study tumor metabolism directly in patients, and as a result discovered metabolic properties that promote cancer progression and early death. We will now 1) block these pathways to prolong survival in mouse models of cancer; 2) develop methods to discover more metabolic properties that drive cancer progression in patients and could be blocked with new therapies; and 3) use a unique orthogonal approach based on rare genetic diseases to discover how some metabolic defects prime cells to become malignant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH BENEFIT  This proposal will develop a new therapy that will help to cure drug-susceptible and drug-resistant forms of tuberculosis. It will also have the potential to reduce the length of time need to treat tuberculosis and inhibit new resistance from occurring. If our research goals are achieved, the novel therapy would be an important step towards the global eradication of tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The replication stress response is required to repair DNA lesions that arise due to both endogenous sources and environmental genotoxins found in water, food, and industrial chemicals. This proposal aims to discover how the replication-coupled protein HMCES protects cells from genomic instability and mutation (K99) and more broadly how DNA-strand specific obstacles contribute to mutagenesis (R00). Completing this proposal will characterize how cells prevent mutagenesis in a new context uncovering mechanisms in DNA repair.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative West Virginia bears many historical, physical, psychosocial, and fiscal burdens brought about by a multitude of issues – high levels of chronic diseases, the opioid crisis, environmental risk factors and economic trends. The West Virginia Pediatric Clinical Trials Network (WVPCTN) as a Clinical Site of the ECHO IDeA States PCTN (ISPCTN) has truly been a catalyst for addressing some of these burdens by fulfilling its two-fold mission in our IDeA state of West Virginia – bringing clinical trials to our underserved population and building professional capacity for clinical research. Together with strong and sustained partnerships throughout the state, and the multiple environmentally related conditions of our citizens, WVU continues to be uniquely positioned to be successful as an ISPCTN Clinical Site and add to a long-standing commitment to Pediatric focused initiatives across the state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes is a growing public health concern associated with increased risk of heart failure. However, there are limited strategies to identify which patients with type 2 diabetes may benefit from preventive therapies such as intensive blood pressure control. We propose to measure N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide and high-sensitivity cardiac troponin T from blood stored by the NHLBI Biorepository of participants enrolled in the ACCORD-BP trial to evaluate whether a biomarker-based approach can inform intensive blood pressure control treatment decisions among high-risk adults with type 2 diabetes to prevent heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensing and discrimination of foreign vs host nucleic acids is key for providing protection against pathogens while preventing autoimmunity. The nucleic acid sensors known as retinoic acid inducible gene I (RIG-I)-like receptors (RLRs) are critical to regulating pulmonary inflammation, protection from damage, and repair, but the roles for RLRs in discrete cell types and tissue microenvironments remains unknown. This R35 research program will utilize novel RLR (RIG-I and MDA5) genetic knockout murine lines to unravel the unique roles of the RLRs in regulating pulmonary homeostasis, pathology, and tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Given the enormous amount of data generated by research studies and in the clinic today, visualization is often a key element in gaining insight into the genomic basis and mechanisms of disease. These insights will help to develop hypotheses for further study, guide treatment, and point the way to new therapeutic targets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is the most common liver disease in the U.S. and progresses to liver fibrosis. Hepatic Stellate Cells (HSCs) that normally exhibit a quiescent phenotype (qHSCs) and store Vitamin A, activate into Collagen Type I-expressing aHSCs/myofibroblasts in response to metabolic liver injury to produce the fibrous scar. Phenotypic changes in HSCs occur without a change in the DNA sequence but are regulated on an epigenetic level (e.g. specific modifications in the chromatin structure), characterization of the gene expression and epigenetic changes specific for primary human HSCs isolated from normal, and NASH livers will identify new targets for antifibrotic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Methods to regenerate photoreceptors represents a major therapeutic goal for inherited retinal disease. Zebrafish have the capacity to regenerate lost neurons following acute injury but mutants with retinal degeneration do not regenerate. This proposal will address critical unanswered questions such as why zebrafish with chronic inflammation in diseased retinas fail to regenerate and to determine how inflammation regulates regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Projective Narrative Emotion-based impulsivity, which involves difficulties with emotion regulation and cognitive control, is a debilitating and understudied problem in bipolar spectrum disorders. This study will use advanced neurophysiological measurement and ecological momentary assessment to examine whether neural oscillations underlying response inhibition are associated with emotion regulation and impulsivity in daily life. The resulting data may help to identify novel treatment targets for emotion-based impulsivity in bipolar spectrum and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Family caregivers are essential to the nation’s well-being and economy yet little information exists regarding the daily lives of ADRD and non-ADRD caregivers across the diverse social partners who provide care. The present study develops and administers new survey instruments in the Understanding America Study (UAS) to identify caregivers and implements new daily assessments and wearable devices to capture caregivers’ daily experiences and their links with daily emotional and physiological well-being among ADRD and non-ADRD family and non-family caregivers ranging in age from young adulthood to old age. Understanding daily experiences and reactivity and the factors that predict greater resilience and vulnerability to stress in a national sample of caregivers will provide unprecedented information regarding potentially modifiable risk and protective factors for improving caregiver health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proposed study investigates how cerebral aneurysm treatment outcome can be predicted through computer simulations. Typical simulations do not account for clotting factors in the blood, which are important in determining which treatments succeed and which fail. We will incorporate these aspects into computer simulations and validate them with an animal model of cerebral aneurysms for cerebral aneurysm treatment outcome prediction. This project has an impact on public health by improving the prevention of hemorrhagic stroke from aneurysm rupture and improving treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue-resident macrophages (TRMs) are vital executives of tissue homeostasis and play important roles in tumors, yet the (metabolic) pathways important for their development, tissue- specific identity, and function are not well understood. Here, we put forward a framework to identify and characterize the metabolic programs overseeing these key aspects of TRM biology, including innovative approaches to explore macrophage metabolism within human tissues. Through these studies, we will obtain a deeper understanding of TRMs across health and disease, and ascertain novel metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited for immunomodulation of these essential cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project seeks to understand how the body senses and regulates iron-uptake. The uptake of iron into the body needs to be tightly controlled, because too little iron causes anemia and compromised brain development. Complications of too much iron include liver cirrhosis, liver cancer, heart arrythmias, and arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) experience acute pain events, or vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) which may progress to chronic pain. Our lack of understanding of the mechanisms and risk factors for progression to chronic pain, and lack of diagnostic biomarkers to identify VOC impairs our ability to appropriately treat VOC, and often results in potentiating and worsening chronic pain through excessive, inappropriate and ineffective exposure to opioids. Our innovative transcriptomics analysis of samples collected from relevant cell types from individuals with SCD with and without chronic pain, and paired genomics data, will address this unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to Public Health: This research project is focused on an enzyme, SERCA, that transports calcium in all cells of the body. This pump is particularly important in the heart, where it controls the strength of the heart muscle contraction. Human heart failure is associated with disordered cardiac calcium handling, so SERCA is considered to be an important therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trypanosoma brucei causes serious illnesses in humans and livestock that cause enormous suffering in Sub-Saharan Africa. We will study how the parasite establishes its shape, which is mediated by a specialized set of microtubules that underlie the cell surface. Our work will further the fundamental understanding of how T. brucei and other trypanosomatid parasites maintain and transmit the morphologies that are essential for their infectivity, which could open a new avenue towards therapeutics for treating a wide range of neglected tropical diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Sickle Pan-African Research Consortium Clinical Coordinating Centre (SPARCO Center) together with six Consortium sites and the Sickle Africa Data Coordinating Centre will form the SCD in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) Network (SickleInAfrica). The specific aims of SPARCO Center will be to i) provide governance, oversight and operations, ii) expand the sickle cell registry and database to a total of 34,000 participants, iii) integrate SCD standards of Care into healthcare, iv) coordinate cohort and implementation research studies v) facilitate participation in short, medium and long-term skills development programs, and vi) facilitate engagement with public and private partners across the globe. The overall goal for SPARCO Center is to develop sustainable continent-wide SCD resources for multidisciplinary research that will increase understanding of SCD and improve health outcomes in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Depression and poverty are linked together in an intractable syndemic affectig millions of people around the world. Poverty is a major cause of depression, while depression significantly reduces economic productivity. Integrated intervention approaches that seek to interrupt the cycle of poverty and depression have not been tested. This application describes ASHA: an integrated intervention that combines depression treatment with economic strengthening for depressed, low income women in rural Bangladesh. If the research is successful, we will work with government and NGO partners to initiate new collaborations between mental health researcher’s/policy makers and development groups seeking to increase economic productivity and wellbeing in Bangladesh and other countries of the global south.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anthracycline anticancer agents are essential, lifesaving chemotherapies used in a majority of pediatric cancer patients but they confer a substantial long-term risk of heart failure, which is an important public health concern. This proposal seeks to define anthracycline-related cardiac remodeling, an important precursor to heart failure, through the development of new imaging-based markers and an examination of its relationship with modifiable risk factors and subsequent cardiac dysfunction. The goal of this research is to improve early detection and clinical prognostication, and to inform the future design of a targeted intervention to prevent heart failure in survivors of childhood cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research project will develop new statistical methods for analysis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) studies that feature truncated or interval-censored covariates. Our methods will address analytic shortcomings that may have contributed to the conflicting findings regarding the potential efficacy of statins and the potential risk of proton pump inhibitors with respect to AD. The proposed statistical methodology that will eliminate the bias that may arise with truncated and interval-censored covariates, which are inherent to longitudinal cohort studies in AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Current tuberculosis (TB) tests have reduced sensitivity when applied to diagnose young children who may develop more rapid and severe disease due to their immature immune systems, and this can delay or prevent the initiation of appropriate anti-TB treatment and result in more severe disease or death. Our initial proposal developed a blood-based biomarker assay that read by a mass spectrometer that sensitively detects proteins release by M, tuberculosis (Mtb) to diagnosis TB even in diagnostically challenging pediatric populations, and we now intend to expand upon this experience to develop a streamlined assay that is read by an inexpensive portable device that can be used in resource-limited settings where TB is often prevalent. This assay will detect proteins on extracellular vesicle (EV) secreted by Mtb-infected phagocytes and by immune cells to evaluate Mtb burden and its containment by the immune system, and thus provide critical information about pathogen-host interactions required improve pediatric TB diagnosis and to allow rapid assessment of the effectiveness of TB treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This application will advance a novel therapy, whereby white blood cells are trained in the laboratory to recognize and kill cancer cells. These killer cells have the capacity to recognize multiple surface markers expressed by the tumor cells but not healthy cells. To date, more than 170 patients have been treated in clinical studies with this therapy with no serious side effects. This project will advance cell therapy in combination with existing chemotherapy to treat patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a type of blood cancer with minimal treatment options and low survival rates, with the ultimate objective of getting marketing authorization to benefit more patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative In mice, innate Type 3 cytokine producing lymphocytes (iT3L) expressing γδTCR (Tγδ17) are found preferentially in mucosal tissues of neonates and prevent eczema-like disease in the skin by fortifying the barrier. Lung Tγδ17 cells have similar function during neonatal flu infection. This proposal will determine whether the relative resistance to COVID-19 in infants is linked to heightened activities of neonatal Tγδ17 cells, and if so, how they can be mobilized in adults to confer improved resistance to SARS-CoV-2 infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 1 in 60 children have autism. The high rate of poor oral health in teens with autism and the considerable lifetime costs of preventable oral diseases underscore the importance of behavioral intervention research aimed at improving toothbrushing skills and habits. The proposed work is a critical first step in helping teens with autism develop long-term toothbrushing habits to prevent tooth decay, improve quality of life, and reduce well-documented disparities in oral health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed R25 summer program will provide ten deserving students per year the opportunity to experience multi-disciplinary, hands-on research in nationally recognized labs studying NHLBI mission- related projects. Their research experiences will also be complemented by career development activities that encourage a life-long commitment to scientific research in the next generation of health professional investigators. This R25 program will instill in our students a better appreciation of the important role for health professionals to have academic careers by motivating them to continue integrating research in their post-graduate clinical training in their chosen disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Discogenic back pain, is a leading cause of disability, and involves degenerative changes of the intervertebral disc. Only a small subset of patients responds favorably to existing treatments, and there is a need for alternative options, including regenerative therapies. We are developing and optimizing use of anti-inflammatory cells for disc repair in hope that it improves outcomes for patients with back pain and degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent discoveries of the phase-separation abilities of several chromatin regulators have led to novel models for chromatin organization. This project aims to develop biochemical, genetic and computational tools that enables studying the functional role of chromatin regulator phase-separation in individual living cells. We will apply these tools to the study of the regulation and impact of heterochromatin formation and transcription activation during stem cell differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aligned with NIH’s strategic priority to support innovations in HIV prevention, testing, adherence and retention to optimize HIV care continuum outcomes, the overall goal of the proposed study is to examine the impact and cost-effectiveness of an innovative multilevel intervention on HIV treatment adherence and engagement in care outcomes among school-going adolescents living with HIV (ALHIV) in Uganda. This R01 will combine group-based HIV stigma reduction for educators and Multiple Family Groups for HIV stigma reduction with a family economic empowerment intervention to address stigma and economic barriers associated with treatment outcomes and engagement in care. Findings may inform combination intervention efforts to optimize HIV treatment outcomes among ALHIV in Uganda and other countries in SSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder (SUD) is a debilitating condition that is associated with poor decision making and elevated risk taking. Despite significant progress in identifying the behavioral and neurobiological mechanisms underlying this causal relationship, our understanding is still limited as the majority of the work has used male subjects. The objective of this proposal, which is the first step toward rectifying this limitation, is to investigate the neurobiological mechanisms by which estradiol promotes risk aversion in females; this knowledge will provide critical insight into how such mechanisms may be compromised after chronic substance use in females, resulting in elevated risk taking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Inflammation due to infection and tissue damage causes anemia because inflammation inhibits the production new red blood cells by the bone marrow. To compensate for this loss of red blood cell production, the body induces a stress response to rapidly make new red blood cells. This proposal will examine the mechanisms by which this stress pathway makes new red blood cells with the hope that these studies will identify new therapies for anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Taking advantage of Hawaii’s unique multiethnic population with cancer health disparities and a unique physical environment for drug discovery, this training program will mentor undergraduate and graduate students living in Hawaii and in the Pacific by providing them with distinctive training experiences both in cancer biology and in population sciences. This hands-on cancer research experience will enable trainees to pursue successful careers in cancer prevention and control that will help to lower cancer incidence and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to psychosocial stressors is associated with negative health outcomes, including excessive activity of the sympathetic nervous system that may lead to cardiovascular problems. This proposal investigates arginine- vasopressin modulation of the ventral midbrain and responses to psychosocial stressors that are risk factors for developing cardiovascular disease. The proposed study is relevant to public health because it explores the therapeutic potential of arginine-vasopressin, acting via the V1A receptor, in treating psychosocial stress- associated cardiovascular conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. Deaf community – a group of more than 500,000 Americans who communicate using American Sign Language (ASL) – experiences nearly triple the rate of lifetime problem drinking and twice the rate of trauma exposure compared to the general population. Although there are several treatments for alcohol use disorder (AUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in hearing populations, none have been developed for or tested with Deaf clients. To address these barriers, our team developed Signs of Safety, a Deaf-accessible therapy toolkit for treating AUD and PTSD. We propose a nationwide, virtual clinical trial to compare (1) Signs of Safety with (2) treatment as usual and (3) a no treatment control, to collect data on clinical outcomes, and to explore potential mediators and moderators of outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The proposed research is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission of developing fundamental knowledge and therapeutics that will help reduce the enormous burdens of morbidity and mortality associated with human disease. The goal of this project is to develop new classes of engineered antibodies that can be precisely controlled to regulate cellular physiology. These smart antibodies can be used not only as broadly-applicable biomedical research tools, but also as potential precision therapeutics to intervene in human diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-saving treatments for cancer have significantly improved survival rates in recent decades, particularly among those affected in childhood, however, many of these therapies have a deleterious impact on the gonad and are a major cause of infertility and early menopause in female cancer survivors. For pre-pubescent girls that are incapable of responding to ovarian stimulation, cryopreservation of ovarian tissue has emerged as an effective means of safeguarding reproductive options, but auto-transplantation of tissue back into patients following remission is highly inefficient and results in poor oocyte yields. Using a combination of patient-derived vascular endothelial cells and robust local delivery of an ovary-specific factor, anti-Müllerian hormone, via modified mRNA, this proposal aims to both improve the viability and output of thawed ovarian tissue following auto-transplantation and/or protect the ovary in situ from the gonadotoxic influence of cancer chemotherapy.
