IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide rates among U.S. Hispanics have increased by approximately 20% since 2000 and the Hispanic population is expected to double in the coming decades, indicating that suicide among Hispanics is an issue of pressing public health concern. However, empirical data indicating how to prevent suicide among this population, especially for Spanish-speaking adults in the U.S., are notably lacking. This proposal forms the basis of a program of research focused on suicide prevention for geographically and linguistically isolated Hispanics, with a particular emphasis on the role of cultural-social engagement in the prevention of suicide among this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Advances in non-invasive monitoring of human brain function under normal and pathological conditions will lead to breakthroughs in our understanding of the brain in health and disease, and lead to the development of devices available for everyday use, with applications such as monitoring patients with brain injuries or neurodegenerative disease, studies of brain function in natural environments, and brain-computer interfaces. We propose to develop a fiber-based speckle contrast optical spectroscopy (SCOS) system to measure CBF variations due to brain activation in humans with a contrast to noise ratio (CNR) by at least one order of magnitude compared with existing systems, that will also measure all the hemodynamic parameters associated with brain activation, achieve an up to 3x improvement in brain sensitivity compared with traditional optical brain imaging devices, and permit estimation of evoked changes in CMRO2. This will provide a unique neuroimaging approach to measure all cerebral hemodynamic and optical metabolism parameters related to brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some children who are born very early develop severe, long-term lung problems that make them need a breathing machine to live at home and there are no studies that explain why some children need to use a breathing machine longer than others. This research will provide new understanding about why a given child may, in the context of their family and the care they receive, use a breathing machine longer, have to go the emergency room more often, and be hospitalized more often than another child. This research will also test whether providing more complete information to a child’s team of doctors, nurses, and respiratory therapists about the factors that affect how long children use breathing machines at home, can safely decrease the time a child uses a breathing machine while also avoiding hospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: White blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil counts are used in many domains of medicine including as parameters to help dose medications and for criteria in diagnosing and prognosticating in infection. WBC and neutrophil counts are lower among African Americans and other persons of African and/or Middle Eastern ancestry compared to persons of European or East Asian ancestry, and the genotype underlying this observation is well known. We propose to use large datasets with matched genotype and clinical outcomes to determine how to interpret WBC and neutrophil counts for the purpose of dosing medications that affect these counts including chemotherapy and for the purpose of accurately diagnosing severe infections.

PHR: Project Narrative The Northwest Portland Area Indian Health Board (NPAIHB) has a long-standing health research relationship with Oregon Health & Science University and Portland State University. With its two academic partners, the NPAIHB will implement three training programs for American Indian and Alaska Native researchers designed to help reduce disparities for tribal people nationwide, including a graduate fellowship program in cancer prevention research, a fellowship in applied biostatistics, and our Summer Research Training Institute for AI/AN health professionals…a program that has included over 1000 trainees so far. In addition to the training grants, we will evaluate the feasibility of an elders’ fall intervention program that makes use of technology only available in Portland for balance testing and monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Organelle contact, including the interactions between mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum (ER), plays an important role in cell and animal health, and defects in this process are associated with human disorders. We are studying the relationship between the lipid transport protein VPS13D, mitochondria and ER contact, autophagy, cell stress, and inflammation in models of a progressive neurodegenerative disease. The association of defects in organelle contact, autophagy, cell stress, and inflammation with age-associated disorders illustrates the importance of investigating the relationship between these processes and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The process of ribosome-associated quality control (QC) is critical for cellular fitness in bacteria: its loss often results in decreased pathogenicity, viability, or antibiotic resistance. This project aims to characterize the mechanism of a novel ribosome-associated QC factor HrpA, which has been shown to mitigate the effects of ribosome-targeting antibiotics on bacterial growth. Findings from the proposed experiments can be used for future development of HrpA-targeting antimicrobials for treating human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiculopathy is a common spinal condition resulting from compression and irritation of the spinal nerve roots, leading to sensory deficits, muscle weakness, and pain. Clinicians use dermatomal sensory testing to localize the level(s) of nerve root injury in radiculopathy; however, dermatomal maps are limited and remain to be quantitatively validated. Here we will use spinal cord functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to test hypotheses central to dermatomal maps, advance our knowledge of spinal cord sensory processing in healthy and injured states, and provide preliminary validation of diagnostic markers for radiculopathy while improving our spinal cord fMRI methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF), the most common abnormal heart rhythm worldwide, is associated with increased risk for stroke, heart failure and death. Treatments for AF are sub-optimal because of poor understanding of the underlying mechanisms; here we propose to determine if the variable response to antiarrhythmic drugs for AF is due to genetics. Our studies will not only improve the prediction of response to drugs but will also improve our understanding of the underlying mechanisms and help in the development of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A promising approach to halt, and even reverse, the progression of acute kidney injury is to administer mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) based therapies [i.e. parent MSCs (a cellular therapy) or MSC-derived extracellular vesicles (a cell free therapy)] directly into the kidney, via its arterial blood supply. In the present study, we will examine how these therapies can regenerate the kidney when locally administered, specifically focusing on how they modulate the heat shock protein pathway. In addition, we will examine how using pulsed sound waves can facilitate kidney regeneration, either by causing changes in the local microenvironment or by stimulating intrinsic regenerative pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Extreme heat may threaten the effectiveness of interventions for child physical activity including the national program Safe Routes to School. Using modeled estimates of heat stress and children's geolocated physical activity on school routes, the proposed research will determine the relations between built environment changes from Safe Routes to School, children's exposure to ambient temperature, and their active school commuting behavior. Research findings can provide evidence for whether urban heat management strategies are needed to be incorporated as environmental interventions within Safe Routes to School and other programs designed to promote physical activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Inherited retinal degenerations and age-related macular degeneration affect more than two million people in the United States. For 90% of the people afflicted with these diseases, no treatments have been developed. This project will test a drug with strong therapeutic potential, and it will define a specific pathway involving AMPK and PGC-1 that can be activated to protect retinal neurons and RPE from inherited mutations and age-related degeneration. This in vivo study is designed to directly determine the role of mitochondrial gene expression and function as a contributing factor to inherited retinal degeneration and age-dependent macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We classically understand changes in the biology of cells and tissues as determined by how cells relay information from outside to their nucleus, in order to turn genes off and on. While this framework has helped explain the majority of biological research to date, it largely overlooks the fact that cell biology also requires the movement of a vast number of metabolites throughout the compartments inside a cell and between cells in a tissue. This proposal seeks to investigate how the movement of metabolic information within a cell and amongst populations of interacting cells controls how genes are turned off and on and how cells behave collectively inside an animal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite intensive therapy, patients with high-risk neuroblastoma frequently suffer from relapses that prove fatal. To prevent and treat relapse, we need a better understanding of how to target the populations of cancer cells that survive our current therapies. This proposal aims to target drug-resistant cancer cells by exploiting differences in how they sense inflammatory stimuli in order to enhance their susceptibility to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemokines are soluble proteins that direct migrating immune cells to sites of injury or infection. Aberrant chemokine function contributes to cancer, chronic inflammation and autoimmune disease. CCL20 levels are elevated the joints of psoriatic arthritis patients. XLock Biosciences is developing a lead molecule (CCL20LD) that blocks this chemokine and reduced joint and tendon inflammation in a preclinical study. This Phase II SBIR project will perform the R/R&D necessary for an IND application leading to first-in-human trials of CCL20LD as a psoriatic arthritis therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human and animal organ size and shape are precisely controlled by a patterning process during embryonic development and individual growth. Our current knowledge about this patterning process is still limited. The outcome of this project will demonstrate a previously less recognized patterning mechanism by ion channel- mediated bioelectricity, and this knowledge could be used for developing preventive and therapeutic interventions of human congenital diseases in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative New treatment strategies to end the HIV epidemic are urgently needed and currently being studied, including the administration of broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV. Mutations in the virus, however, can cause resistance to these antibodies. We propose to study mutations in HIV in depth that cause resistance against antibodies in a large number of samples from resource-limited areas, for a better understanding of the role these mutations play for antibody therapy in these settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Long distance signaling and trafficking of proteins in neuronal axons is important for neurodevelopment and for responses to nerve injury, while impaired axonal trafficking is a hallmark of many neurodegenerative disorders. This work focuses on how a protein-lipid modification called palmitoylation controls the long distance transport and activity of axonal signaling enzymes that control the balance between axonal maintenance and degeneration. The proposed research will provide new insights into axonal biology and has the potential to enhance understanding of neurodegenerative conditions in which axonal trafficking and signaling is impaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  On the surfaces of human cells, sensory proteins are activated by not only by molecules outside the cell but also by lipids of the membrane environment in which they function. We seek to understand how the cellular membrane environment affects the activities of these sensory proteins, including affecting their abilities to bind drugs and transmit information inside the cell that ultimately causes physiological responses. The results of this work provide fundamental information into how receptor- lipid interactions in the membrane can be leveraged to design novel inhibitory or activating drug molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE An alarming rise in the injection of opioids is fueling the HIV epidemic in India, with young people who inject drugs (YPWID)—i.e., individuals 18-29 years of age—bearing a disproportionate burden of new HIV infections. We propose to develop Yuva Sath, a novel peer-led behavioral intervention for YPWID—tailored to their unique developmental vulnerabilities—that will support their engagement in substance use treatment and HIV prevention services by addressing the diverse barriers they experience. This research will lead to one of the first youth tailored interventions for HIV prevention among YPWID in India and contribute to urgent efforts to address the high HIV incidence in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Latent tuberculosis infection affects 1.7 billion people globally, and is a common coinfection in persons living with HIV. In this project, we will define the role of latent tuberculosis infection as a contributor of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk and immune activation in persons living with HIV. We will therefore examine a prevalent, preventable, and treatable coinfection in persons with HIV to inform the design of future interventions to decrease the risk of cardiovascular disease in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aggressive tumors acquire the ability to scavenge and eat nutrients from their environment, which allows them to face starvation and survive even the harshest chemotherapy treatments. To fight those cancers, many scientists are currently working out ways of blocking the ability of cancer cells to scavenge food; however, what if, instead of preventing cancer cells from eating, we simply locked the fridge? Our laboratory at MIT has recently discovered a molecular machine that acts as a gate for the release of food from the fridge, and our goal is to develop drugs that can stop this machine from working, which will effectively starve aggressive tumors, whilst sparing all other normal cells that do not rely on food scavenging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE With the new availability of several treatment options for AML patients harboring IDH1 or IDH2 mutations, it is not known yet how to predict which therapy will lead to the best treatment response for individual patients. We will perform the first head-to head comparison trial of the sequence of therapy with IDH-directed versus non- IDH-directed small molecule inhibitors for newly diagnosed, older IDH-mutated AML patients, complemented by the analysis of the largest to-date cohort of IDH-mutated AML patients to delineate clinical and molecular predictors of treatment response to different frontline therapies, including cytotoxic chemotherapy and small molecule inhibitors, which will be complemented by the integrated analysis of our large longitudinal patient collection. We hypothesize that these data analyses will characterize therapy-associated molecular treatment response patterns, with the overarching goal to provide data-driven support for for molecular-based treatment choices that improve outcomes of IDH-mutated AML patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peer victimization is a common and potent predictor of psychopathology in adolescence, but the behavioral and neural mechanisms underlying this association remain unknown. I will test a novel conceptual model assessing how dimensions of peer victimization—peer threat and peer deprivation—differentially shape neurocognitive processes and social behaviors that confer risk for internalizing psychopathology. Identifying developmental processes that are disrupted following peer victimization and ultimately lead to psychopathology is a necessary first step in developing targeted intervention approaches to mitigate the effects of peer victimization on youths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal for a Biomarker Characterization Center seeks to improve upon the management of lung cancer and other malignancies through detection of tumor specific abnormal DNA methylation in plasma. The Biomarker Development Lab will discover new loci with a high prevalence of cancer specific methylation in lung cancer and others, and develop new and more sensitive methods of detection. These approaches will be transferred to the Biomarker Reference Lab for testing in a clinical setting, and operations of these two components and their communication facilitated by the Administrative Core.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is designed to achieve two major objectives: 1) determine the frequency of different types of heart attacks (type 1-5) in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) over 14 years of follow-up, and 2) identify risk factors specific for the different types of heart attacks. Understanding the specific risk factors that cause the different types of heart attacks will enable scientists to identify who is at risk of which specific type of heart attack, and develop treatments specific to these different types of heart attacks (i.e., precision medicine). This will allow physicians to tailor treatments to individual patients' risk that will maximize benefit, minimize risks and more efficiently utilizing healthcare resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There have been no new FDA-approved drugs for Alzheimer’s disease in more than 20 years. The goal of this project is to develop artificial intelligence (AI) approaches for extracting unforeseen patterns from clinical, genetic, genomic, and imaging data that could lead to ideas for new drug development. Our proposed AI methods and software will be open-source, user-friendly, and freely available for all to use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Finding previously uncharacterized effects of common drugs on cancer or Alzheimer's disease has the potential to immediately impact clinical care. These discoveries can both prevent some cases of disease, and point to new treatments. Instead of requiring thousands of experiments, we will find these effects systematically and efficiently by creating new methods for analysis of existing data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity has become a major public health concern as it increases the risk for type 2 diabetes, heart attack, certain forms of cancer, hypertension and stroke. Obesity results from the interaction between the environment and genetic predisposition. This research proposal is aimed at understanding better how mutations in the Melanocortin-4 receptor, a brain expressed gene that controls food intake in response to peripheral cues, cause severe obesity in humans. This research could lead to a better understanding on how people become obese and could lead to new treatments for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TDP-43 aggregation is a hallmark of several neurodegenerative diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), an Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementia (ADRD). I aim to understand how interactions of TDP-43 with RNA contribute to disease etiology and how RNA can rescue TDP-43 aggregation and disease phenotypes. Successful completion of my proposal will result in the development of a therapeutic that can be advanced for treatment of patients with ALS and FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Manmade nanocages to mimic protein cavities can be useful for medical research, as they can recognize important biological targets for sensing and catalyze reactions to synthesize therapeutics. This work proposes to create some of the first fully sequenced-defined nanocages with protein-mimetic, robust cavities, thus providing new solutions in fields of sensing and catalysis. Ultimately, this work will lead to selective, rapid sensing devices for neuropeptides to help elucidate the etiology of a variety of brain disorders, as well as to new artificial enzymes useful to synthesize otherwise difficult to access therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a science-to-practice gap in sickle cell disease (SCD) between evidence-based guidelines and the care that is delivered. Issues are worsened for individuals living in rural regions or with socio-economic challenges known to accentuate health disparities. The current project, Recruitment and Engagement in Care to Impact Practice Enhancement (RECIPE) will advance efforts to identify and link unaffiliated patients to SCD specialists by applying implementation science research to adapt existing methods used in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: In this application, we propose a Core Center for Clinical Research (CCCR) at Northwestern University to promote cutting-edge clinical research aimed at prevention or control of rheumatic and musculoskeletal conditions and poor outcomes associated with them. While we will provide broad support, we will particularly seek to drive this theme: prevention strategy and intervention development through lifestyle, behavioral, medical, and rehabilitative solutions, built on a foundation of person-centered assessment in daily life and community engagement. Because our CCCR is centered on the goal to improve how persons feel and function in their daily lives, focuses on community and personal experience, and builds upon the wearable and portable technology revolution, we are positioned to have substantial impact on work within and beyond our institution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances in models for studying human gastrulation present the opportunity to answer questions in the field of early human embryology that have been unanswered for decades. This proposal will thoroughly investigate the role of the intracellular signaling pathway MAPK/Erk signaling dynamics in human gastrulation through a combination of micron-scale stem cell engineering technologies and optogenetic tools, that enable the systematic variation of signaling patterns. This work will increase understanding of signaling mechanisms that drive pattern formation in the human gastruloid and investigate how RASopathies effect human gastrulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: Approximately 3.5 million adolescents suffer from high impact chronic musculoskeletal (MSK) pain. Current treatments for chronic MSK pain are suboptimal with a recovery rate of ~50%. Discovery and validation of a prognostic and robust signature for pain recovery vs. persistence will facilitate risk stratification, a more resourceful selection of patients who are likely to respond for undergoing current multidisciplinary pain treatment approaches, and new insight into biological and behavioral processes that may be exploited to develop novel strategies profiting those who are refractory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Technology-based interventions hold promise to extend the availability of support for individuals managing mental health concerns, but their success requires keeping users engaged over time. This K01 proposal leverages machine learning to establish a messaging intervention that can automatically adapt communication styles to accommodate users’ individualized support needs and preferences and their fluctuations over time. If successful, this project will lead to a scalable intervention model that delivers engaging, personalized support while imposing low burden on users and the health system, and that could be broadly applied to address a wide variety of mental health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the current project is to combine two evidence-based treatments for school-aged children with ADHD: Central Executive Training (CET) and Behavioral Parent Training (BPT). CET is a computerized training intervention that improves ADHD symptoms and academic functioning by improving children’s working memory abilities. BPT is a therapeutic intervention that improves family functioning and child ODD symptoms by changing parenting behaviors. Their combined use is expected to provide complementary and additive benefits, particularly if CET is delivered before BPT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RELEVANCE: Multiple myeloma (MM) is a common, incurable hematologic malignancy whose management is extremely costly, with long-established disparities disproportionally inflicting African American populations. However, MM lacks comparative modeling, like the six cancer sites within the CISNET, to guide its prevention and control policies. The proposed MM Incubator Program will develop such modeling to assess the value of guideline recommended therapies and novel intervention strategies for MM prevention and control across MM care continuum with the goals of reducing MM burden and disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will study elderly people living with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) longitudinally over 3 years for cardiovascular health. Cardiometabolic diseases disproportionately develop in people living with HIV, and we are looking for new treatments to mitigate cardiometabolic disease and tools to predict the development of adverse cardiovascular health outcomes in blood samples. We will study participants’ blood cells immunometabolic changes longitudinally, proteins that make energy, and acquire longitudinal cardiovascular and whole body vascular imaging to advance our understanding of cardiovascular health in the HIV field.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Osteoporosis is the most common bone disorder in the world, affecting more than 10 million individuals in the US; however, treatment of osteoporosis, particularly among children remains ineffective. This project will determine the role of Plastin-3 in osteoblast differentiation and mineralization as it relates to the development of childhood-onset osteoporosis. This project will also establish a novel model system for the study of childhood- onset osteoporosis that will facilitate the identification of novel pathways and targets related to Plastin-3 and can be used in the development of alternative therapeutic strategies for osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytoplasmic La-related proteins (LARPs) are involved in post-transcriptional gene control by regulating the delicate balance between active translation, degradation, and storage of mRNAs. We seek to understand the intricacies of their “non-canonical” RNA recognition at a molecular level to illuminate how structural commonality and individuality contribute to their unique functionality. The results of this work will provide fundamental information on how various LARPs adopted to specific RNA targets as well as provide the molecular level framework for the design of novel therapeutic approaches targeting associated fibroproliferative diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the Affordable Care Act-mandated Hospital Readmission Reduction Program launched in 2012 has modestly reduced readmissions, an unintended consequence has been the shift of a significant fraction of heart failure (HF)-related care to the outpatient setting. However, little is known about the epidemiology, clinical profile, treatment patterns, and/or outcomes of outpatient worsening HF (WHF). To address these critical knowledge gaps, we propose (1) to systematically describe the contemporary epidemiology, clinical characteristics, treatment patterns, and outcomes associated with outpatient WHF and (2) to evaluate the impact of an episode of outpatient WHF on generic and disease-specific HRQOL in the context of a fully integrated health care delivery system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This grant focuses on the neuronal mechanisms that underlie decision-making processes that are based on knowledge of the external world. Many symptoms and underlying causes of neuropsychiatric disorders can be characterized as dysfunctions of these processes. Understanding the neuronal mechanisms that underlie these higher order decision making systems is a necessary step towards developing future diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions for these neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Pancreatic cancer is a leading cause of cancer mortality with few effective therapies. This project will develop a novel immunotherapy that we show has pronounced therapeutic activity in preclinical animal models. We will uncover the mechanistic basis for the observed antitumor effects and create a novel immune therapy designed to change the standard of care for pancreatic cancer patient treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although half of patients with soft tissue sarcoma develop distant metastases after radiation therapy and surgery, there are currently no biomarkers to identify patients who would benefit from adjuvant systemic therapy and no known genetic alterations that mediate soft tissue sarcoma response to radiation therapy. We propose to use circulating tumor DNA analysis to identify patients at high risk of relapse who could benefit from additional therapy and discover genetic alterations that mediate radiation response. This work will lay the foundation for future clinical trials incorporating circulating tumor DNA analysis and tumor genomics to personalize treatment approaches and improve outcomes in patients with soft tissue sarcomas and other malignancies treated with radiation therapy.

PHR: The Northwest Portland Area Indian Health Board (NPAIHB) has a long-standing health research relationship with Oregon Health & Science University and Portland State University. With its two academic partners, the NPAIHB will implement two training programs for American Indian and Alaska Native researchers, including a graduate and undergraduate fellowship program with a strong population health sciences focus. Similarly, our high school enrichment program for tribal students will use a population health sciences lens to engage the tribal students in the sciences – our efforts are designed to help reduce disparities for tribal people regionally and nationwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Hirschsprung disease (HSCR), or congenital aganglionosis, results from defects in enteric neural crest cell precursor (ENCC) development to enteric neurons in a sex-biased manner. We propose studies to improve HSCR risk prediction from patient genome sequence, advance the mechanistic understanding of HSCR at the genetic and cellular levels, and identify the rate-limiting genetic steps suitable for therapeutics. Our goals are to provide a genetic paradigm for uncovering the pathophysiology of a sex-biased complex multifactorial disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Individuals with an underlying HIV-infection have an increased risk of developing AIDS-related malignancies. Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is the necessary causal agent for Kaposi's sarcoma and is a cofactor in B cell lymphoproliferative disorders observed in AIDS patients. Understanding how KSHV is transmitted amongst the population is a necessary first step in creating a vaccine to prevent the spread of KSHV worldwide. The results from the proposed studies utilizing the nonhuman primate model should help elucidate and define the mechanisms involved in KSHV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite that majority of microbes found in nature exist and function in spatially organized communities, our current basic understanding of microbes is heavily based on the studies performed in liquid cultures. Therefore, the next frontier is to understand the group behavior and physiology of microbes with a pre-defined spatial context and engineer synthetic consortia in a well-defined 3D framework for desired functional outcomes. The proposed research is relevant to public health because expanding our fundamental understanding of naturally- occurring communities of microbes will enable us to better control/treat clinically relevant biofilms and engineer biomaterials useful for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  A therapeutic strategy to induce neovascularization of tissues and biomaterials would represent a major breakthrough in the treatment of ischemic tissue disorders, dysfunctional wound healing, and the replacement of damaged tissues. The proposed studies are designed to improve our understanding of how the body naturally orchestrates successful blood vessel growth, and then to apply these principles to the design of novel biomaterials that harness these processes to promote vascularization.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) HIV prevention tools are promising, with tenofovir (TFV)-based daily oral PrEP and the dapivirine vaginal ring (DPV-VR) recommended by WHO for cisgender women at-risk for HIV. Retail pharmacies can increase options for reaching at-risk individuals with PrEP and efforts are underway to define pathways for pharmacy-delivered PrEP in Kenya. Through close collaboration with the Kenya Ministry of Health, we will expand on our successful pilot to offer both daily oral PrEP and the DPV-VR and prospectively ascertain PrEP outcomes (initiation, persistence, adherence) among adolescent girls and young women in a cluster RCT at 20 pharmacies in Kisumu, Kenya–a region with an HIV prevalence of up to 28% among women–in a effectiveness-implementation hybrid study designed to expedite translation into practice by evaluating clinical effectiveness alongside implementation and cost outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal focuses on the development of computational methods for identifying aberrations in gene expression. In particular, we propose to develop methods for identifying allele-specific expression, for identifying mutations that directly impact gene expression in reporter assays, and for identifying which parts of the genome regulate which genes. We expect this work to result in more effective identification of causal variants and a higher diagnosis rate for currently undiagnosed patients of a wide variety of diseases, as well as potential leads toward the design of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ionotropic glutamate receptors (iGluRs) are key molecules that play fundamental roles in neuronal excitability/functions and memory formation in the mammalian brain. In order to better understand the molecular mechanism of the entire iGluR superfamily and how protein co-factors regulate iGluR receptor activities, we will, herein, investigate the structure and function of native kainate receptor-type iGluRs from mammalian brains. We are particularly interested in how kainate-type ionotropic glutamate receptor (KAR) ligands, brain lipids, and protein co-factors modulate the functions of the receptor. This proposed research will provide novel insights, which will be helpful for the future development of treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma is a devastating pediatric brain tumor that despite decades of clinical trials remains fatal with a median survival of less than a year. This proposal focuses on the development of safe and effective immune-based therapies for these tumors, using chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapy. Through these studies we hope to improve our understanding of the tumor growth within the immune microenvironment and translate effective immunotherapies to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adipose tissue macrophages, a specialized population of immune cells that reside in fat tissue, are known to play a significant role in the pathophysiology of obesity, a common condition that is associated with insulin resistance and inflammation, as well as significant disease burden. A recent study established that adipocyte- derived exosomes modulate adipose tissue macrophages. This project aims to further our understanding of the effects of adipocyte-derived exosomes on macrophage recruitment and differentiation, as well as determine whether this regulation is dependent upon canonical pathways involved in adipose tissue macrophage recruitment and differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune system thrives on balance between overexuberant and insufficient immune responses. Maintaining this balance are a subpopulation of T lymphocytes termed regulatory T cells, which are essential guardians against autoimmune disease but culprits in pathologies of insufficient immunity like cancer. Regulatory T cells live within tissues and have adapted a metabolic profile to thrive therein, and despite substantial inflammation can maintain their identity. In this proposal, we will study how the metabolites present in tissues like cancer or in inflamed intestine interact with regulatory T cells and promote their function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant is aimed at enhancing our ability to study and assess liver cancer treatment using locoregional therapy in combination with systemic immune therapy. At the core of this effort is the unmet need for advanced imag- ing which can track the combined locoregional and immune therapies, and to that end we will develop, evaluate and translate advanced imaging, machine learning and image analysis methods to predict and assess clinical outcome with non-invasive imaging biomarkers based on characterization of liver tumor microenvironment. The resulting predictions and assessments will lead to improved patient care through more informed treatment strati- ﬁcation and clinical decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking is both common among adult patients with cancer and undertreated, despite strong evidence that quitting smoking markedly improves the health of cancer patients and survivors. Too few patients with cancer who smoke are offered and provided effective smoking treatment by their cancer care teams. The proposed research will identify and disseminate effective and feasible smoking treatment programs for cancer centers to increase the rates at which cancer patients who smoke quit smoking and improve their cancer recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Urinary tract infection (UTI), one of the most prevalent bacterial infections, is caused primarily by uropathogenic Escherichia coli (UPEC) and it is recalcitrant to treatment due to the ability of UPEC to form biofilms on catheters and host cells. The work proposed in the attached application expands on our recent findings demonstrating that UPEC uses the high-affinity quinol oxidase cytochrome bd to respire aerobically during infection and that deletion of cytochrome bd alters UPEC biofilm susceptibility to antibiotic treatment. In collaboration with Vanderbilt’s institute for chemical biology, we propose the use of synthesized cytochrome bd-specific inhibitors to evaluate the potential of preventing the establishment of UPEC biofilms on catheter material (aim 1) or, altering the architecture of pre-formed biofilms to increase the efficacy of antibiotics (aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: After massive intestinal resection, there are alterations in the gut barrier function, enhanced expression of genes involved with lipid signaling in the intestine, as well as severe liver injury and fibrosis. The overall goals of this project are to understand the contribution of intestinal lipid signaling to the genesis of advanced liver injury. This information is critical for the development of new therapies to save lives of children who have required massive intestinal resection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our study is uniquely designed to unravel some of the complexities of sex-specific dementia risk by conducting the most rigorous examination to date of the associations between women’s histories of pregnancy and breastfeeding with the etiological processes that contribute to Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Understanding the relationships of women’s pregnancy and breastfeeding histories with ADRD-related pathology is critical for identifying at-risk post-menopausal women. Similar to what has been developed for breast cancer, our research program will work towards developing post-menopausal women’s ADRD risk assessment tools based on reproductive history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Breast cancers can show various types of unstable genomes that can be readily identified by DNA sequencing. These cancers are the most lethal subtypes of breast cancer at the present time. The SPORE is designed to improve the outcome of patients by using the latest in genomic diagnostic tools and pathological evaluations, plus extend this new knowledge for therapeutic approaches to exploit the underlying genomic instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chromatin dynamics, gene expression, and cellular decisions are tightly linked on both short timescales such as individual enhancer-promoter contacts, and longer ones involved in epigenetic memory across cell generations. Our understanding of chromatin dynamics is mostly limited to snapshots, making it difficult to predict its time evolution and effects on human health. Drawing on recent advances in synthetic epigenetic control, genetic locus labeling, super-resolution imaging, multiplexed microscopy, and polymer modeling, we aim to create a new imaging technology to study chromatin dynamics and gene expression across short and long time scales of cell differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project asserts that there at least two different patterns of genome instability for double-strand break repair. One is focused on the function of the BRCA1-BRCA2 pathway, where alterations in function are actually quite common; the second is focused on upstream sensing of DNA damage, which is another way to suppress cancer formation. Upstream defects are best targeted by the use of replication checkpoint inhibitors, but that BRCA defective tumors are best treated by targeting the backup pathway, such as PARP-inhibitors or new agents beyond PARP-inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromosomal instability (CIN) is a hallmark of aggressive breast cancer, yet how it contributes to the ability of cancer cells to resist therapy and spread to distant organs remains poorly understood. Our research identified that CIN promotes aggressive cancer behavior by sustaining chronic inflammation. Here, we will exploit this finding to test whether a tool compound that inhibits inflammation can suppress breast cancer metastasis and to develop novel biomarkers predictive of response to chemotherapies and immunotherapies already approved for the treatment of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: Metastatic breast cancer is one of the leading causes of death among women in the United States with mortality linked to the disease becoming resistant to hormonal therapies. Analyses of breast cancers that are metastatic reveal the presence of pathogenic DNA mutations originating from the mutagenesis process induced by the activity of the APOBEC family of antiviral enzymes. This project will facilitate clinical identification of cancers in which APOBEC is or will become active, elucidate how APOBEC promotes drug resistance, and develop new methods for treating APOBEC positive tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the knowledge that immune activation in spleen critically regulates physiological wound healing and pathological left-ventricular remodeling post-myocardial infarction, the specific mechanism that regulate this cross-talk are not known. Our preliminary results suggest an important role of TNFR1 expressing exosomes in shuttling cardiac-specific damage signals to the distant lymphoid tissues such as the spleen and subsequent immune-activation post-myocardial infarction. In the proposed study, PI intends to study the role of i) spleen in processing circulating exosomes, and ii) exosome specific TNFR1 expression in regulating pathological immune activation and left-ventricular remodeling.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public health relevance)  Antimicrobial resistance is a global health threat, predicted to cause ten million deaths and cumulative healthcare costs of $US100 trillion annually by 2050 if no new approaches are developed. This proposal seeks to obtain a mechanistic understanding of the acquisition of multidrug resistance. The results will have the potential to generate innovative strategies to reduce the spread of resistance determinants and restore the efficacy of MLS antibiotics.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Ross, Judith, M.D. Project Narrative Historically, there have been barriers to involvement of many children in the U.S. in state-of-the art pediatric clinical trials. The IDeA States Pediatric Clinical Trials Network (ISPCTN) represents a transformational opportunity to recruit more underserved children to participate in state-of-the-art clinical trials, facilitate implementation of well-designed pediatric clinical trials, and enhance pediatric clinical trial capacity within the IDeA state, Delaware (DE) at Nemours/Alfred I duPont Hospital for Children (AIDHC). The DE- Nemours/AIDHC site participation in the ISPCTN will catalyze new ideas, promote new collaborations, and will engage clinicians, researchers, and the community in well-designed pediatric clinical trials. Provision of this expertise and infrastructure will increase cutting edge clinical trial research with improved efficiencies for initiating and completing clinical trials and improved public health in DE and the Nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed renewal will expand upon the first phase of a highly productive grant integrating metabolomic profiling and genetics in two cohorts of African Americans with chronic kidney disease. The renewal seeks to advance knowledge of biological pathways underlying chronic kidney disease by further integrating proteomic profiling as well as expanding metabolomic and proteomic work to a third cohort of patients with biopsy- confirmed kidney disease and adjudicated histopathology data. The overall goal is to improve the care of the 800 million patients worldwide with chronic kidney disease by enhancing mechanistic insight and clinical utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The University of Pittsburgh Autism Center of Excellence will fill a void in research on autistic adults and their mental health needs, including risk for suicide. We address this critical topic in authentic partnership with autistic adults and their allies, emphasize mechanistic translation, bring new researchers to work on autism, and provide an academic home for junior researchers getting started in this area. We will generate measures and mechanistic treatment targets that can be applied to improve safety and quality of life, and to reduce premature mortality for autistic adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Asthma, a chronic lung disease that affects 20 million American adults, has well-known disparities in prevalence, severity and death by race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status and sex. We will use Electronic Health Record (EHR) data enhanced with information on social, economic, and environmental characteristics to identify sub-groups of adults with asthma who share common patterns of risk factors. This information will be used to create a tool that can support precision patient care strategies, as well as motivate public health strategies to decrease asthma risk in specific geographic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We  are  creating  user- friendly  and  targeted  tools  to  create  hypothesis- driven  models  of  entire  cells  that  integrate  the  large  body  of  available  knowledge  on  cellular  composition  and  biomolecular  structure.  In  collaboration with experimental and computational biologists, we are applying these methods to systems of  biomedical  interest,  with  a  focus  on  the  interpretation  of  tomographic  data  and  modeling  and  simulation  of  bacterial and mitochondrial genomes. Integrative structural biology also provides unparalleled opportunities  for outreach and education by providing a comprehensive and intuitive understanding of living systems that  spans from atoms to cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Odors are powerful drivers of emotional responses, and aberrant assignment of emotions to odors underlies a variety of human neuropsychiatric conditions. The results of this project will enhance our understanding of how odors acquire emotional significance, and will expand our knowledge of the brain regions and neurotransmitter systems involved. This proposal therefore supports the NIH and NIDCD’s mission to understand how odors are processed in the brain to support perception and ultimately behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Supracellular actomyosin networks are used to fold a diverse range of tissues during development, like neural tube closure. Errors during neural tube closure cause congenital malformations in humans, but we lack a complete understanding on how actomyosin networks contribute to neural tube closure. We propose test a mechanistic model of mammalian neural tube closure which will provide insight on the generalizability of actomyosin-mediated folding mechanisms and create a conceptual foundation from which to understand, prevent, and treat congenital malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although death is a common occurrence, remarkably little work has examined how animals are able to sense and respond to the dead. This proposal seeks to characterize how the fruit fly, Drosophila, senses and responds to the dead of its own kind (conspecifics), as well as the mechanisms underlying this response. Ultimately, our work may have implications for human health, as the spread of vector-borne disease relies on a careful balance between insect life and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop an alternative treatment method for xerostomia or dry mouth, a devastating side effect of radiation therapy that affects 68-85% of head and neck cancer patients. We will develop a bottom-up approach to recreate a functional salivary gland using patient-derived cells with regenerative potential and artificial extracellular matrices that recapitulate the native microenvironments of the developing organ. The goal is to produce an engineered construct with branched architecture consisting of secretory acini and connected ducts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: DNA forms a variety of non-canonical structures that are important for the proper regulation of molecular processes such as replication, recombination, and transcription, but these structures can also promote mutagenesis, driving disease states. This conference will focus on the mechanisms by which DNA structures form, mutate, and resolve, with emphasis on new technologies that can analyze the effects of cellular and environmental factors on different DNA structures. In addition, the conference will provide a supportive and interdisciplinary environment in which new investigators and trainees can interact with field leaders to share their findings and develop collaborations, leading to new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) causes chronic infections in over 250 million patients worldwide who risk developing severe liver disease, including liver cancer. The development of curative therapies has been significantly hampered by the lack of small animal models that support HBV infection and recapitulate disease. Building on exciting new data from our lab, we aim to investigate why HBV does not infect other species, in particular mice, with the goal of creating a mouse model for HBV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Mitochondria play a key role in sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) risk and recovery. We will leverage data from a total of ~5000 SCA cases to identify, validate, and functionally characterize mitochondrial genetic variants associated with SCA risk and resuscitation outcomes. These investigations ultimately will lead to innovative approaches to prevent SCA and improve resuscitation outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial diseases are a group of clinically variable disorders caused by the malfunction of cellular components called mitochondria, which are responsible for generating energy that powers vital body processes. This proposal will utilize cell and animal models to investigate why patients with with mitochondrial disease are more susceptible to lung injury and inflammation after infection with opportunistic bacterial pathogens. This research will have a positive impact on public health because it will enhance our understanding of immune dysfunction in mitochondrial disease and may lead to innovative treatments that alleviate inflammatory and infectious pathology in patients with these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Outgrowth of a large variety of pathogenic bacteria contributes to the progression of periodontal disease. The proposed research will provide insight into how an otherwise unstudied pathogen, Selenomonas sputigena, invades into the cells of the gingival tissue where the organism then disrupts host biology. This research is among the first ever investigations into how this organism interacts with the host and will help elucidate the collective knowledge of how bacteria in the complex plaque biofilm cause periodontal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Major depressive disorder (MDD) disproportionately affects women, but the biological basis of this sex difference is not understood, and stress vulnerability is emerging as a critical risk factor of MDD. Studies have implicated the ventral hippocampal (vHPC) projections to the nucleus accumbens (NAc; vHPC-NAc) in stress-induced susceptibility, and this circuit excitability is reduced by adult testosterone in mice. This research plan will investigate the role of androgen receptors, the signaling pathways involved, and the molecular mechanisms underlying vHPC-NAc circuit excitability which will elucidate how adult testosterone regulates vHPC-NAc circuit function to drive sex-specific behaviors and vulnerability to stress and may lead to specific novel pharmacological therapeutic targets that could be used to treat female patients for MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE TH17 cells play a pivotal role in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) pathogenesis through secretion of many pro- inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. The nuclear receptor NR2F6 is reported to act as a negative transcriptional regulator of TH17 cells making its agonism a promising target for IBD therapy. The proposed studies will address fundamental questions regarding the transcriptional role of NR2F6, insights which will be particularly valuable understanding TH17-mediated chronic inflammation and whether targeting this nuclear receptor may be therapeutically relevant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease of unknown etiology (CKDu) is a global public health crisis with high morbidity and mortality in Central America, and Nicaraguan youth in regions with high adult CKDu prevalence have shown evidence of kidney injury. Nephrotoxic metals have been associated with CKDu in adults and are arguably more toxic to youth given ongoing development of organ systems, though no prior studies have assessed environmental exposures in this high-risk group of young people. While changes in the human microbiome have been associated with both metal exposure and renal health in other populations, we propose the first study to consider metal exposure, the urinary microbiome, and renal function in Central American youth, results of which may inform early CKDu detection and intervention efforts.

PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Gordon Research Conference on Bioinspired Materials will be held June 16-21, 2024 in Les Diablerets, Switzerland, and will be preceded by an accompanying Gordon Research Seminar (June 15-16, 2024). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Obesity in the United States has become a grave public health threat, highlighting the need for the development of more effective obesity treatments. Understanding how gastrointestinal-derived satiation signals, such as amylin, affect neuronal activity to control feeding behavior is necessary for the development of novel pharmacotherapies to combat obesity. The proposed work will evaluate the role of amylin receptor signaling in a novel mesopontine-limbic pathway in the regulation of food intake and motivation to seek palatable food rewards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Proper T cell signaling is required for effective immunity, while aberrant T cell activation is associated with autoimmunity, immunodeficiency, and increased susceptibility to infections and cancer. Our lab has observed that membrane proximal T cell signaling involves physical and functional coupling between membrane domains and protein condensates. The proposed project studies the mutual regulation between membrane rafts and protein condensates in vitro and in live cells and how they affect T cell signaling to advance understanding of spatiotemporal regulation of signal transduction in activated T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative- Stephanie Dancausse Neurotransmitters, like dopamine, play essential roles in carrying out appropriate behaviors in response to an organism’s environment. In order to understand how dopamine in the central brain functions as a neuromodulator and the subsequent impact on locomotive behavior, one must identify the sensitive neurons and their role in behavioral output. Utilizing an invertebrate model to elucidate neural pathways that underlie locomotion and motor control can be yield applicable information in higher order organisms to comprehend disease states associated with these behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deciphering the cryptic patterns of protein recognition sites within cis-regulatory elements along DNA is fundamental to understanding the transcriptional regulation of genes. Deep neural networks applied to this task have demonstrated impressive performance; however, because of their complex nature, it remains difficult to determine how these networks form their decisions. This project will develop a new surrogate modeling framework for interpreting the cis-regulatory syntax learned by deep neural networks, providing a software suite of computational tools for the biomedical community that will have direct applications for understanding complex biological systems and treatment of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-tumor adaptive immune system activity is crucial for good prognosis in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients, but tumors can evolve to escape immune detection, likely leading to worse outcomes. This proposal will characterize one cause of immune evasion–the loss of tumor antigen presentation–and test two potential treatment strategies to overcome this process in breast tumors. This work will be highly relevant to clinical practice and may inform the development and implementation of new therapeutic approaches in TNBC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and associated comorbidities, namely cardiovascular disease (CVD), disproportionately burden Black women and the study of self-management behavioral mechanisms in the specific socio-cultural context of Black women are underexplored. This proposal describes a multi-level, intersectional investigation into these socio-behavioral mechanisms, as influenced by macro-level context, through proposing pathways by which self-management behaviors influence CVD risk in the context of the Superwoman Schema (SWS) among a longitudinal cohort of Black women with SLE. This proposal will advance the knowledge of how to address inequities in SLE by providing a foundation on which to design future disease management interventions and by supporting a junior investigator devoted to a research career in developing and testing multi-level intervention for chronic diseases such as SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is a hallmark symptom in nearly 75% of individuals with AUD, however, the underlying mechanisms of chronic alcohol withdrawal induced pain (CAWIP) are not known. The parabrachial nucleus of the brainstem controls both behavioral reflexive and affective components of pain. This proposal will investigate changes in Y1 neuron activity and function in the parabrachial nucleus as a result of chronic alcohol exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Reading impairment is a devastating and nearly ubiquitous consequence of post-stroke aphasia that results in increased processing time for text-based information and the potential abandonment of hobbies and activities (i.e., reading novels or newspaper articles) due to comprehension difficulties. Currently, our clinical understanding of reading deficits relies on behavioral testing which does not provide adequate insight into the underlying breakdowns in written language processing, especially for bilinguals with aphasia who may present with reading difficulties in one or both languages. This project will examine real-time reading comprehension in bilinguals with aphasia to determine how this population navigates literacy post-stroke and to evaluate whether eye tracking measures may inform clinical approaches to bilingual reading assessment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Assessment of real-time reading comprehension in bilinguals with aphasia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A muscle injury often results in persistent functional declines and impaired mobility in older individuals owing in large part to impaired regenerative responses. With the goal of better understanding the mechanisms underlying these declines over time, we will: 1) investigate how aging of the skeletal muscle extracellular matrix (i.e., the scaffolding material that surrounds all cells) alters the ability of extracellular vesicles to promote functional muscle regeneration, and 2) evaluate whether and how muscle contractile activity reverses these changes. Our long-term goal is to develop novel therapeutics to enhance tissue healing in a geriatric population

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wood smoke exposure has become a growing concern worldwide and has been linked to various respiratory adverse health outcomes, including airway inflammation and disease; however, the mechanism by which this occurs remains unknown. Given that changes in the respiratory microbiome have also been associated with airway inflammation and respiratory disease, investigating its role in the host’s response to wood smoke is significantly relevant to public health, as it offers potential therapeutic and preventive strategies against wood smoke’s adverse effects on respiratory health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  By 2050, Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are estimated to cost the US 1.6 trillion dollars, emphasizing the need to understand their contributing factors. Life course stress has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, anxiety, and elevated levels of inflammation which have long-lasting negative effects on an individual’s health, but there is limited research on associations between lifespan stress and ADRD. The overarching goal of this proposal is to examine the associations of early and later-life stress on later-life cognition and plasma biomarkers of ADRD pathology and whether associations differ by sex, in an effort to provide insights for targeted interventions to mitigate ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This research fellowship aims to design a useful tool for both gaining fundamental knowledge of viral protein-cell membrane interactions and addressing current challenges in targeted drug- delivery, especially those associated with carrier (delivery vehicle) -cell receptor specificity. By developing adapted cell-free protein synthesis techniques, we intend to construct user-defined proteoliposomes whose composition can mirror an exterior viral surface, used towards either furthering our understanding of virus ligand-host cell interactions or repurposed for targeted therapies exploiting the native fidelity of virus membrane proteins and for their respective cellular receptors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to abnormal responses to both expected and unexpected balance challenges, children with cerebral palsy are at an increased risk of falls and resulting injuries. This study will investigate how children with cerebral palsy respond to expected and unexpected balance challenges which mimic functional, daily-life scenarios, and how these responses change with the addition of a secondary, cognitive task. The findings from this study will inform the development of future research studies and facilitate the translation of intervention strategies to clinical practice, improving mobility-based participation and function for children with cerebral palsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study seeks to understand how neural reward processing, an important biomarker of depression risk, relates to real-world experiences of pleasure and affect among adolescents at heightened risk of developing major depressive disorder (MDD). The results of this study could further our understanding on how measures of depression risk that are typically studied in the laboratory relate to adolescents’ daily experiences and could help to identify malleable markers of risk that can be targeted in interventions aimed at decreasing risk for MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The small intestine has dedicated cell types specialized for its role in nutrient absorption and fluid secretion. The proposed research focuses on the mechanisms driving the fate specification of a unique cell type that expresses very high levels of CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator). This work will contribute to the identification of novel therapeutic targets for intestinal disease associated with CFTR dysregulation, including cystic fibrosis and secretory diarrheal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with autism spectrum disorders have persistent deficits in social communication, but prospective studies indicate disruptions in communication are difficult to detect in early infancy. Infants initiate their first social interactions through cry and previous research supports cry acoustics as an early marker of autism. The proposed study utilizes existing longitudinal data to replicate and extend prior findings of caregiver perception differences of cries from infants later diagnosed with autism and investigate patterns of caregiver- infant interactions involving cry to advance understanding of early social communication development in infants with and without autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension and cardiovascular disorders are major contributors to premature death worldwide and their prevalence and severity are exacerbated by excess salt intake. The steroid hormone aldosterone induces sodium intake, but we have a poor understanding of how this occurs. The proposed study will investigate the molecular and genetic changes that occur in specialized aldosterone-sensing neurons after aldosterone treatment which may allow for the future development of therapies to reduce excess salt intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The expansion of Medicaid increases health care access for patients experiencing critical illness, half of whom will experience new or worsening physical, mental health or cognitive function after an intensive care unit stay. The proposed work leverages complementary methods and data to understand how sociocultural environments, built environments and health systems influence Medicaid members’ recovery after an intensive care unit stay. By combining Medicaid claims, hospital & community-level public health, interviews and electronic health records datawith health services, qualitative, and machine learning research methods, this project will provide much-needed information to state Medicaid agencies formulating policies to improve the health outcomes of seriously ill patients and advance health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to public health Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma is a deadly liver cancer with limited treatment options. Recent progress in developing subtype specific treatments have shown the promise of precision medicine for improving outcomes, emphasizing the need for noninvasive diagnosis of thesesubtypes. Leveraging the high sensitivity of hyperpolarized imaging, the proposed work aims to optimize and validate a new approach to bring accurate and rapid diagnostics to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cancer cells rely on non-canonical DNA damage repair mechanisms to stabilize their genomes, and these pathways are often non-essential in healthy tissues and thus represent therapeutic opportunities. In this proposal, a multidisciplinary approach will be leveraged to develop a covalent inhibitor for a recently discovered genome maintenance pathway dependent on the protein cancerous inhibitor of protein phosphatase 2A (CIP2A). Proposal success will both provide valuable chemical tools to understand CIP2A function and lay the foundation for therapeutics to inhibit this protein and its role across various cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Enterococci cause as much as 26% of all cases of infective endocarditis (IE), a disease among the most challenging to treat with mortality rates often exceeding 30%. To date, there is a dearth of evidence to explain patient and bacterial factors most important for the transition from enterococcal bacteremia to IE. The proposed research will use genomics, proteomics, dense and well-integrated patient health data, and follow up in vitro studies to disentangle factors associated with enterococcal IE to inform diagnostic, therapeutic and intervention strategies to curb these infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of general single-atom skeletal editing reactions enables the rapid synthesis and evaluation of a broader scope of core-modified derivatives of bioactive compounds during medicinal and agrochemical discovery campaigns. The photomediated ring contraction of saturated heterocycles exemplifies a highly enabling reaction of this class, but is currently difficult to apply in a real-world context due to limitations in scope, lack of understanding of the most efficient wavelength to use, and variability in enantioselectivity. Expansion of the scope by leveraging peripheral functionalization chemistry, characterization of mechanism and wavelength- dependent reactivity, and data science driven rationalization of enantioselectivity trends will elucidate fundamental understanding and enable application of this knowledge to the optimization of the ring contraction for more general and highly enantioselective applications in health-related industries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The decline of physical function with aging is a critical public health concern, given the strong association between frailty, muscle weakness, and adverse health outcomes in the elderly. This project aims to investigate the role of L-kynurenine (L-Kyn) and the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) in exacerbating physical function deterioration during aging. Understanding the mechanisms underlying age-related physical decline could lead to the development of novel interventions to attenuate frailty and muscle weakness and improve the quality of life for the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is characterized by RAS and autophagy-dependent growth, and dual inhibition of the RAS-ERK MAPK and autophagy pathways is a potential treatment strategy for PDAC. One aim of this study will assess whether prolonged inhibition of the RAS-ERK MAPK pathway results in compensatory upregulation of another nutrient scavenging pathway, macropinocytosis, and whether this process mediates resistance to dual RAS-ERK MAPK and autophagy pathway inhibition. Additionally, I demonstrate that ERK inhibition results in increased macropinocytosis and hypothesize that this could be exploited to increase delivery of albumin-bound therapeutics such as nab-paclitaxel, which is currently second-line treatment for PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mesolimbic dopamine system is at the core of stimulus processing, and its dysregulation by cocaine use results in deficits in the ability to appropriately respond to biologically important information outside of the drug context. In order to identify potential therapies targeting these systems, it is paramount to fully understand how dopamine signaling is involved in basic neural functions that support adaptive learning and motivation. In this proposal, I will define how dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens organizes local neural activity around interaction with salient stimuli, and identify how dopamine's capacity to modulate striatal function changes as a consequence of chronic cocaine use.
