IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Parasitic nematodes are the most abundant, diverse, and destructive macroparasites on the planet, placing heavy health burdens on billions of people in developing countries and causing billions of dollars lost annually in crops and livestock. This proposal seeks to identify genes, transcripts, and small molecules involved in emodepside resistance, a promising new anthelmintic with completely uncharacterized resistance mechanisms. Completion of this proposal will identify emodepside resistance genes and establish biochemical mechanisms behind the metabolism of emodepside, which are both needed to implement targeted and effective anthelmintic treatment plans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our recent studies identified ATAD2 as an up-regulated druggable protein treatment-induced NEPC. Moreover, we demonstrated that ATAD2 inhibitors dramatically suppress NEPC cell and tumor growth. The goals of the study are to test the therapeutic potential of ATAD2 inhibitor alone or in combination therapy settings in pre- clinical models of adeno-CRPC and NEPC and define new mechanisms through which ATAD2 regulates prostate tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative At present, there is no ideal treatment for type II diabetes, which increases a patient's likelihood of developing cardiovascular disease and its related mortality. This research proposal aims to investigate the molecular pathways through which high fat diet leads to cardiac insulin resistance, as obesity is a major contributor. The insights gained from this study will allow for the advancement of therapies for cardiovascular disease in patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular herpes infection is a leading cause of infectious corneal blindness in the world. Current topical antiviral eyedrops available for the management of ocular herpes need to be administered 5-9 times daily. This proposal aims to repurpose adefovir dipivoxil, an off-patent FDA-approved hepatitis B virus DNA polymerase inhibitor, for the treatment of ocular herpes and reformulate ADV into long-acting nanoformulations to achieve once a day topical therapy for effective therapy of ocular HSV infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During division, cells must accurately segregate their genome into two equal daughter cells, as errors can impact cell health and lead to diseases such as cancer. The anaphase spindle is the structure responsible for actively separating sister chromatids, and here I will probe its mechanical properties in live mammalian cells and ask how overexpression of the oncogenic protein PRC1 can disrupt its proper functioning. By improving our understanding of anaphase mechanics in healthy and cancer contexts, this work may provide future avenues of therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies of how distinct dietary inputs integrate to affect colorectal cancer metabolism and epigenetic regulation are limited. This project will contribute to our understanding of how metabolic pathways regulate the differentiation and function of CRC, as well as how manipulation of host genetics can augment or limit the efficacy of dietary interventions. Determining the interaction between dietary inputs in the context of host genetics has the potential to identify novel mechanisms to inform dietary interventions to prevent and combat CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Traditional SPF mouse models do not accurately reflect the immune compartment makeup observed in humans, particularly the T cell compartment. This proposal utilizes pet store mouse cohousing to normalize mouse pathogen exposure with the goal to explore the maintenance and function of long-lived effector CD8 T cells. These studies will help better understand the factors that promote T cell maintenance and function in a model with normal levels of pathogen exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Novel Ewing sarcoma therapies are urgently needed as children who present with metastatic disease have only a 30% chance of survival, and if a child relapses the chance of survival drops to nearly zero. This project aims to validate IGF2BP1 as a dependency in Ewing sarcoma, uncover the role IGF2BP1 plays in Ewing sarcoma pathogenesis, and biochemically characterize how IGF2BP1 promotes Ewing sarcoma growth. Through understanding how IGF2BP1 binds substrates, high-throughput chemical screens can be developed to identify novel, IGF2BP1 targeting molecules as future Ewing sarcoma therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, approximately 240,000 infants die globally due to birth defects; although efforts have been made to address this through interventions and preventative strategies, progress is hindered by the challenges of understanding the genetic underpinnings of human development. In this proposal, we aim to investigate a novel epigenetic regulatory mechanism essential for hematopoietic development. The outcomes of this research are expected to significantly enhance our understanding of human development, potentially opening doors to innovative therapeutic approaches for combating birth defects and blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medulloblastoma metastasizes outside of the brain leading to a ten-fold increase in mortality but the underlying mechanisms that lead to invasion and migration properties in medulloblastoma is still unknown. Our preliminary analyses indicate BAIAP2 and CDC42 have oncogenic roles leading to migratory properties in medulloblastoma. We will investigate their interaction in medulloblastoma in order to identify possible novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Antibiotics are primary treatments for bacterial infections, but their use promotes generation of multi- resistant pathogens, affects the diversity and function of the microbiota, and subsequently impacts the intestinal regulatory immune system. Very little is known about how commonly prescribed oral antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin, impacts beneficial gut microbes, such as Lactobacillus, and its interaction with the host immune system. This project addresses that gap by investigating how the ciprofloxacin-selected Lactobacillus alters the function of intestinal regulatory lymphocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease and its related dementias (ADRD) have become both a health and financial crisis in America; it is currently estimated that one-third of seniors dies with ADRD, and more than 11 million Americans provide unpaid care for persons with ADRD. There are currently no viable treatments for ADRD that have been shown to rescue brain function. My proposal will contribute fundamental knowledge to early ADRD reversal, using an interventional approach that may someday achieve clinical relevance in the treatment of ADRD.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseased skeletal muscles exhibit abnormal patterns of RNA processing. The proposed work aims to determine how disruption to the RNA processing of the clathrin gene products leads to defects in skeletal muscle function. By defining these cellular and molecular events, the proposed studies will help identify targets that can be used to develop novel therapeutics to treat skeletal muscle diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vestibular inner ear encodes head motions through the displacement of mechanosensitive hair bundles and distinct afferent firing patterns. Previous work has characterized hair cell and afferent properties at the single- cell level yet how head motions are encoded at the circuit-level is not well understood. The objective of the proposed study is to use hair cell and afferent voltage-gated ion channels as building blocks for circuit-level computational models that are more faithful to how the system encodes head motions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative: Periodontitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the destruction of the tooth-supporting structures including periodontal tissue attachment and alveolar bone. We propose that activation of a newly identified cell surface receptor present on gingival mast cells contributes to inflammation and periodontal bone loss. Development of novel humanized mouse models to study how this receptor is activated may provide new approaches to modulate periodontitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dysregulation of inflammation and immune responses plays a key role in the pathophysiology of skin disorders, including psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, hidradenitis suppurativa, and pachyonychia congenita. This project is focused on identifying keratin-dependent pathways in epidermal keratinocytes and understanding their role in regulating the spatiotemporal pattern of neutrophil infiltration and engagement of other cellular effectors in inflamed skin. Completion of the proposed studies will generate new insight into skin homeostasis and may help identify new biomarkers and new targets for the diagnosis and treatment of skin disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precise regulation of neutrophil inflammatory state following myocardial infarction is critical in driving cardiac repair. The balance of chemical and mechanical cues that regulate this state, and the mechanisms by which they act, remain poorly understood. This proposed research will contribute to human health by elucidating mechanisms by which neutrophils integrate chemical and mechanical cues to regulate inflammatory state, which will inform the design of therapeutics to modulate this process in the context of human cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose the development of a 3D hydrogel platform that can anchor soluble bioinert ligands, like GFP, for the activation of regenerative cell behaviors from cells engineered with synthetic Notch receptors. We hypothesize that this innovative technology will lead to tunable and dynamic control of cellular behaviors with high levels of spatial control from the captured ligands. To demonstrate the therapeutic potential of our platform, we will test inflammation attenuation and differentiation of multipotent cells to osteogenic and chondrogenic fates for musculoskeletal repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Biological energy transduction is crucial to life and is primarily orchestrated through the coupling of proton and electron movement. While electron transfer has been extensively studied, proton transfer has been more difficult to study experimentally. Through protein design, we will design and express proteins that bind abiological photoacid cofactors that will enable us to observe, for the first time, the generation and management of proton currents in proteins, giving fundamental insight into proton conduction in biological systems and take the first step toward the design of complex protein machinery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Huntington’s Disease – a devastating neurodegenerative condition – is caused by a defect in the Huntingtin gene, resulting in the production of alternative forms of Huntingtin mRNA and protein. This proposal will use small RNA drugs to reduce alternative forms of Huntingtin in mouse models of Huntington’s disease and determine the effect on disease features and outcomes. Findings from these studies will provide insight into the mechanisms underlying Huntington’s Disease to inform the development of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ability for blood vessels to dilate for the delivery of oxygen (O2) to targeted muscles and the extraction of O2 at the muscle level are impaired in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS); however, no research has examined the influence of lower-limb vascular function on poor walking efficiency in this population. This project may identify specific vascular mechanisms that contribute to walking efficiency in persons with MS. Such findings may guide researchers, clinicians, and exercise specialists in the design of targeted approaches to improve walking efficiency and its consequences with the aim of promoting health, managing comorbidities, and enhancing overall well-being, quality of life, and participation in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulation of gene expression to produce proteins at the right time and right place is essential for animal development. Localization of messenger RNA (mRNA) and local translation is one method of regulating gene expression posttranscriptionally, and this mRNA regulation is necessary for establishing asymmetrical protein distributions to create the architecture of polarized cells during a process called morphogenesis. This proposal examines the localization and protein interactors of an mRNA as neurons remodel their axons and dendrites during morphogenesis using a relevant fruit fly (Drosophila) model through novel CRISPR/Cas13-based methods.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide insight into the relationship between chronic health conditions occurring early in the life course and fertility patterns, including the mechanisms through which these processes are connected. Results from this study will improve demographic knowledge of population fertility by enhancing understandings of fertility goals, timing, and achievement in the context of chronic health conditions, particularly as average maternal age at birth increases in the U.S. This project will provide an unparalleled opportunity to train the applicant in the methodological tools and professional skills required to complete the proposed research and develop into a social demographer poised to study this important intersection between health and fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative This proposal requests funds to support the 77th Annual Symposium of the Society of General Physiologists (SGP) titled `Molecular Evolution in the Membrane' from September 4th to September 8th, 2024, at the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) in Woods Hole, MA. The SGP annual symposium has an established international reputation as a leading meeting for physiologists, biophysicists, and molecular biologists at all career stages. The overarching goals of the 77th edition are to highlight cutting edge methods and transformative technologies that have led to advancements in understanding the origins of functional diversity in ion channels, transporters, and receptors, inspire and recognize young and diverse investigators who carry out this research, and to foster interdisciplinary collaborations across fields such as biophysics, physiology, structural biology, bioinformatics, and phylogenetics, which will contribute to foundational science in support of breakthroughs in human health.

PHR: UNCOVERING THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF VEGFA AND ANG2 PRO-ANGIOGENIC SIGNALING IN HEREDITARY HEMORRHAGIC TELANGIECTASIA Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) is a genetic vascular disease with sometimes lethal, non-curative arteriovenous malformations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Encephalitozoon intestinalis is one of the most prevalent species of microsporidia found in humans and can lead to fatal disease in immunocompromised individuals. While E. intestinalis causes significant disease burden, our understanding of how these parasites develop within their host remains limited. Thus, using cellular, proteomic, and structural approaches we will investigate the molecular and cellular features of the replicative niche established during infection and uncover how these parasites successfully replicate within their host, ultimately leading to the development of novel therapeutic strategies which are currently limited.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Racism is increasingly becoming a public health concern which poses a risk for an increase in depression symptoms among Black Americans during adolescence and with recent studies indicating that Black fathers are salient and active participants in the parenting process,5, 25, 39 our understanding of the patterns of parenting strategies among Black fathers is limited. The overall goal of this NRSA proposal is to provide a methodologically rigorous examination of the heterogeneity of Black fathers’ parenting strategies and its protective capabilities on the long-term consequences of racism experiences on depression symptomatology among Black adolescents. The proposed research will 1) investigate the longitudinal stability of Black fathers’ paternal strategies subgroups and attenuating effects of parenting strategies among Black fathers on the relationship between racism exposure and depression symptoms among Black adolescents and 2) could inform theory and efforts to promote positive youth development in the face of racism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver disorders affect 30 million people in the United States and a better understanding of hepatocyte biology is urgently needed to improve existing approaches and to innovate therapies for liver disease treatment. Polyploidy (increases in whole chromosome sets) is characteristic of the liver, yet the functions of diploid and polyploid hepatocytes are poorly understood. The comprehensive research plan will expand our understanding of hepatocyte ploidy populations and elucidate the specialized roles played by diploid and polyploid hepatocytes in acute liver injuries.

PHR: Project Narrative Lipid droplets play critical roles in energy metabolism and the etiology of numerous human diseases, such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, atherosclerosis, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders. A comprehensive understanding of the underlying processes of lipid droplets is paramount for the development of effective strategies to prevent and treat these prevalent diseases. The upcoming 9th FASEB Scientific Research Conference on Lipid Droplets will unite researchers from diverse scientific backgrounds and career stages, fostering lasting collaborations and discussions on important topics in lipid droplet biology and inspiring innovative research among the next generation of scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The poorly characterized initiation factor eIF2A functions in an alternate translation initiation pathway during times of cellular stress. This factor has been implicated in the translation initiation of viral and oncogenic mRNA through classical AUG and near-cognate start codons. The proposed research will contribute to a fundamental understanding of how eIF2A selectively binds and recruits tRNA to the ribosome to facilitate activation of this non-canonical initiation pathway.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to understand how synaptic dysfunction of inhibitory interneurons contribute to disease phenotypes of human disorders due to pathogenic loss-of-function variants in the X-linked gene CASK. Lack of knowledge about how loss of the protein CASK contributes to neuronal dysfunction and how this dysfunction connects to disease phenotypes has limited the ability to develop therapeutics to alleviate symptoms or prevent disease. Furthermore, this project is applicable to the NIH’s mission because it will provide fundamental knowledge about the cellular mechanisms of intellectual disability and epilepsy, common symptoms across numerous neurodevelopmental disorders. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to investigate the activation mechanisms of myokine signaling in response to mitochondrial protein import stress. We will validate the role of a specific myokine in promoting body mass homeostasis and cardiac health. This research holds the potential to advance our understanding of cellular stress adaptation and its implications for metabolic and cardiovascular health, opening new avenues for targeted therapeutic interventions to reduce the burden of metabolic and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality crisis in the US has led to implementation of numerous state-level initiatives and policies aimed at changing clinical practices to improve outcomes. However, some newborn initiatives were designed and implemented with little mention of maternal outcomes, and evidence on the effect of these initiatives is limited and mixed. This study will use recent methodologic innovations to address evidence gaps and evaluate the effects of state-level initiatives to reduce early-term elective deliveries (i.e., non-medically indicated labor inductions and c-sections occurring before 39 weeks gestational age) on both maternal and newborn outcomes and disparities in outcomes; results will inform future adaptation and development of state-level initiatives to improve perinatal outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Oxidative stress contributes to the development and progression of ocular diseases including cataracts, glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration, and diabetic retinopathy. One-carbon metabolism influences the response to oxidative stress via antioxidant biosynthesis; however, this pathway is also perturbed by oxidative stress in the eye. In these studies, I propose that oxidative stress leads to the oxidation of Adenosylhomocysteinase (Ahcy) inhibiting its activity, resulting in increased SAH and decreased methylation capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to maintain genome integrity, our cells must continuously restrain the mobilization of “jumping genes” or transposable elements (TEs), in particular Long INterspersed Element-1 (LINE-1), the most active and influential mammalian TE. In this project, I will establish transcriptional decay by the RNA exosome complex as an unidentified yet critical repressor of LINE-1 activity in B lymphocytes and assess the downstream cellular consequences in the absence of this proposed silencing system. My anticipated findings will illuminate a new mechanism by which B cells prevent genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders are chronic disorders often accompanied by persistent alterations to neural circuitry underlying reward and memory, leaving diagnosed individuals susceptible to relapse after prolonged periods of abstinence. Women and men differ in their biological and behavioral responses to drugs of abuse, and significant progress is needed to understand the molecular and epigenetic mechanisms underlying sex-specific, drug- induced alterations. The experiments in this proposal will examine how Gilz (glucocorticoid-induced leucine zipper), an X-chromosome linked gene, contributes to the establishment and reinstatement of cocaine- associated behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronavirus Infection Dynamics and Cross-species Transmission in Bats Newly emerged coronaviruses are a major threat to public health and understanding infection dynamics in reservoir bat hosts has the potential to inform on disease emergence and mitigation of epidemic and pandemic risk. This proposal will investigate host and environmental conditions facilitating cross-species transmission in wildlife sampled across Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. I will also prospectively collect data on bat-borne coronaviruses in diverse ecosystems locally in California (USA) and at an international field site (Myanmar) to assess seasonality, model disease dynamics, and investigate drivers of cross-species disease transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KMT2A-rearranged (formerly MLL-rearranged) leukemia is a particularly aggressive form of blood cancer that is often resistant to current chemotherapies, thus highlighting the need for better treatment strategies. We discovered that a key factor, called HMGA1, is required for KMT2A-r leukemic cells to grow and evade therapy. I now propose studies to determine how HMGA1 functions in KMT2A-r leukemia in order to develop better therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intracellular bacterium, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, causes the potentially fatal human infection, granulocytic anaplasmosis. This proposal will dissect how A. phagocytophilum exits host cells using a process known as regulated exocytosis as an essential step in disease progression. As numerous other pathogens and malignancies commandeer regulated exocytosis, the fundamental knowledge generated by this project could lead to novel therapeutic targets for treating diverse diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiome is emerging as an important determinant of brain development and these recent findings are prompting a paradigm shift in neuroscience. Microbial dysbiosis, which is frequently associated with neurodevelopmental disorders like autism, is also associated with aberrant visual processing, a commonly diagnosed comorbidity with autism. My goal in this proposal is to determine the role host-associated microbes play in visual system neurodevelopment, and to expand our overall knowledge on how the microbiome interacts with local cells in the gut to impact brain development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rett syndrome (RTT) is a debilitating neurological disorder without cure caused by mutations of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome. This proposal aims to apply CRISPR-based DNA methylation editing to restore healthy MeCP2 expression from the inactive X chromosome for the treatment of RTT in female patients. Understanding the extent of and mechanisms that govern this process will inform targeted epigenetic approaches to treat RTT and other X-linked disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Proprioception encodes the perception of body and limb position, which is critical for motor behaviors and reflexes. Despite the essential nature of this sense, our understanding of how proprioceptive signals are transmitted into the spinal cord to regulate movement is not clear. The experiments proposed herein, will investigate the mechanisms through which the voltage-gated sodium channel, NaV1.6, shapes proprioceptive signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Altered dopamine signaling is a major characteristic of many neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders including schizophrenia and Parkinson’s disease. Due to a limited understanding of dopamine biology in both healthy and diseased states, we lack effective treatments for these disorders. The newest dLight variants provide the ability to measure dopamine dynamics with unprecedented precision, and this proposal aims to characterize the performance of the newest versions of this sensor in regions throughout the brain in both healthy animals and offspring of a maternal immune activation disease model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voltage-gated sodium channels (VGSCs) mediate action potential propagation and transduction in neurons, however, recent work has shown that VGSCs serve additional functions in non- excitable cell types and in the developing nervous system. The potential contribution of these “non-canonical” functions of VGSCs to the development of neurodevelopmental conditions remains unknown. This proposed work will use human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived brain organoids and genome engineering to investigate the molecular mechanism underlying non-canonical VGSC contributions to neurological development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allergies have dramatically increased in developed countries in the last several decades and can lead to deadly reactions. These responses are driven by IgE, an antibody isotype whose fundamental biology is poorly understood. By elucidating the molecular and cellular mechanisms of IgE clearance, this project will provide insights into the persistence of allergy and highlight potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accessing the submucosal space within the wall of the gastrointestinal tract is an attractive minimally invasive method that could be used for the implantation of therapeutic devices and cell therapies. However, the biology of the submucosal space as a host for cell therapies is not well understood, limiting development of these technologies for clinical application. This proposal aims to develop new knowledge in this area, which will be critical for subsequent potential therapeutic human applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanism of how AAA+ protein disaggregases collaborate with molecular chaperones to target and dissolve toxic amyloid aggregates to maintain protein homeostasis. These studies propose to use both biochemical assays and cryo-electron microscopy to determine structural snapshots which identify how these AAA+ disaggregases interact with the Hsp70 molecular chaperone system to disaggregate substrate. Completion of this proposal will produce the very first high-resolution details to the disaggregation activity of a protein disaggregase and will lead a foundation to study how potentiated mutants can dissolve human-associated amyloid aggregates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myopia is rapidly approaching pandemic levels worldwide. The proposed studies will use wild-type conditions, environmental (LIM), and pharmacological (atRA) myopia models to elucidate the role of scleral fibroblasts during refractive development in mice. In doing so, I will provide valuable insight into mechanisms driving myopia development that are downstream of retinal signaling, which is an ideal window for clinical intervention in myopia prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Monkeypox (mpox) virus (MPXV) is significant threat to public health with pandemic potential. However, FDA- approved smallpox antiviral drugs do not work effectively for treating MPXV infections. The development of chemically and mechanistically novel antiviral leads that are safe, potent and orally available in this project will set the stage for further pre-clinical development of MPXV drugs that may also contribute substantially to countering other orthopoxviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is a great need for earlier diagnosis and more effective treatments of psychosis, but a lack of understanding of the underlying neural circuitry involved in the pathophysiology of psychosis is a major barrier to the development of effective treatment options. This project will examine the synaptic and functional details of a murine neural circuit that links hippocampal hyperactivity to overactive dopamine signaling and psychosis-associated behavior. The investigation on specific brain regions, pathways, and nerve cells will help fill the gap in knowledge of the underlying neurobiology of psychosis and aid our ability to ultimately identify early indicators of pathology and develop new and more targeted treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a leading cause of liver failure with mortality rates projected to continuously increase over the next few years. As the average lifespan increases, the prevalence of chronic liver diseases like ALD increases especially in the older adult and elderly population. The proposed studies will help to elucidate the underlying mechanisms in which aging and alcohol consumption collaboratively influence and exacerbate the development of ALD by assessing the roles of TFEB-mediated autophagy and the involvement of the integrated stress response (ISR) mediated by ATF3 activation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Obesity is a disorder leading to metabolic disease, which is pervasive and is reaching epidemic proportions in the United States. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of perineuronal nets regulating neurons in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) that mediate body weight and glycemic control. These investigations will facilitate the creation of new avenues for the treatment of obesity and associated disorders including diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a debilitating and irreversible neurodegenerative disease associated with major disruptions to sleep, an essential and ubiquitous process in all animals. Recent works reveal there is a strong bidirectional relationship between loss of slow-wave sleep (SWS), the deepest sleep stage, and the pathological and cognitive features of AD. Here, I will investigate whether chronic pharmacological slow-wave activity (SWA) enhancement can improve pathology and disturbances to sleep-wake rhythms and sleep architecture (Aim 1), as well as rescue behavioral and biological measures of memory deficits (Aim 2) in a mouse model of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the 3rd most common cancer and the 2nd leading cause of cancer death. After surgery, patients receive chemotherapy, including a drug called oxaliplatin, to prevent the recurrence of cancer. Oxaliplatin benefits less than 10% of patients, but it causes disabling neurotoxicity (nerve damage) in over 90% of patients. This project aims to develop an artificial intelligence model to predict which patient would benefit from oxaliplatin so that clinicians can choose different regimens to maximize efficacy and minimize unnecessary side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Epidermal basal cells give rise to the stratified layers of the epidermis during homeostasis; however, upon wounding, epidermal basal cells undergo a transient transcriptional switch to express genes required for wound healing. The regulation of this transcriptional switch is unknown, but our research has shown that a key chromatin regulator, PRC1, represses genes specific for epithelial fate upon wound induction, suggesting that PRC1 regulation is responsible for the transcriptional switch observed in epidermal basal cells during re- epithelialization. By investigating the role of PRC1-mediated regulation of epidermal basal cells during wound healing, we will be able to elucidate the mechanisms that control the transient transcriptional switch and thus the epidermal basal cells’ ability to properly contribute to the re-epithelialization process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The detrimental effects of social isolation during COVID-19 on young brains was immediately evident in the rise of the loneliness epidemic, an increase in mental illness amongst adolescence, and the immergence of Hikikomori Syndrome, but the long-term effects of adolescent social isolation on neurodevelopment are unclear. Social deficits are an early predictor for development of psychiatric disorders and are linked to cognitive impairments, a symptom of psychiatric illnesses for which there are no available treatments. This proposal aims to elucidate neurodevelopmental impact of adolescent social isolation across lifespan at the level of the cell, circuit, and behavior, and to identify timepoints for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advancements in treating isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutated acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with targeted differentiation therapy, oncogenic Nras mutations consistently predict resistance. This proposal will characterize the role of oncogenic Nras in IDH mutant AML leukemogenesis and responsiveness to differentiation therapy with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets for this high-risk patient group. Using clinically relevant mouse models and patient samples, this work will elucidate how signaling environments influence a cell’s differentiation state and how cell state subsequently influences response to differentiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a multifactorial disease with poorly understood mechanisms. Our previous research implicates the ouabain-induced signaling pathway of the Na,K-ATPase as a contributor of cyst progression in ADPKD. This proposal uses novel animal models to begin uncovering the mechanisms behind this ouabain-induced Na,K-ATPase signaling in ADPKD and reveal targets for future ADPKD therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Severe increased intracranial pressure results in high levels of death and disability for affected individuals, particularly in low-income environments such as rural settings and regions lacking access to neurosurgical care. In this proposal, we aim to develop novel kinematic navigation tools and workflows that will enable first- responding doctors to provide emergency stabilizing treatment to affected individuals in need of transport to hospitals with access to neurosurgical care. We additionally aim to deeply investigate the principles of these new kinematic tools for other surgical approaches including brain biopsy and spine surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) have a greater than 2-fold chance of experiencing a cardiovascular disease (CVD) associated event. Understanding the physiological profile and interaction between cardiac macrophages and fibroblasts will provide critical information regarding the increased CVD risk these patients face. Evaluating the impact of PTSD on CVD development we will lay the groundwork to determine CVD risk in vulnerable patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphatic malformations (LMs) due to somatic activating mutations in the KRAS gene lead to life-threatening symptoms such as pleural effusions, chylous ascites and chylothorax. The proposed research will be the first to investigate the role of the PA pathway and MMPs in the regression of lymphatic valves in LMs. This work may enable the development of therapeutics for LMs by identifying the downstream targets that directly cause valve loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the rapidly evolving immune system, genetic variation between individuals, or intraspecific variation, is a major driver of differential responses to infection. Transposable elements occupy about half of the mammalian genome and are a major source of genetic variation. By characterizing the contribution of these elements to intraspecific variation in both the human and mouse adaptive immune system, we will improve our understanding of how the immune system evolves and derive novel insights into the gene regulatory networks underlying the adaptive immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy type 1 (EDMD1) is a hereditary muscular dystrophy that causes profound atrial arrhythmia. EDMD1 is caused by loss-of- function mutations to the nuclear membrane protein emerin, but how emerin influences atrial cell health remains a mystery. We propose a new model system to study this disease, and will use this system to define how emerin is regulated by dynamic trafficking through the secretory pathway in human atrial cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) Striatal calcium voltage-gated (CaV)1.3 channels represent a novel molecular target for levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LID), which remains a serious complication to medical treatment of individuals with Parkinson disease (PD). Acknowledging that age is the greatest risk factor for PD and that there are sex-related differences in PD and LID, in the previous iteration of this R01 award we expanded our research program, aimed at validating this promising target, into male and female parkinsonian rats and nonhuman primates (NHPs) of advancing age demonstrating for the first time that when gene-therapy mediated CaV1.3 silencing is employed as a proactive precision therapy in the aging brain there is maintenance of a profound antidyskinetic benefit and a striking reversal of long-standing parkinsonian disability, particularly pronounced in aged NHPs. In this competitive renewal, we propose a set of studies directed at determining the capacity and/or limitations of reversing established LID, modeling exploration of the therapeutic efficacy of CaV1.3 silencing in two demographics of PD, specifically in those with idiopathic PD and those with young onset PD (YOPD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a highly prevalent neurological disorder with associated cognitive comorbidities that represent a significant burden to quality of life. This proposal will investigate whether altered timing of hippocampal inputs contributes to memory impairments in a mouse model of temporal lobe epilepsy. Understanding how hippocampal synchrony supports cognitive performance and how this is disrupted in epilepsy will yield deeper insight into the basic mechanisms of learning and memory in addition to enabling future treatments that specifically target cognitive deficits in epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption to the cilia, a small cell protrusion, in the feeding center of the brain causes obesity. In this research proposal, I will define how a ciliary GTPase regulates feeding behavior. A better understanding of satiety and appetite control will enable new strategies to combat obesity, a major public health concern.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine fibroids are noncancerous tumors that form within the uterus, affecting nearly 70 - 80% of women in their lifetimes, and are a major cause of severe pain, bleeding, and infertility. Yet, despite its high prevalence and significant disease burden, current treatment options are limited, relying primarily on surgical means of removal, with innovation hampered by a poor understanding of the underlying disease pathophysiology. Therefore, this research proposal seeks to establish fundamental knowledge regarding the structure, function, and mechanics of uterine fibroids through a multi-scale, multi-faceted engineering-based approach to directly improve the diagnosis and treatment of uterine fibroids.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Despite nearly all adolescents in the United States reporting they use social media, and nearly half reporting they use it almost constantly, mixed findings in the literature have prevented a clear understanding of how social media use is specifically associated with adolescent emotional development. The proposed investigation will use a nuanced multimethod approach, combining lab-based experiments—along with physiological indicators— and real-life ecological momentary assessment to understand how four distinct SMU types impact adolescent emotions, are intentionally used by adolescents to influence their feelings, and their association with the development of depressive symptoms. In taking a nuanced approach to understand how specific types of SMU are associated with distinct emotional experiences, both in controlled lab-based settings and in everyday life contexts, this study aims to inform future interventions that target healthy adolescent social media use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Eviction is a common, inequitably distributed, and policy-sensitive driver of poor individual health outcomes that may also produce spillover effects on neighborhood health by exacerbating stress and disrupting protective social structures within communities. This mixed-methods study will draw on local and national data to examine whether, how, and for whom neighborhood-level eviction exposures affect individual-level cardiovascular health outcomes. This study will deepen our understanding of how eviction influences health (with implications for reducing health inequities) while also providing invaluable opportunities to expand the trainee’s conceptual knowledge, methodological skill, and ability to translate research findings to policy and practice improvement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in Chromodomain Helicase DNA-binding protein 8 (CHD8) have a strong causal association with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), but the cell-type specific molecular phenotypes that drive ASD-relevant pathology are uncertain. Further, previous studies of human ASD patients, including CHD8 mutants, suggest a presence of immune dysfunction, but the effects of CHD8 haploinsufficiency on microglia have yet to be defined. This proposal will help elucidate cell type-specific changes in gene expression linked to Chd8 haploinsufficiency in the mouse brain and clarify its relationship to immune function, thereby enhancing the current understanding of mechanisms underlying autism and identifying potential targets for treatment or preventative measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neuroimaging field is currently in the midst of a power problem. Without sufficient increases in power, predictive utility of connectomes, including for clinical applications, remains low. I propose improvements to network-level statistical methods for human functional and structural connectomes to improve statistical power.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive decline during aging involves impairments in using stored information to support learning in new environments, leading to decreased behavioral flexibility. This proposal will investigate whether the similarity between cognitive maps in the dorsal CA1 region of the hippocampus changes as mice accumulate multiple cognitive maps across different age groups. Understanding how similarity between cognitive maps aids in behavioral flexibility is critical to understanding the neural signaling alterations that underlie cognitive decline and can pave the way for therapeutic interventions that will improve the quality of life for an aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although research has identified a link between psychopathology and cognitive decline, as well as the inverse causal effect, (i.e., degradation of biological and cognitive systems increasing risk for new or worsening psychopathology), investigation of a bidirectional relationship between psychopathology and cognition remains largely unstudied. The objective of this application is to investigate the bidirectional effects of psychological and cognitive processes over time in midlife to identify potential early signs of cognitive decline prior to the onset of neurodegeneration, which may in turn, reduce the likelihood of new or worsening psychopathology. The proposed training and research plans will develop the applicant’s program of research on the longitudinal interplay between psychopathology and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic treatment decreases the burden of bacterial diseases, but efficacy is often diminished when bacteria are in mixed microbial communities such as the microbiome. Lactic acid bacteria are a component of the microbiome; however, little is known about how these bacteria impact community physiology and how their growth is affected by small molecules from the community. The proposed study will determine the molecular mechanisms of how the growth of the lactic acid bacteria Lactiplantbacillus plantarum is coordinated and how this influences antibiotic sensitivities and community stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The skin is continually exposed to the inflammatory stresses of the outside world. Following transient inflammation, the long-lived epithelial stem cells that maintain this barrier can retain lasting epigenetic memories that markedly heighten future responses to stress. This proposal will explore how allergic type 2 inflammation in skin specifically influences the long-term functionality of epithelial stem cells, both locally within sites of inflammatory pathology and systemically across the skin and airway epithelia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our sense of hearing relies crucially on the development and function of hair cell stereocilia in the cochlea, which act as vital mechanosensory structures responsible for detecting sound. The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms that ultimately determine the size and shape of stereocilia. By understanding this critical process, this research opens avenues for developing novel therapeutic strategies to improve hearing health and enhance the lives of individuals impacted by hearing-related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lens injury promotes robust and extensive retinal ganglion cell (RGC) survival and axon regeneration following injury, providing a unique and biologically relevant neuro-repair mechanism in the central nervous system. The proposed project will identify lens injury-elicited molecular mechanisms for neuro-repair towards RGCs. The results of this project will provide new knowledge on core neurorepair gene programs that may be targeted for the treatment of central nervous system injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate how functional connectivity between networks that harbor early Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology are related to AD risk, longitudinal AD pathology accumulation, and age. Although the co-occurrence of Aβ and tau pathology underlie AD, the mechanisms by which early forms of these proteins interact across spatially distant brain regions to promote AD progression are not well understood. Functional network connectivity may underlie these remote interactions and this project will provide insight into mechanisms that drive regional vulnerability to early pathological protein accumulation in aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 6.5 million Americans over the age of 65 currently live with Alzheimer’s disease: a debilitating neurodegenerative disorder characterized by significant cognitive deficits. Research shows that up to 40% of dementia risk is due to modifiable risk factors, including deficient sleep and cardiovascular risk factors that exacerbate Cerebral Small Vessel Disease (CSVD). This project examines the mechanisms linking CSVD to sleep and sleep-dependent memory deficits related to Alzheimer’s disease, and lays the groundwork for advancement of behavioral interventions, refinement of screening, and development of public health recommendations for patients with disordered or deficient sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Autism is linked to differences in predictive coding. Competing empirically-supported hypotheses of this link are complicated by phenotypic heterogeneity within autism and potential dissociation of how neural activity maps onto behavior between autism and typical development, particularly in social contexts. These experiments use both neural and behavioral measures of temporal prediction to assess these competing models while accounting for both heterogeneity and dissociation, enabling clinicians to more effectively use skills-based approaches to help autistic individuals achieve their social and relational goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE β-cell dysfunction is one of the major characteristics of type II diabetes (T2D). MafA is an essential transcriptional regulator of β-cell biology, and is necessary for glucose sensing and insulin secretion, but it is often dysregulated in β-cells in animal models and people with T2D. In this proposal, I test whether MafA acetylation affects the β-cell functional response to obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid overdose crisis remains a critical public health threat and warrants an evidence-based approach to develop treatment and policy solutions. The proposed study will investigate whether a pharmacist-integrated model of medication treatment for opioid use disorder may increase primary care capacity for co-prescribing the overdose antidote, naloxone. The proposed training plan will provide the applicant with clinical trial methodological experience with the guidance of her sponsor and expert consultants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Processing visual input within its context is critical for cognition and perception and is altered in a number of neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. This higher-order component of visual processing requires aspects of distributed brain circuitry which may not develop fully until adulthood. This project aims to explore how top-down projections to visual cortex from higher brain regions develop during adolescence with the goal of elucidating core neurobiological processes in healthy and pathological visual development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injuries trigger complex secondary and chronic neuropathological effects, through neuroinflammatory activity and molecular changes at the spinal cord injury site, that can severely affect spinal cord regeneration and recovery. The proposed study will evaluate the use of multi-parametric MRI and PET imaging to characterize structural, functional, and molecular changes in spinal cord injuries over time, and identify biomarkers that relate to spinal cord injury severity and recovery progression. The multi-parametric imaging methods will be applied to evaluate the efficacy of novel spinal cord injury drug treatments and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ENIGMA-Addiction consortium was established to investigate the genomic and neurobiological bases of problematic substance use by combining existing genomic and brain imaging datasets. Its goal is to maximize the yield from existing datasets through very large data pooling efforts thereby providing statistical power for rigorous and reproducible analyses. The renewal of funding will permit further expansion of this pooled database as a unique resource for the scientific community and provide support for comprehensive investigation of psychiatric comorbidities and identification of sub-groups of problematic substance use with differing etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: This study will aim to exploit the liver’s ability to regenerate in order to reverse alcohol-induced liver damage common in alcoholic-associated liver disease (ALD) and alcohol-associated hepatitis (AH). Specifically, the study will determine whether preservation and/or supplementation of hepatic cardiolipin promotes liver regeneration in ALD/AH via multiple models (animal, in vitro, and human samples). Findings from this pre-clinical study will lead to the evaluation of the safety, dose tolerance, and efficacy of cardiolipin lipid vesicles and elamipretide as a treatment strategy for ALD/AH in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Oxidative stress arising from exposure to environmental agents is a common cause of DNA damage that must be resolved by base excision repair to avoid the development of human disease. The goal of this project is to establish how the scaffold protein x-ray repair cross-complementing 1 (XRCC1) facilitates the activity of DNA polymerase beta (pol ꞵ) at DNA damage located in chromatin. This project will provide technical and professional training by using a unique combination of complementary assays to investigate how oxidative DNA damage is repaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral epithelial dysplasia precedes head and neck cancer, presenting an ideal window for early treatment, yet there are limited diagnostic criteria used to predict which lesions will progress to cancer. The interaction between the immune system and the tumor greatly informs treatment response and tumor progression, therefore, this project will investigate the modulation of the immune response at the onset of cancer initiation. This work will describe how immune cells are co-opted in precancerous lesions to promote tumor survival, providing critical information into key therapeutic interception points that may restore anti-tumor immunity at earlier stages of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Flexible and protective withdrawal behaviors are essential for avoiding painful stimuli, but in pathological conditions people can become hypersensitive to pain or feel pain in response to otherwise innocuous sensory input. This proposal asks how properties of mechanosensory stimuli impact escape behavior and aims to understand how these signals may be integrated at the circuit level. This proposal will reveal potential mechanisms underlying behavioral flexibility in the context of escape and provide conserved insights for studying pain modulation at the cellular and circuit levels in analogous vertebrate systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study seeks to address the growing opioid epidemic by identifying novel therapeutic targets for treating opioid use disorder. Our preliminary studies have identified calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) producing neurons in the parabrachial nucleus as potential direct activators of the negative affective states associated with opioid withdrawal. In this study, we seek to establish this functional connection and understand how opioid taking and protracted withdrawal result in gene expression and epigenetic changes within this neuronal population to evaluate the feasibility of leveraging CGRP therapeutics for treating opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In an effort to develop new tools to study pain in the spinal cord, as well as a new chronic pain treatment, I will first use statistical genetics to identify families of neurons in the spinal cord that have a genetic risk of malfunctioning and causing chronic pain. As a strategy to selectively activate or shut off these neuron families, I will then use machine learning to find, and design, DNA sequences, called cis-regulatory elements, which are predicted by my models to drive gene expression in just these neuron families, in order to block pain signaling without causing off-target effects. Finally, I will experimentally validate that these cis-regulatory elements indeed have specific activity in mouse, and collaborators will do the same in macaque; cis-regulatory elements discovered or designed in this project will serve as a useful resource for functional pain experiments in animals, and potentially for a novel therapeutic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aerosolization, is an essential, yet poorly understood physiologic process, that is essential for the transmission and spread of Mycobacteria tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB) and the deadliest infectious disease worldwide. The goal of this proposal is to identify the specific genes and metabolic pathways that Mtb employs during its adaptive response to CO2 and nitrogen deprivation in the aerosol droplet environment. Identifying the key metabolic players during this adaptive response has the potential to reveal novel targets for therapeutics that block TB transmission and dramatically reduce its incidence and the global disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Abnormal GABAergic inhibitory neurotransmission in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) is implicated in the cognitive and emotional disturbances present in schizophrenia and mood disorders, among the leading causes of disability globally. Using multi-tiered in vivo and in vitro functional, structural, and computational methods, this project aims to characterize the as yet unknown properties of dendritic inhibition and determine how they can shape cortical activity in functionally-distinct medial and lateral PFC areas in primates. This will shed vitally needed insight on the mechanisms of differential susceptibility of these PFC areas to network disruption, potentially aiding diagnosis via electrophysiological correlates of cognitive-affective disorders and improving pharmacological and neuromodulation-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Beginning with the eruption of baby teeth, dental caries affects humans of all races, ages, and sexes. The proposed studies will elucidate the novel catalytic mechanism(s) of glucosyltransferases by which the dental caries etiological agent Streptococcus mutans (SM) synthesizes insoluble (a-1,3-linked) and soluble (a-1,6- linked) glucans. The results will define novel enzymatic mechanism(s) and lead to the development of new inhibitors to prevent SM’s acid generation, which initiates enamel erosion and dental caries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective treatment is an essential component of malaria case management. In the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), which accounts for 13% of all global malaria deaths, malaria control efforts are threatened by increasing reports of antimalarial drug resistance, including to artemisinin-based combination therapies, the current first-line and most effective treatment for Plasmodium falciparum. This proposal integrates genomic, epidemiological, and spatial approaches into a well-characterized 2015-2022 malaria longitudinal cohort study of children and adults to characterize the antimalarial drug resistance landscape in Kinshasa, the most populous province in the DRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hallucinations and other psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia are highly burdensome conditions for patients and society at large, and treatments for these symptoms are often ineffective or poorly tolerated. A necessary first step towards developing more selective biological interventions is to elucidate mechanisms of these symptoms at a neurobiological circuit level. Here, we test the predictions of a computational model of corticostriatal circuitry using translational experiments in humans and mice to clarify the circuit neurobiology of hallucinations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Many sepsis survivors are not educated on their diagnosis nor its implications for self-care after hospital discharge, leading to knowledge deficits that consequentially contribute to delayed follow-up care, poor health outcomes, and frequent rehospitalizations. The Surviving Sepsis Campaign calls for nurses and other clinicians to deliver patient education tailored to the specific needs of sepsis survivors; yet, research on sepsis patient education interventions is limited. By measuring the relationship of sepsis patient education quality as perceived by sepsis survivors to education and health outcome indicators, this study will inform future patient education interventions dedicated to reducing knowledge deficits and improving health outcomes among sepsis survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circuit mechanisms of reward-context learning, involved in complex exploration behaviors, remain unclear despite increasing health challenges in substance abuse and other mental disorders (e.g., attention disorders and cognitive decline). I propose to examine the role of rewards and reward expectation in exploration and memory formation using electrophysiology, intracranial stimulation, and animal pose tracking methods. Insights into how reward circuits and memory systems (e.g., the hippocampus) interact to form neural codes are critical for understanding complex behaviors and developing therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative An immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) in pancreatic cancer, one of the deadliest human malignancies, is known to be a major barrier to effective treatment. We propose to study how cellular interaction within the pancreatic TME through CCR1-IRG1 axis contributes to pancreatic carcinogenesis and explore the therapeutic potential of targeting IRG1, using both mouse models and patient derived organoids. Our study will not only provide critical insights into the immune suppressive function of CCR1-IRG1 axis in pancreatic cancer, thereby addressing a significant knowledge gap in the field, but also identify novel therapeutic approaches to effectively treating pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary cilia are signaling organelles present on nearly all stem and progenitor cells throughout the body that regulate cell fate, including the differentiation of preadipocytes into mature, fat storing adipocytes through adipogenesis. It is unclear how the cilium regulates this process, though recent discoveries highlight the only described ciliary G protein-coupled receptor drives adipogenesis in a cilia-dependent manner by increasing ciliary cAMP. This proposal will investigate the necessity and sufficiency of ciliary cAMP in the adipogenic process, as well as identify additional adipogenesis-modulating G protein-coupled receptors that localize to the preadipocyte cilium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is typically considered a disease of older adulthood, however the influence of modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors, beginning in childhood, significantly influence AD development later in life. Through a novel, multimodal approach, we aim to collect data related to brain development (cognitive, brain imaging), modifiable risk factors (physical activity, cardiorespiratory fitness) and non-modifiable risk factors (APOE-ε4 allele status) in order to understand early-life vulnerabilities that effect AD risk. Characterizing the development of AD-vulnerable brain systems, and how these risk factors influence them, could lead to new insights regarding early-life risk stratification and disease prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A majority of disease-associated genetic variants are located within the non coding region of the genome where the genetic regulatory code is poorly understood. To help inform us which variant is causal for a phenotypic disease of interest, it is imperative to learn the variant to function characterization of genetic variants to decipher the non coding regulatory code. This proposal will develop a novel deep learning model that can predict genetic variants impact on chromatin accessibility, which we use as a proxy for variant function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Crying is the only way infants can communicate their needs – unfortunately, maladaptive responses to infant sounds have been associated with neurological and hormonal pathologies impacting motherhood, such as those that lead to postpartum depression. Disentangling the neural circuitry that supports adaptive maternal responses is essential for supporting infant well-being and maternal mental health outcomes. In this proposal, I will take advantage of cutting-edge whole-brain imaging and genetic tools available in mice to uncover the brain- wide neural mechanisms that enhance the maternal response to auditory cues from their offspring, with the potential of identifying ways we can predict and intervene in cases where these responses may go awry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The classical subtype of PDAC expresses lineage specifying transcription factors that are important in normal development and cell fate determination. Although cell identity is tightly regulated by TFs, the transcriptional network that governs the classical subtype of PDAC has yet to be clearly defined and how these networks are redefined due to targeted therapies is unknown. This proposal aims to define the transcriptional networks created by lineage specifying transcription factors and how modulating oncogenic signaling alter these networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Poly-substance use (METH, opioids) has been shown to enhance neuronal damage and dramatically increase the risk of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND), creating a significant unmet medical challenge. Here we will use ex vivo models derived from induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) to determine whether silent HIV infections in the brain become reactivated in response to poly-substance exposure and dissect the intracellular signals responsible for HIV reactivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Over the last several years, the use of methamphetamine has increased markedly in the United States. Patients seeking treatment for methamphetamine use disorder describe experiencing cognitive deficits and, notably, also report an increased incidence of sleep disturbances, which also can lead to cognitive deficits independent of methamphetamine use. Addressing cognitive problems associated with methamphetamine-induced sleep disruptions may offer a novel treatment strategy to improving patient outcomes, including reducing the risk of relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The representational quality of episodic memory is diminished in older adulthood, but little is known about the neurocognitive mechanisms that underlie age-related declines in memory specificity nor individual variations in these declines. The proposed project aims to leverage scalp electrophysiological recordings and computational modeling at the individual-subject level as non-cognitively impaired young and older adults complete mnemonic similarity recognition tasks. These methods will enable us to investigate the neural corrrelates and cognitive processes that underlie variations in the representational quality of episodic memories within and across young and older adults, paving the way for future non-invasive methods of measuring memory quality and predicting memory loss associated with aging and neurocognitive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular dysfunction, such as hypertension or atherosclerosis, is a leading cause of death in the United States and linked to heavy drinking behaviors. However, the acute effects of alcohol on vascular functioning are subtle and clouded by chronic cardiovascular loads such as frequent heavy drinking, drug-drug interactions (such as alcohol/cannabis co-use), and chronic stress. This application proposes five training goals and three research aims to launch a unique line of independent research that seeks early signs of vascular dysfunction to reduce alcohol-related cardiovascular disease prevalence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative UNC-6/Netrin plays vital roles in the directing of neuronal axons to their target cells, as well as in the formation of synapses, the connections between neurons that permit communication between them. It is unknown, though, whether the neurons that express unc-6/Netrin for the purpose of axon pathfinding are the same as those that express unc-6/Netrin to facilitate synapse formation. I propose to use the roundworm C. elegans to determine whether these two functions are separable and to characterize neuron-specific control of unc-6/Netrin expression, which may help me to elucidate the relative contribution of the lack of each of these functions in unc-6/Netrin-associated neurodevelopmental diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allosteric regulation of enzymes, which underpins many metabolic processes, can be perturbed by genetic mutations, contributing to metabolic re-programming in cancer and other diseases. The broadly evolutionarily conserved enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is allosterically regulated by many small molecules to control glycolytic flux in the cell, but the evolution and molecular mechanism of this regulation is poorly understood. We propose to characterize the complex combinatorial allosteric mechanism of PFK-1 towards the rational design of powerful therapeutics to target this essential enzyme in metabolic diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child maltreatment is a prevalent and costly public health issue associated with many negative outcomes, though the pathway through which these negative outcomes occur is not well understood. This application will examine the effects of child maltreatment on brain development as a potential pathway to negative outcomes. Results will guide future intervention and treatment efforts for individuals with a history of child maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis (UC), a chronic disease that is characterized by diffuse inflammation of the colonic and rectal mucosa, is rising globally. Current medications for UC include antibiotics, corticosteroids, and biological drugs, which can have deleterious off-target effects, contributing to increased susceptibility to severe infections and chronic immunosuppression. Building from our recent work documenting that dietary panaxynol, a bioactive component of American Ginseng, can mitigate colitis, I am proposing to examine immune, microbial and metabolite signatures to establish the potential mechanisms mediating panaxynol’s benefits in colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will elucidate the molecular mechanisms behind the development of varicose veins by leveraging the recent advances in single-cell sequencing technologies and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). Transcriptomic changes at the single cell level in varicose veins will allow us to identify key regulators effecting the different components of the varicose vein and their effects on EC-SMC crosstalk. Similarly, utilizing iPSCs to recapitulate the disease phenotype of varicose veins in vitro to screen for drugs will likely provide new insight into the pathogenesis of VV and benefit the development of therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive and neuropsychiatric disorders have been linked to aberrant alternative splicing of various ion channels. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The androgen receptor (AR) plays a major role in transcriptional regulation and cell signaling in normal prostate cells, and is often dysregulated in most prostate cancers (PCa’s), thus AR is targeted for therapeutic treatment in PCa. Recent and emerging experimental data from the Bah-Kotula lab research collaboration has unveiled that Abl kinase-Interactor 1 (ABI1), a multi-isoform and scaffolding cytoskeletal adaptor protein, binds to AR and to chromatin in order to regular gene expression. However, the molecular underpinnings of this critical ternary interaction remain unknown; thus, I will elucidate the biophysical and structural basis governing the AR-ABI1- DNA axis, setting the stage for the development of novel therapeutics against PCa.
