IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a pervasive and increasingly common form of dementia with no current effective treatment options and thus, a critical need exists to understand how various cell types and genetic variants are implicated in the disease. Microglia have been associated with altered, pro-inflammatory phenotypes in AD, and defects in the fractalkine receptor, which is the primary axis for communication with neurons to attenuate the inflammatory response, have been associated with AD onset and progression. In this proposal, my goal is to utilize a human cellular model to elucidate the effects upon microglia with an AD-associated fractalkine receptor gene variant, both alone and in co-culture with neurons, to determine whether this variant may mediate neurodegenerative phenotypes and serve as a target for future AD intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Juliet King 1 PROJECT NARRATIVE Cleft lip and cleft palate (CL/P) are among the most prevalent birth defects globally, and especially threaten the wellbeing of families in countries with limited access to care. CL/P occurs when the oral and nasal passages fail to separate during fetal development, and our lab has found that cell adhesion plays a critical role in this process. This proposal will determine the molecular players and tissue layer-specific signaling that guides this process with the goal to improve future gene therapy techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research project aims to better understand how lymphatic flow is affected in patients with lymphedema and how surgical interventions like lymphaticovenous anastomoses (LVA) can improve their condition. By studying the mechanics of lymphatic vessels and how they adapt to different treatments, we hope to find more effective ways to treat lymphedema and improve the lives of millions of people worldwide who suffer from this condition. Ultimately, our research has the potential to contribute to better healthcare outcomes and enhance the quality of life for those affected by lymphedema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current proposal seeks to understand why metformin inhibits adaptations to aerobic exercise training in healthy, aged individuals. The project proposes that metformin negatively impacts calcium handling in skeletal muscle, which contributes to the inhibition of adaptations to aerobic exercise. Understanding these mechanisms could help determine strategies to maintain the positive effects of aerobic exercise training in healthy aging subjects, who may benefit from metformin treatment and, more importantly, who may not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This proposal aims to elucidate the timeline of dopaminergic neuron specification and maturation during homeostasis and injury. Additionally, the research in this proposal will reveal genes that promote the creation of neurons that produce dopamine, a key signal in the nervous system. Uncovering and characterizing genes important for dopaminergic neuron regeneration using planarian flatworms could lead to a better understanding of successful brain regeneration and could lead to improvements in creating dopamine-producing neurons from stem cells for human therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to characterize the transcriptional, epigenetic and functional changes that intestinal epithelial stem cells undergo during and after exposure to inflammatory granulomas that are generated during parasitic helminth infection. In the short term, the data generated in this study will reveal whether intestinal stem cells maintain an epigenetic memory of inflammation and will enable the identification of the signaling pathways and molecular regulators implicated in this process. In the long term, this work will improve our understanding of how inflammation impacts intestinal stem cells’ function and enhance our knowledge of their role in inflammation- driven diseases such as Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Both mitochondrial and blood brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction have been independently associated with neuropsychiatric illness. Based on our recent publications and compelling preliminary data, we propose that in a relatively common genetic cause of neuropsychiatric illness, mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to BBB dysfunction and presents a novel therapeutic target. If our hypothesis is correct, this finding can shift paradigms for inflammatory influences on brain development and function based on the synergistic influences of relatively subtle structural and energetic weaknesses in the BBB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction and neuroinflammation are major hallmarks of brain aging and age-related neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease, and although abnormal mitochondrial function appears to precede inflammation, it remains unclear if or how mitochondrial dysfunction initiates inflammation in brain aging and Alzheimer's disease. This project will explore the potential role of mitochondria-derived double-stranded RNA, which may be released due to mitochondrial dysfunction, in activating inflammatory signaling as an early driver of age/Alzheimer’s disease-related neuroinflammation. The results may provide insight into the biology of brain aging and the development of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This research project examines the role of ECM-mediated inter-tissue adhesion in early spinal column development. The project seeks to understand how the neural tube adheres to the flanking mesoderm with a medial-lateral stress gradient while simultaneously sliding posteriorly relative to the mesoderm. The proposed research utilizes a unique combination of live imaging, spatially and temporally controlled genetic manipulation and a new in vivo single molecule spectroscopy and machine learning protocol to elucidate the molecular, cellular and tissue level mechanisms that orchestrate early development of the spinal column.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) remains a disease with a dismal prognosis and limited therapeutic options. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorder affects 8.5% of the United States population and stressful life experiences can promote relapse, resulting in re-initiation of drug taking in abstinent individuals. This proposal seeks to expand our understanding of the mechanism by which the stress hormone, corticosterone, activates the endocannabinoid signaling system and promotes drug seeking. Moreover, this study will advance an understanding of the mechanisms through which stress guides behavior under healthy and pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OI patients experience brittle bone and recurrent fractures due to mutations impacting type I collagen production, modification, or trafficking. Recent work has identified that misfolded type I collagen accumulates in the ER and causes ER stress in certain individuals with OI -- it is not known if this phenomenon is common to all forms of OI or if the process interferes with bone active therapeutics used to treat OI. This proposal will establish that ER stress as a clinically important, genotype dependent feature of OI and establish preclinical data for a new precision strategy to treat OI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Positive childhood experiences prevent and mitigate the effects of adverse childhood experiences and lead to improved adult health outcomes. The HOPE framework is a relationship-based approach which transforms interactions between providers and parents, opening up dialogue to focus on a family’s assets and strengths, bringing in family agency and ultimately leading to an alignment of the agency’s goals and family’s priorities. The goal of the HOPE Regional Satellite Meetings is to catalyze and support organizational transformation and adoption of HOPE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increased mental health problems are present in developmental language disorder (OLD) and emotion regulation difficulties are one potential contributor to their development. This project will investigate the emotion regulation of children with OLD in comparison to children with typical development during both linguistically demanding and domain-general tasks using self-report, behavioral, and physiological indicators. The project will contribute to fundamental knowledge about the ER functioning of children with OLD, inform the multimethod assessment of ER in populations with language deficits, support early identification of emotional problems in children with OLD, and possibly allow for earlier targeted interventions to prevent and mitigate future mental health problems and/or disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorder-containing protein domains inherently have a dynamic nature and play important roles in numerous physiological processes as well as pathological states. In this work, I propose an innovative workflow for the high-throughput identification and optimization of modulators for two distinct, dynamic transcriptional coactivator domains, KIX and HEAT, the results of which will directly contribute the cancer therapeutics. This workflow will be pivotal for the successful targeting of conformationally dynamic proteins, a class of proteins that is known to contribute to numerous diseases but is largely considered to be ‘undruggable’.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to predict the impact of oxidative stress on human proteins via a novel deep learning methodology. The deep learning approach involves encoding atomic protein geometry using a graph transformer-based autoencoder, enabling the biochemical information contained within known protein structures to be applied to tasks with limited training examples. Through this project, we will uncover functional insights into aging-related ailments, identify potential drug targets, and validate the computational findings through collaboration with an experimental lab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Craniofacial birth defects commonly arise due to altered patterning of the cranial neural crest-derived cells that form the jaw skeleton and connective tissues. This project investigates two novel jaw-specific mechanisms that regulate the proportion of skeletal and connective tissue cell types in the developing face. Findings from these studies will inform how altered Hedgehog signaling and chromatin accessibility contribute to a variety of birth defects affecting the jaw.

PHR: Narrative Frontotemporal dementia is the second most common presenile dementia but the underlying pathogenic mechanisms remain largely unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite mounting genomic and transcriptomic evidence linking alternative splicing to autism spectrum disorder (ASD), the underlying molecular mechanisms remain elusive. This project employs single nucleus long-read sequencing to identify, quantify, and localize full-length isoforms into cell populations of the postnatal prefrontal cortex, in individuals with and without a diagnosis of idiopathic ASD. Gaining insight into how brain-expressed isoforms contribute to cell types, interact in biological pathways, and are dysregulated in the context of ASD, will further our mechanistic understanding of brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone metastasis is an incurable condition, and current standard of care disrupts estrogen signaling in the bone microenvironment leading to bone-related morbidity, which if left untreated may accelerate metastasis. This proposal aims to investigate the use of a novel endocrine therapy called Elacestrant which may lessen destruction of the bone microenvironment while still eliminating metastatic cells, due to context-dependent selective ER agonist/antagonist activity. The proposed study will expand the knowledge of new-generation endocrine therapies in the context of cancer and the cancer microenvironment, as well as yield clinically actionable data which may be rapidly translated to patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Crohn’s disease is a chronic and deadly gastrointestinal inflammatory disorder with no cure, and it continues to impose substantial burdens on patients and healthcare systems globally. Through this research proposal, we aim to define the intricate role of Myosin 5b in governing microvilli assembly and its potential implications on intestinal epithelial susceptibility to Crohn’s disease associated pathobionts. The findings from this study have the potential to provide a new understanding of Crohn's disease, potentially identifying novel biomarkers to enable early diagnosis and targeted therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GCN2 control nonderepressible 2 (GCN2) is a highly conserved amino acid sensor that enables cells to respond to nutrient stress by modulating mRNA translation. While the GCN2-eIF2 pathway is known to play a critical role in human developmental disorders and endothelial cell dysfunction, the importance of mRNA translation in the pathogenesis of GCN2-related disorders is unknown. Therefore, I will combine human induced pluripotent stem cell technology with high throughput translatome analysis to uncover novel GCN2 targets that will provide insight into new candidates for treating endothelial-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular replication requires exquisite spatial control of cell contents, especially genetic information. This project examines new ideas about how certain protein sequences can result in concentration of key cellular components together as a necessary step for successful cell replication. Better understanding of the physical mechanisms of cellular replication will help develop treatments for disorders caused by mutations in these proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE) Cachexia involves the involuntary loss of weight due to the combination of reduced food intake and hyperactive catabolism in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue and is highly prevalent in solid malignancies. Despite almost 50% of cancer patients experiencing features of cachexia and its association with increased morbidities and mortality, there are currently no approved treatments for cancer-associated cachexia. This proposal will identify how tumor genetics, an intact immune system, and diet promote cachexia, providing key insight into the mechanisms that drive cachexia to be exploited by future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative To advance research on non-opioid analgesic therapeutics, this project will investigate the non-intoxicating, FDA-approved cannabis terpene, myrcene, and its effects on pain hypersensitivity and negative affective states associated with a mouse model of chronic neuropathic pain. This proposal will determine the extent myrcene engages the endocannabinoid system in areas of the brain implicated in the descending modulation of pain. The information gained from this study will clarify the relationship between terpenes and endocannabinoids and their role in chronic pain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it investigates prevalence of, root causes of, and an intervention to address an under-studied medical barrier to family planning use: when providers deny a preferred method of family planning with an illegitimate or inappropriate medical rationale. Preventing the application of inappropriate medical contraindications would improve person-centeredness of family planning services and has the potential to reduce contraceptive discontinuation due to dissatisfaction with a non- preferred family planning method. This project leverages innovative and rigorous data from an NIH-funded parent study - including mystery client observations and a cluster randomized design - and implements a mixed-methods approach to address a challenging, impactful, and understudied barrier to contraceptive access in the Global South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Binding Problem asks how the diverse contents of awareness are unified, a cortical process that is fundamental to understanding healthy and disrupted cognition in humans. This study will test if bursts of high- frequency cortical oscillations (i.e., ‘ripples’) possess the properties crucial to a possible role in binding. If successful, this work will lay the foundation to study neural binding in the human cortex, thereby facilitating the investigation of how information processing is disrupted in many form of neuropsychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinoids, the active forms of vitamin A, have significant impacts on human health, influencing vision, immunity, metabolism, embryonic development, reproduction, and cell differentiation. They also serve as crucial therapeutics for cancers, skin and visual diseases, and are promising therapeutic approaches for treating neurological, and metabolic disorders. The primary aim of the 7th International Conference on Retinoids FASEB SRC is to facilitate scientific exchange and collaborations in fundamental research and clinical applications of retinoids for disease prevention and treatment, while offering training opportunities for newcomers and early- stage investigators in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to illuminate the cardiogenic cellular hierarchy and the gene regulatory networks that determine the origins and fates of Juxta-Cardiac Field (JCF) cardiovascular progenitor cells during heart development. Results from these studies will yield new insights into how disrupted cardiovascular regulatory networks lead to congenital heart disease and how they may be modified to develop treatments to improve patient outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual violence (SV), trauma symptoms, alcohol use, and intimate partner violence (IPV) are all major public health issues that disproportionately affect bisexual women (BiW). This project tests a model in which receipt of intimate partners’ negative reactions in response to SV disclosure is associated with increased trauma symptoms, which exacerbate alcohol use that, in turn, heightens risk for IPV victimization. The role of minority stress in exacerbating trauma symptoms, alcohol use, and, ultimately, IPV victimization is examined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is a rapidly growing epidemic with no FDA approved treatments and is a significant global health and economic burden. Mitochondria play an essential role in restricting progression of steatotic liver disease to steatohepatitis (MASH) by acting as a relief valve for excess lipid. In this proposal, I will identify the role and regulation of SLC25a25, a mitochondrial solute carrier, in the onset and progression of MASH with the goal of identifying a novel therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, over six million Americans are living with Alzheimer's disease (AD), and by 2050 this number is projected to rise to nearly 13 million if no disease-modifying treatments are discovered. The lack of successful therapeutic options can be attributed to the complexity of AD and the limited understanding of the genetic and neuronal mechanisms that underly AD. I performed genetic mapping of brain-composition traits in a panel of genetically diverse mice that model human AD to identify Lrfn2 as a gene that modifies AD-related cortical neurodegeneration, and in the proposed project I will determine if Lrfn2 is a genuine mediator of resilience to AD and is a valid target for development of effective treatments for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Ultrasound imaging, also known as ultrasonography, is the most widespread and accepted clinical imaging modality and offers diagnostic information throughout the human lifespan, starting prebirth. While its dynamic and scholarly research community continually improves image quality, it also develops new ways to benefit from this exciting modality that involves in-vivo biomedical ultrasound applications. This meeting will bring together scientists and trainees from a wide range of backgrounds to discuss and further ultrasonography so that those in need can benefit from lung ultrasound, virtual biopsies, immunotherapy and more, and will soon be seeing wearable ultrasound to understand better how daily activities, ailments, and disorders impact our bodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) is a global health pandemic that results from impaired insulin secretion, peripheral insulin resistance, obesity, overnutrition, lack of physical activity, and aging. However, genetic and physiologic data suggest that inadequate insulin secretion from the pancreatic beta () cell is the chief determinant predicting progression from insulin resistance to overt T2D. The goal of this research is to understand the mechanistic interplay between the process of store operated calcium entry (SOCE) and estrogen signaling in the  cell and will test the hypothesis that decreased SOCE leads to reduced G Protein-Coupled Estrogen Receptor signaling and loss of β cell identity and function, thereby contributing to the pathophysiology of T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative People with migraine and other neurological diseases often experience disabling discomfort from flickering light. This discomfort may be due to a mis-match in the brain between sensory expectation and experience. To test this idea, we will use personal light-logger devices to measure the visual environment of people with and without migraine, and then test predictions regarding the perception and brain responses to flicker found for these two groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR)-T cell immunotherapy has shown impressive response rates in B cell malignancies; however, limitations to access and failure of many patients to reach complete response call for therapeutic enhancement. Although the causes for CAR-T cell failure are multiple and still emerging, the time necessary to manufacture CAR-T cells seems to directly correlate with quality: the longer the manufacturing time, the worse performance of CAR-T cells once infused into the patient. We hypothesize that platforms enabling in vivo engineering of CAR-T cells will enhance CAR-T cell quality and efficacy with less expense and greater patient access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are central hubs of cellular metabolism, and have been implicated in genetic diseases affecting 1 in 5,000 people, as well as some of the most common diseases that contribute to human suffering such as cancer and heart failure. Targeting mitochondrial bioenergetics holds major therapeutic potential for these patients, and the mitochondrial acyl carrier protein is an attractive target that sits at a major intersection in mitochondrial bioenergetics. This proposal will define how the mitochondrial acyl carrier protein is regulated by upstream metabolism, providing information imperative to the development of future therapeutics controlling the mitochondrial acyl carrier protein to target mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronically activated, pro-inflammatory macrophages are believed to be critical determinants of disease progression in atherosclerosis. I have identified the immunomodulatory receptor Paired immunoglobulin-like receptor B (PirB) as a novel regulator of macrophage pro-inflammatory phenotype through its ability to regulate non-canonical autophagy and mitochondrial stress. Understanding the mechanism by which PirB coordinates these two crucial pathways to dampen inflammation may reveal new therapeutic targets to treat arterial inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Synapse specificity describes the process by which neurons must form the correct type of synapses with the correct synaptic partners. Results of this proposal will investigate the molecular mechanisms of how two synapse specificity molecules work together to mediate specific synapse formation. This basic research has clinical relevance because disruption of synapse specificity is thought to underlie many diseases, and mutations in one of the molecules I will study, Kirrel3, are associated with Autism spectrum disorders and intellectual disability.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Climate change is the most significant event of our time, and will result in environmental pressures that will drive rapid organismal adaptation to novel environmental conditions, or in the absence of the capacity to adapt, extinction. I will study the Drosophila species on the tropical island of São Tomé to understand the relationship between underlying genetics and thermal tolerance and thermal preference. My work will illuminate the evolutionary mechanisms that permit organismal adaptations to a changing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative As incidences of digestive diseases continue to rise, there remains an urgent need to discover new therapeutic targets to alleviate the devastating effects of chronic colitis. Although the intestinal microbial composition is known to modulate gut health, the precise mechanism by which the gut microbiome influences host immunity to exacerbate chronic inflammatory bowel diseases remain largely unknown. In this application, we propose to study how the microbiome and circadian clock cooperate to enhance mucosal immunity and protect the host against colitis, thereby generating candidate targets that may ultimately aid in the design of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants in the protein LOXL1 can alter individual risk for developing pseudoexfoliation glaucoma, a blinding disease that affects more than 10 million individuals worldwide. This project seeks to determine how these genetic variants alter the structure and function of LOXL1. Successful completion of this project will provide a better understanding of how LOXL1 variants contribute to pseudoexfoliation glaucoma and thereby provide important groundwork for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, SARS-CoV-2 has infected more than 16 million children and adolescents, who are undergoing critical periods of brain development and might be particularly susceptible to the neuroinflammation associated with COVID-19. However, the extent to which these inflammatory effects during the acute illness phase impact adolescent brain structure and function, and consequently cognitive abilities and risk for mental illness, remains unknown. A better understanding of these neurological effects will provide knowledge to identify adolescents most at risk for poor psychological health and cognitive deficits and the potential for early intervention through cognitive training or mental health therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ebola virus (EBOV) and Marburg virus (MARV) cause fulminant disease in humans with alarmingly high fatality rates. Given the prevalence of gastrointestinal symptoms associated with Ebola virus diseases (EVD) and Marburg virus disease (MVD) presentation, the study of EBOV and MARV infection in intestinal cells is of clear clinical relevance and importance. The goal of this proposal is to study the mechanisms by which EBOV and MARV infections cause gastrointestinal manifestations, particularly intestinal diarrhea, using novel infection platforms based on induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC)-derived human intestinal organoids and their ability to recapitulate intestinal filovirus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Androgens are a known driver of aggressive prostate cancer, and our findings support that vitamin D deficiency leads to elevated androgens in the prostate tissue of African American men. We further identified megalin as an endocytic receptor expressed in the prostate, regulated by vitamin D, as importing circulating testosterone. Here we propose to examine vitamin D deficiency and megalin in aggressive prostate cancer and the consequences of vitamin D deficiency on prostate hormone homeostasis in patient-derived models, patient specimens, and mouse models.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the clear benefits of medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) for people with HIV and OUD, little is known about which specific form of MOUD is more beneficial to brain health in people with HIV. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lead (Pb) is an important public health threat, and exposure to Pb has been shown to increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes among African Americans, who also experience the detrimental health impacts of racial and gender discrimination. Racial health disparities in maternal mortality and morbidity persist across socioeconomic strata and extent of educational attainment; thus, a more robust understanding of root-causes of maternal health disparities are essential to improving health outcomes for women in minoritized racial groups. Through providing insight into the impact of Pb on preterm birth – specifically in the context of structural racism – this study will create actionable solutions that can be directly applied to patient care through community engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Huntington’s disease (HD) is an inherited, neurodegenerative disorder that debilitates individuals due to uncontrolled movement, changes in personality and loss of cognition. Astrocytes, the guardians of the brain, survey and nourish brain cells and have received growing attention due to their involvement in neurodegenerative pathologies. Research proposed here on HD astrocytes during development and disease progression is imperative to the field to inform efficient disease modifying therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative How apicomplexan parasites control highly divergent cell division is not well understood, but it is clear that the proper execution of the cell cycle program is critical to parasite numbers in the host and associated disease. In this proposal, we will investigate the molecular basis for cell cycle control in Toxoplasma gondii. Some of the essential factors identified in our studies are shared by other related pathogens, such as Plasmodium falciparum, which causes malaria and, therefore, has a broader impact on the field of studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative: The sense of taste plays a vital role in our survival, enabling us to discern nutrients and toxins in our surroundings. Chemotherapy-induced taste dysfunction can lead to malnutrition and a reduced quality of life, underscoring the urgency of comprehending its causes and finding effective remedies for these adverse effects. This proposal aims to investigate the impact of a common chemotherapeutic, cyclophosphamide, on gustatory neurons to shed light on the underlying mechanisms of chemotherapy-induced taste dysfunction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs) are often promoted in low- and middle-income countries, yet qualitative studies suggest that LARC promotion can inhibit reproductive autonomy through overzealous encouragement for uptake and barriers to removal, thereby impacting public health and human rights. This mixed-methods study will use secondary data collected as part of the Postpartum Intrauterine Device (IUD) Study in Tanzania and Nepal to examine if and how a postpartum IUD intervention impacted women’s experiences with autonomy in contraceptive decision-making and IUD discontinuation. The proposed aims align with NICHD’s strategic goal of “setting the foundation for healthy pregnancies and lifelong wellness” and can be used to inform future family planning programs that aim to increase contraceptive access and support reproductive autonomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cardiovascular system is vital for the growth and healing of wounds, playing a crucial role in overall well- being. This proposal utilizes a multidisciplinary approach to investigate the activation mechanism and modulation of the Tie2 receptor, an essential membrane protein responsible for creating tight cell-cell junctions at the endothelial monolayer that lines the blood vessels. The results of this study will provide a more complete picture of the regulation of Tie2 on the structural level to improve our understanding of Tie2 biology and provide a platform to investigate the dysregulation of Tie2 in human vasculature diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Estuaries are dynamic interfaces between the marine and terrestrial environments and estuarine sediments support a tremendous diversity of microorganisms which interact by expression of chemical signals or natural products. Microbial natural products have been valuable sources of therapeutic agents, and there remains a need for new biologically active compounds to study and treat drug-resistant cancers and infectious diseases. The use of in situ sampling methods paired with advanced mass spectrometric analysis will facilitate an unprecedented metabolomic study of estuarine sediment communities and identification of biologically active natural products with potential for human disease treatment and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 37 million people in the United States have diabetes. Despite many medications for diabetes, the number of deaths resulting from coronary vascular complications, including coronary microvascular disease, is still high among patients with diabetes. This study is designed to identify the cellular defects that cause the abnormalities of small coronary arteries in diabetic patients and to develop new therapeutic approaches for coronary endothelial dysfunction in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this study is to investigate the culturally-specific storytelling practices and styles of bilingual Latinx children with and without Developmental Language Disorder (DLD). We will document the storytelling practices and styles bilingual children with DLD participate in at home and in their communities. Lastly, we will compare their performance on narratives using extant White, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD) measures with culturally-relevant measures that arise from the data, so that speech-language pathologists may optimize assessment for this historically underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Accurately assessing obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) severity is essential to improving patient care. In this proposal, we will develop a mathematical model to provide a detailed clinical representation of OSA at various target locations in the body, which will allow for the assessment of tissue hypoxia burden and daytime sleepiness as a potential alternative indicator of severity and serve as an important step in my training in clinically-relevant computational research.The clinically deployable model and resulting pool of data, which will be obtained from simulated cases of OSA and a re-analysis of existing polysomnography studies, will be invaluable to furthering the clinical understanding of OSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Quiescent cancer cells are a source of drug resistance as they evade chemotherapeutic treatments targeted at cycling cells and retain their ability to proliferate in the future, whereas senescent cancer cells are tumor- suppressive as they limit the proliferation of damaged cells and recruit the immune system. The proposed research will investigate how cells transit between quiescence and senescence and will determine the mechanism by which quiescent cells permanently lose their ability to proliferate, thus becoming senescent. Quiescent and senescent cells arise side-by-side following chemotherapeutic treatment, thus, a mechanistic understanding of how cells choose between these fates would aid in the development of more targeted and effective chemotherapy treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The assembly and disassembly of CTD-mediated transcription factory and the molecular interactions that regulate this process are poorly understood. Dysregulation of transcription is associated with cancer, diabetes, obesity, autoimmunity, neurological disorders, and cardiovascular diseases. In this proposal, I will focus on two regulators of transcription; phosphorylation of CTD from fungi living in extreme environment and their cis-trans prolyl isomerization by the PPIase Ess1, and how these modifications influence the LLPS of the CTD in vitro and at the atomic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sunscreens that prevent UVR induced DNA damage are imperative for human health and protection against melanoma. This project will investigate the function of gadusol, a newly discovered vertebrate sunscreen. Our study will provide insight into the developmental mechanisms and evolutionary origin of this sunscreen, which could lead to the production of effective and environmentally safe sunscreens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of the temporomandibular joint of the jaw are a common source of chronic pain. This proposal uses complementary zebrafish and mouse models to investigate the role of LGRs, which potentiate Wnt signaling, in maintaining and controlling differentiation of stem cells that give rise to diverse jaw joint connective tissues. Knowledge gained from these studies will inform future studies aimed at repairing and restoring damaged connective tissues in temporomandibular joint disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis of cancer cells from the bone to the lung is responsible for the majority of osteosarcoma patient deaths, but how this process happens is not completely understood. Platelets are known to facilitate metastasis of other cancers, and studies have shown that cancer progression can affect megakaryocytes (platelet producing cells) but specific interactions between osteosarcoma cells, megakaryocytes, and platelets have not been established. This proposal focuses on examining how interactions between osteosarcoma cells and megakaryocytes in the bone marrow influence how megakaryocytes make platelets, alter the function of those platelets, and promote osteosarcoma metastasis to the lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis is the most used illicit drug among adolescents, which is concerning given that adolescents undergo considerable brain and behavioral development—processes that may be disrupted by cannabis leading to long- lasting consequences. This proposal will investigate microglia as a mechanism underlying cannabis-induced cognitive dysfunction in adulthood that we have previously reported following adolescent vaporized cannabis use. These findings will provide important insight into the biological targets of vaporized cannabis during adolescence, and the mechanisms through which they mediate long-term neurocognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zebrafish regenerate amputated fins to their original size and shape, as controlled by fibroblast-lineage cells. The applicant’s proposed fellowship research would investigate how these cells transition between previously undescribed cell states to slow down and stop regeneration as the original organ size is reached. Understanding such mechanisms that trigger and sustain pro-growth cell states could enhance wound healing and tissue regenerative medicine in humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mean paternal age in the United States has been increasing for the past 40 years. At the same time, there is increasing evidence that advanced paternal age correlates with negative effects for offspring. The goal of this project is to use clonal analysis in the zebrafish testis to expand our understanding of the biological mechanisms of male fertility across the lifespan, with particular attention paid to the Paternal Age Effect (PAE) disorders that cause severe developmental abnormalities in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alphaviruses like Sindbis (SINV) and chikungunya (CHIKV) virus, can cause encephalitis by crossing the blood- brain barrier, likely via infection of the brain microvascular endothelial cells that make up the barrier. Seminal work in the field has identified residues in the SINV and CHIKV E2 glycoproteins that are critical for neuroinvasion in vivo, while additional work has separately identified host receptors that interact with SINV and CHIKV E2. We expand upon these findings by characterizing the relationship between these E2 residues and known E2 interactors at the blood-brain barrier, thus laying the groundwork for novel treatments against the increasing threat of a large scale CHIKV outbreak.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity-associated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a highly lethal cancer that is a rising and challenging problem and in dire need of safer and more effective treatments. I hypothesize that the inhibition of cytochrome P450 family 8 subfamily B member 1 (CYP8B1), an enzyme expressed only in the liver, will significantly reduce formation of cholic acid (CA), the 12α-hydroxylated (12α-OH) primary bile (BA), and consequently, drastically decrease the ratio of 12α-OH to non-12α-OH BAs and the levels of deoxycholic acid, a secondary BA derived from CA by gut microbiota, thereby suppressing obesity-associated HCC development. I will determine the role of CYP8B1 in an obesity-associated HCC mouse model and develop novel CYP8B1 inhibitors as potential drug candidates for the treatment of obesity-associated HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep problems are prevalent in individuals with neurodevelopmental conditions, such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), which can have deleterious effects on brain development and behavioral outcomes. The proposed studies will longitudinally examine the impacts of infant sleep disturbances on brain connectivity and developmental trajectories in both typical and atypical development. These findings will inform the utility of distinct sleep metrics as an early biomarker for altered neurodevelopment, leading to earlier detection and interventions for neurodevelopmental conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) regenerate all blood cells throughout life, but their function declines with age. This proposed research will investigate the role of translation fidelity in promoting protein homeostasis, HSC fitness, and longevity during aging. Investigating the role of translation fidelity in HSC function and longevity is critical for developing new therapeutic targets that mitigate age-associated functional declines of HSCs and to enhance the regenerative capacity of stem cells in older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants and young children amass a vocabulary at a remarkable pace and rates of growth between 2 and 3 years of age predict important future outcomes. Research on vocabulary development has largely focused on the cognitive processes underlying how young children learn new words, but we know little about how young children retain newly learned words and integrate them into their lexicon. We propose two experiments using functional magnetic neuroimaging analysis to examine the contribution of the hippocampus, anterior medial temporal lobe and medial prefrontal cortex to the retention and generalization of newly learned words, and general vocabulary extension in toddlers ages 25 to 35 months of age, thereby building a more comprehensive theory of vocabulary development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Male infertility is a highly prevalent yet poorly understood condition that clinically manifests in combination with poor somatic health, especially in terms of elevated cancer risks for affected males and their families. This proposal will use high-depth DNA sequencing to explore novel relationships between germline and somatic mutagenesis, reduced fertility, and poor somatic health. The results obtained from this proposal will guide future research efforts to elucidate the biological, genetic, and cellular mechanisms underlying the etiology of male infertility and its associations with reduced health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative As the most common genetic developmental disorder that leads to intellectual disability, people with Down syndrome have several health challenges that impact their quality of life. This application requests funding to cover travel expenses of American-based junior investigators, postdoctoral fellows and graduate students to attend the Fifth International conference of the Trisomy 21 Research Society (T21RS). This conference will lead to fruitful discussions and novel collaborations that are essential to define the future of DS research. The theme of our meeting will be Promoting Research Experience in Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The recent surge in the use of the highly-potent synthetic opioid fentanyl has exacerbated the opioid epidemic and underscores a significant public health crisis. A potential therapeutic target for opioid use disorder lies in cannabinoid receptors, which are co-expressed with opiate receptors in the brain's reward centers and modulate opiate-associated behaviors. This proposal aims to use chemical biology to investigate cannabinoid- opiate interactions, which will pave the way for new therapeutic strategies in the fight against the intensifying opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Complex, black-box machine learning (ML) models have become standard tools in biomedical inquiry and clinical medicine, and their opaque nature and consequent lack of interpretability gave rise to transformative explainable AI (XAI) techniques. However, due to fundamental limitations, current XAI techniques provide only a partial explanation of inner workings of clinical ML models. This project aims to address these challenges by developing novel general XAI frameworks for medically relevant and computationally rigorous interpretation of clinical AI models and applying them to skin disease as an example.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) suffer from severe acute and chronic pain, the exact causes of which are unknown. We will determine whether free heme drives steady state pain and whether the cytokine TNFα drives acute vaso-occlusive episodic pain by sensitizing sensory neurons through direct and immune-mediated inflammatory signaling. If our studies are positive, they will suggest that TNFα inhibitors which are FDA- approved should be tested in clinical trials with SCD patients.

PHR: Despite widespread vaccination in the United States, pertussis (whooping cough) can be life-threatening for infants and young children. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks support for junior researcher attendance at the 11th World Congress on Stuttering and Cluttering (formerly referred to as the “International Fluency Association Joint World Congress”), to be held May 15-19, 2024 in Austin, Texas, USA. The World Congress is a joint effort of the World Stuttering and Cluttering Organization (formerly referred to as the “International Fluency Association”), the International Stuttering Association, and the International Cluttering Association, with additional support from the Arthur M. Blank Center for Stuttering Education and Research (Austin, Texas). Support recipients will also attend two training workshops designed to optimize preparation for grant applications and publication/tenure success.

PROJECT_TITLE: 11th World Congress on Stuttering and Cluttering

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Domestic violence is a substantial public health and safety problem with lasting consequences for individuals, families, and communities. The proposed research aims to rigorously evaluate the effectiveness of implementation of domestic violence protection order firearm prohibitions in reducing subsequent firearm-related crime, injury, and death among victim-survivors, protected minors, and respondents. Findings will provide actionable information for local and state policy makers and practitioners on the design and potential impact of enacting, implementing, and enforcing these firearm prohibitions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-006, Preventing firearm-related harm through Domestic Violence Protection Order firearm prohibitions and relinquishment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black youth experience persistent inequities in community violence with homicide being the leading cause of death for this population. Multilevel approaches that promote individual and collective healing processes and recognize community as an asset and agent of change are promising intervention strategies to prevent youth and community violence. We propose to use a community-based participatory research (CBPR) approach to implement and evaluate a multilevel intervention, Youth Empowered Advocating for Health (YEAH), designed to promote individual and collective healing processes to reduce risk for community violence among Black youth ages 12-17.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-004: Youth Participatory Action Research to Prevent Community Violence among Black youth

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The WTC-Work Study aims to identify how employment and working conditions, and union and employer policies, programs, and practices affect World Trade Center non-traditional responders' mental health, well- being, and health behaviors over the two decades since the September 11, 2001 World Trade Center terrorist attacks. Our study's findings have the potential to identify how work and workplace supports might positively contribute to workers' mental health, well-being, and health behaviors.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: WTC-Work Study: World Trade Center Non-Traditional Responders' Employment and Mental Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative The excess cancer risk in the World Trade Center (WTC) cohorts is not solely explained by surveillance or physician bias thus excess thyroid cancer and possibly more aggressive thyroid cancer may be due to exposure to endocrine disruptors present in WTC dust. Thyroid cancer is largely unstudied in the WTC survivor population which includes adolescents and minor children even though it is well documented that childhood / adolescence exposure to endocrine disruptors is significantly associated with thyroid carcinogenesis. Identifying phenotypes and biomarkers associated with increased risk of more aggressive thyroid cancer in WTC survivors, particularly those < 18 years when exposed, will help identify patients needing more aggressive thyroid cancer screening and management, lead to more effective health care delivery for this population, and shape future studies investigating cancers with excess risk in the WTC and other environmentally exposed populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Effect of WTC Exposure on Thyroid Cancer in the Survivor Population

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative  World Trade Center Responders report high levels of poor sleep quality and have a high prevalence of sleep disturbances known to increase risk of dementia. Particulate exposure and mental health conditions increase risk of premature cognitive impairment and neurodegeneration in WTC responders. In search of lifestyle factors to reduce risk of dementia, this project will test whether consistency of sleep at home and stability of sleep in the lab impacts emotional memory processing and blood-based markers of neurodegeneration.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Sleep stability, emotional memory and risk for neurodegeneration in World Trade Center Responders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is very persistent and prevalent in World Trade Center (WTC) responders following the attacks of 9/11. This project build on existing DNA methylation studies to understand epigenetic contribution to PTSD risk by using a more powerful design for genome-wide DNA methylation profiling that will produce novel findings, and allow for new data to be combined with existing studies to ensure generalizability of the results. This knowledge will help to explicate pathophysiology of this disorders on molecular level, which may become targets for treatment development.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Methylome profile of World Trade Center related PTSD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Registered nurses’ (RNs) can have trouble getting enough restful sleep due to their work hours and job stress. This project is designed to refine and test a sleep training program that can help RNs gain skills at improving sleep. With better sleep, RNs may enhance personal health and decrease safety risks to self and patients.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using Cognitive-Behavioral Change and Mobile Technology to Improve RN Sleep and Fatigue
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: World Trade Center (WTC) related disorders can be ameliorated by lifestyle medicine interventions, but their efficacy is constrained by high attrition. The current project will investigate a variety of potential risk factors to develop an algorithm to forecast attrition. This may reveal pathways to attrition that can be targeted by supportive interventions, thus improving efficacy of lifestyle medicine treatments.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Predicting Attrition from a Lifestyle Medicine Intervention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative World Trade Center (WTC)-exposed rescue/recovery workers who participated in the WTC Health Program (WTCHP) experience improved survival post-cancer diagnosis compared with demographically similar cancer patients from New York State. This survival benefit may be due to the level of care that these rescue/recovery workers receive as part of the WTCHP, but we cannot rule out the possibility that rescue/recovery workers were healthier than the reference population of New York State cancer patients prior to cancer diagnosis and therefore more likely to have a favorable cancer outcome (i.e., due to the healthy worker effect). The overall goal of the current proposal will address this gap in knowledge by investigating cancer survival and survival- related factors such as cancer-specific pathology and treatment initiation in WTCHP responders compared with an occupationally appropriate cohort of non-WTC-exposed responders.
PI_NAMEs: HALL, CHARLES B;WEBBER, MAYRIS P;ZEIG-OWENS, RACHEL  (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cancer Survival in WTC First Responders vs. Comparable Occupational Cohorts

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative We propose to employ innovative statistical and machine learning methods to assess the effects of WTC exposures and comorbidities on the full spectrum of distributions of the post-bronchodilator spirometry and oscillometry measurements, both cross-sectionally and longitudinally. Another aim of this project is to identify and evaluate vulnerable subgroups that show heterogeneous susceptibilities to WTC exposures to reduce health disparity. The findings from this study will improve our knowledge of the health effects on severe respiratory diseases related to the 9/11 terrorist attacks in the survivor population as a whole and within specific vulnerable sub-population, and will inform future risk management, clinical treatment, and address health disparities of patients in the WTC-EHC cohort.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Complex WTC Exposures Impacting Persistent Large and Small Airflow Limitation and Vulnerable Subgroups in the WTC Survivor Population

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work evaluates how two firearm-related policies – Extreme Risk Protection Orders and mandatory waiting periods – affect mortality risks among handgun owners and their cohabitants. Such evaluation adds to the empirical basis regarding the extent to which actionable strategies work (and for whom they work) to reduce the rate of firearm-related deaths.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-006, Leveraging Individual-Level Data to Evaluate Policies Targeting Acute Risk Periods for Firearm Violence: Extreme Risk Protective Orders and Waiting Periods in California

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans may be afflicted by a wide range of age-related conditions that impair vision or ocular function. These include primary open angle glaucoma, cataract, and diabetic retinopathy. Our understanding of the underlying disease mechanisms for these and other conditions is incomplete, as is our appreciation for whether the disease process varies across ethnic groups. Genetic studies provide important information regarding these questions. In this project, the Million Veteran Program resources will be used to (a) identify genetic loci related to ocular conditions that are prevalent in the Veteran population; (b) compare susceptibility genes across Veteran populations of European, African or Hispanic heritage and (c) determine if susceptibility genes are shared in multiple ocular disorders, are involved in other systemic disorders, or interact with environmental factors. The information gained in this project will inform the development of new treatments for age-related eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurately predicting transmission of mosquito-borne diseases in urban environments is challenging due to limited quantitative knowledge on the interacting effects of humidity and temperature on transmission, as well as pronounced spatial variation in human exposure to mosquitoes and mosquito relevant microclimates in cities. This proposal will utilize data generated from experiments that define key relationships between temperature, relative humidity, and transmission, along with climate data collected in the field, to build mechanistic models of temporal and spatial variation in urban malaria. Major outcomes will include an improved conceptual framework for the environmental epidemiology of urban malaria based on mosquito biology and new modeling approaches that apply this knowledge to make predictions of disease transmission.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to use a data-driven deep-phenotyping approach to evaluate at a systems level the mechanisms involved in placental regulation and the normal physiology of pregnancy as well as identifying how disruption of these processes is associated with common obstetric disorders. This study will enhance our knowledge of the dynamics of molecular network throughout pregnancy defining major pregnancy transition states and also generate and prioritize hypotheses of the molecular mechanisms driving some obstetric disorders, which can be used to develop future clinical interventions to promote maternal-fetal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryogenic electron-microscopy (Cryo-EM) is a new and rapidly evolving methodology for reconstructing the three-dimensional structure of proteins and biological macromolecules. The next generation of Cryo-EM problems face bottlenecks in reconstructing small molecular weight proteins, heterogeneous proteins with many conformational states, and in creating explanations for limited resolutions. This research proposes mathematical and algorithmic solutions to these problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This program will address critical issues in cardiovascular medicine: the dwindling supply of well-trained clinical and basic researchers focused on cardiovascular disease, and the need for investigators who can thrive in the multi-disciplinary environments essential to current research approaches. Trainees must be facile with new statistical approaches to large datasets and familiar with modern Omics techniques. Our ultimate goal is to produce investigators who can not only compete successfully for extramural funding and faculty positions but who can make substantive contributions to the understanding and treatment of cardiovascular disease, which remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Cardiovascular Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to expand the Understanding America Study to a longitudinal study of at least 20,000 individuals, including adequate representation of racial/ethnic groups to power subgroup analysis. Integrating multiple innovative data sources and technologies with the existing robust research infrastructure provides unprecedented opportunities to study the development of health and economic disparities over the life course. Resulting data will constitute a uniquely valuable resource, which will be made available to the research community without delay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Two of the most fundamental processes in biology, cell division and protein translation, have dramatically different outcomes in specialized cells. This project will investigate how animal germline cells fail to completely divide, and instead produce clusters of cells that communicate with each other through connecting bridges as they develop into eggs or sperm. We will also determine how and why genes that terminate translation normally in ovarian cells instead support efficient stop codon readthrough specifically in nerve cells of the central nervous system

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic neurodegenerative diseases that affect neurons, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), are excellent candidates for therapeutic CRISPR-based gene editing. This therapeutic benefit however has gone unrealized due to poor delivery of CRISPR machinery and low editing efficiency in neurons. Here, we propose two strategies to make small perturbations in neurons to increase the efficacy and specificity of CRISPR-based editing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  A joint model of longitudinal and multistate models is proposed to investigate the relationship between the risk of autoantibody development and subsequent type 1 diabetes risk, and the longitudinal pattern of risk factors. Based on the joint model, we will develop a dynamic prediction algorithm that can predict type 1 diabetes risk given the status of autoantibodies and the historical data from an individual. This project can facilitate the early identiﬁcation of individuals at high risk of type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Many anesthetics work by binding to proteins embedded in the lipid membranes that encase cells. Current methods for computationally predicting exactly where on the protein such drugs bind are inefficient or inaccurate, because it is challenging to properly consider the effect of the complex membrane environment. This project seeks to improve the widely used and efficient molecular docking method to more accurately consider the membrane, and therefore improve our ability to predict these binding sites.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic stewardship programs optimize the use of antibiotics to improve clinical outcomes, decrease adverse drug events, and reduce the emergence of antibiotic resistant bacteria, but typically neglect prescribing at the transition from hospital discharge to home. We will utilize an implementation science framework to develop, implement, and test the effectiveness of a multifaceted discharge stewardship intervention for hospitalized children with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or skin/soft tissue infections across four hospitals. This will establish a foundation for future expansion of discharge stewardship to additional target populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing a Discharge Stewardship Bundle to improve antibiotic use at transition from hospital to home
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The inability for children to receive definitive general pediatric inpatient care within rural communities creates significant inequities in quality and access to care. Addressing these inequities for children in setting of scarce resources and limited infrastructure requires health policy change and innovative initiatives specifically designed for the rural community. This proposal aims to establish system-level (e.g., provider, hospital, community) facilitators for the provision of general pediatric inpatient care in rural hospitals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Provision of Definitive Care for Children in Rural Hospitals

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This Collaborative Merit Award application (CMA) is a synergistic, multidisciplinary project focused on the mechanistic understanding of platinum resistance as the foremost cause of death in ovarian cancer patients. The overall strategy is to integrate ideas, resources, and expertise in advanced technologies to identify novel therapeutic targets and biomarker-driven treatments for ovarian cancer patients. CMA3 is focused to investigate the reprogramming of recurrent HGSOC cells to a more aggressive and therapy resistant tumor subpopulation with neuroendocrine (NE)-like features. Studies in this project will define the characteristics and molecular pathways activated in NE-like cells while simultaneously exploring unique vulnerabilities that can be exploited therapeutically with drugs poised to target NE-like cells. Aims of this proposal using human ovarian cancer samples and innovative precision medicine approaches have the potential for immediate translation into future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regular physical activity is essential for healthy aging of the heart and for older adults with heart disease, participation in cardiac rehabilitation is an ideal opportunity to deliver a highly tailored and personalized exercise prescription. In this project, we will evaluate the impact of a tailored exercise prescription that optimizes exercise intensity in cardiac rehabilitation, compared to usual care, with the goal to maximize fitness gains and long-term physical activity. We anticipate our results will help improve exercise prescription tailoring to help older adults increase their fitness, improve their levels of physical activity, and enjoy both a better quality and quantity of life as they age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 myocardial infarction (MI) is a common subtype of MI, experienced by over 280,000 individuals in the United States each year, and is characterized by myocardial necrosis occurring due to a mismatch in myocardial oxygen supply/demand. This current project aims to determine whether differences exist in the health status of persons with type 2 MI compared to type 1 MI, to explore clinician and patient perspectives on the use of cardiac rehabilitation for type 2 MI, and to assess if a multifaceted intervention can increase attendance at cardiac rehabilitation and potentially improves the health status of persons with type 2 MI. Cardiac rehabilitation has the potential to be the first therapy to improve the health status of this high-risk population who experience a type 2 MI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Carbofuran (a pesticide) and chlorine (a bleaching and warfare agent) exposure to humans show high ocular morbidity. This project tests a novel hypothesis that mTORC1-mediated dysfunctional autophagosome formation and lysosomal biogenesis are a dominant operating mechanism for corneal damage from exposure of carbofuran or chlorine. This project profiles clinical symptoms and defines underlying mechanism mediating corneal injury after carbofuran (aim-1) and chlorine (aim-2) exposure using two animal species and donor human corneas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe maternal morbidity (SMM) is a significant public health problem in the United States (U.S.), especially among Black birthing people, a population at highest risk of poor birth outcomes. This study will use quantitative and qualitative methods to describe Black birthing people's experiences with chronic racial discrimination (day- to-day occurrences of interpersonal racial discrimination occurring outside the medical setting) and acute racial discrimination in medical settings (discrimination experienced inside the medical setting, perpetuated by nurses, midwives, and obstetricians) and disrespectful care, and explore how these experiences impact SMM outcomes. The findings of this study have the potential to impact practice in many ways, including revision of standardized care practices of providers to improve risks of adverse outcomes in minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Extracellular signal-regulated kinases ERK1 and ERK2 are prototypes of the widely conserved mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAP Ks), and their aberrant activation drives tumorigenesis and confers therapeutic resistance. This proposal will investigate a previously unrecognized post-translational modification that may be critical for the specific and efficient activation of ERK. The insights generated from this work will shed important light on the fundamental issues pertaining to mitogenic signaling in normal and malignant cells, and will likely aid the development of effective therapies for a wide range of tumors characterized by hyperactive ERK.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cadmium is a near ubiquitous food contaminant that the general (non-occupational, non-smoking) population ingests at higher levels than the WHO determined provisional tolerable weekly intake. Cadmium is associated with impaired vision, learning challenges and behavioral disorders, with possible cascading effects on future generations. This proposal examines how cadmium exposure insults vision and genetic profiles leading to negative effects on learning, memory, and behavior in juveniles and across generations using zebrafish (Danio rerio) as a model, which supports NIEHS new initiative on Environmental Risks for Psychiatric Disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The GenitoUrinary Development Molecular Anatomy Project (GUDMAP) has been instrumental to research on urogenital development and diseases. Our proposed work will greatly enhance the current GUDMAP database by targeting structures and organs that have not been covered, as well as by extending into building spatially resolved high complexity molecular atlases. Our application of single cell omics, spatial transcriptomics, multiplex imaging, light sheet microscopy, and advanced computational multi-dimensional atlas building will also help to elevate GUDMAP to a higher level with unprecedented coverage and resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The secondary active cation-chloride cotransporters (CCCs) play fundamental roles in salt handling by the kidneys and inhibitory synaptic transmission in the nervous system. In this proposal, we will combine structural, biochemical, functional, and pharmacological approaches to elucidate how CCCs orchestrate concerted conformational changes to shuttle ions across membrane, how they interact with anti-hypertensive inhibitory diuretics, and how they are regulated by cognate kinases and phosphatases in response to hormones and cell volume perturbation. Successful outcomes will facilitate the development of novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of hypertension, edema, and various brain disorders and psychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Pharmacological therapies for spinal cord injury (SCI), such as methylprednisolone, have limited efficacy. However, a potential alternative treatment, low-dose estrogen (E2), has been found to be neuroprotective in SCI. Thus, studies in this application are focused on investigating the effects of novel fast and slow release E2-loaded nanoparticles (NP) on neuronal dysfunction and skeletal muscle loss in a rat contusion model of severe SCI. Protection of neural function in SCI following treatment with a combination of fast-release (FNP-E2) and slow-release (SNP-E2) formulations can help preserve and stabilize muscle fibers, which are intricately involved in recovery of function, leading to improved locomotor rehabilitation in combat veterans with severe SCI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The pathophysiology of many diseases that are common in the Veteran population such as diabetes, multiple sclerosis, chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia, arthritis, asthma, and the metabolic syndrome is thought to be due in part to a “leaky gut”, an impairment of intestinal barrier function that enables toxic substances in the gut lumen to enter the systemic circulation. Our laboratory has discovered that bacterial toxins that are believed to help cause many of these syndromes enter into the body by a specific transport mechanism through the cells lining the intestine. In the studies proposed in this grant application, we plan to elucidate the specific mechanisms by which these toxins are absorbed, using mice that are deficient in specific transport pathways. We hope to translate these studies, into the discovery of new treatments that will help “tighten” the “leaky gut” with the hope of preventing or treating many of these diseases that commonly afflict Veterans.
