IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: NARRATIVE While pancreatic cancer (PaC) survival rates have been modestly improving from decade to decade, the disease is still considered largely incurable, and therefore, there is an urgent need for new, effective and safe medications for PaC. ABTL0812 is a novel small molecule with anti-cancer activity through a novel mechanism of action. This application proposes to conduct a phase I/II clinical trial to assess the efficacy and safety of ABTL0812 in combination with the standard of care chemotherapy gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel in patients with advanced metastatic PaC at first line therapy.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Phase I/II clinical evaluation of ABTL0812, a novel PI3K/Akt/mTOR inhibitor, with a unique mechanism of action inpancreatic cancer (Protocol sent on 20th June 2019 as an amendment of the IND 137394)

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans comprise an elevated percentage of those with diabetes and subsequently have an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). We and others show that perivascular adipose tissue (PVAT), brown adipose tissue (BAT) that surrounds blood vessels, regulates vascular function differently between sexes. We demonstrate that housing animals at thermoneutrality causes PVAT to change from BAT to white adipose tissue (WAT), causing impaired vascular and cellular function in a sex-dependent manner. PVAT transformation and the resultant impact on vascular function is a novel pathogenic mechanism that may inform the biological underpinnings of sex difference in CVD progression. As the role of PVAT in vascular regulation has only been partially explored, understanding this pathology has translational potential for treating and preventing Veteran CVD in both men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project is aimed at improving the treatment of malaria. Resistance to current medicines makes drug combinations a requirement for treatment, but the best mixture of drugs to use is not easily discovered. The proposed work will use an apparatus, sometimes called a "glass mouse", to understand how best to design drug combinations for malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Increased activity of cancer-causing genes (onco-genes) is often due to increased copy numbers mediated by extrachromosomal DNA (ecDNA). We propose to enhance our software and algorithms for elucidating the structure, function, and evolution of ecDNA and make them available to the research community as user- friendly tools. The resulting resource will enable advances in ecDNA biology and help identify new therapeutic vulnerabilities in currently intractable cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 30 million Americans have diabetes, and 1 in 6, over 5 million, report food insecurity, or insufficient access to enough food for an active, healthy life. The proposed research program will significantly advance our understanding of how to best address food insecurity in the context of diabetes management by testing an innovative medically-tailored meal delivery intervention for individuals with food insecurity and elevated blood sugar levels. This intervention has the potential to improve health and reduce the impact of food insecurity among vulnerable individuals with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegeneration is the most widespread pathological defect found across neurological disorders. In the cerebellum, neurodegeneration is a well-established hallmark of ataxia, although its role in two of the most prevalent motor diseases, tremor and dystonia, remains hotly debated. This proposal seeks to determine how cerebellar neurodegeneration causes distinct functional alterations that initiate different motor diseases, with the ultimate goal of inspiring targeted therapeutic strategies that can restore normal motor function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neighborhood environment, a powerful social determinant of health, has a profound effect in shaping children’s physical, mental, and emotional health and in influencing opportunities for children to achieve long-term health. This project will explore the effect of neighborhood environment on child behavioral dysregulation and academic performance, and determine the degree to which family relationships, a modifiable factor, mediates the effect of neighborhood environment on behavioral dysregulation and academic performance in early childhood. This award will support my development toward becoming an independent nurse scientist dedicated to advancing the science in addressing social determinants of health and its effects on long-term child health and wellness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to characterize how the neural signals encoding odor information for a biologically relevant segment of the fly olfactory system are transformed at critical points within this system. In doing so, we hope to identify how these signal transformations can be associated with changes in specific aspects of fly behavior, like whether they turn more or slow down when making sharp turns. By studying how these signals are transformed and how these transformations impact behavior, we hope to gain a better understanding of how the fly olfactory system influences the selection of specific motor programs during ongoing locomotion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies in this proposal aim to develop therapeutics to normalize mitochondrial function in cocaine use disorders. Using viral strategies to knockout specific mitochondrial genes and fluorescent sensors to measure aspects of mitochondrial function in awake, behaving mice, we will be able to validate currently available mitochondrial therapeutics, as well as develop a pipeline for testing future mitochondrial drugs. These studies will significantly advance the chemistry and pharmacology of substance use disorders by exploring a novel treatment target and expanding the tools to dissect mitochondrial function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL) is a group of heterogeneous disease entities with varied clinico- pathologic features, and ~ 30-50% of PTCL cases remain unclassifiable in current clinical practice. Using novel technological advances, we identified robust molecular classifiers and distinct genetic profiles, which can aid in molecular subclassification of PTCL. We plan to establish standardized, evidence-based procedures on bio- specimen processing for the optimal preservation of bio-analytes to ensure accurate and reproducible downstream assay performance using tissue and liquid biopsy of PTCL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROGRAM NARRATIVE Genetic factors play an important role in determining blood pressure variations and the development of hypertension, the No. 1 identifiable risk factor for disease burden and deaths worldwide. The findings from the studies in this PPG will address one of the most challenging and yet important questions in hypertension research and provide unprecedented insight into the genetic and epigenetic regulation of blood pressure and other complex human traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second leading cause of cancer death among Chinese in the US. The goal of this proposal is to: (1) develop and pilot test CoLorectal Cancer Narrative Education and Navigation (CLEAN), a community-engaged intervention aimed at improving CRC screening in Chinese immigrants; and (2) provide Dr. Vang with mentored, hands-on and didactic training to acquire new knowledge and skills in community- engaged research and randomized controlled trials. This multimodal research and training plan will help Dr. Vang achieve independence as a behavioral health researcher and contribute to the elimination of cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The functional relationship between nuclear compartments and gene expression remains an enigma. Here we propose to identify components of known and still unknown nuclear “active niches”, using a novel combination of proteomics and omics proximity-labeling. Live-cell imaging will then determine the movements of genes and mRNAs to and from these active niches and determine the functional significance of these movements on gene expression exploiting the design of novel, low-cost, high-end microscopes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer relapses in half of all treated patients; relapsed disease does not respond well to new  therapies including those directed at boosting the body’s immune response against the tumor. We and others  determined that a protein called STAT3 promotes growth and survival of head and neck cancer cells and blocks  tumor immunity. We have developed a safe drug that effectively targets STAT3 that we propose to test in this  proposal for benefit in mouse models and patients with head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Expression of truncated constitutively active splice variants of androgen receptor is a major mechanism of resistance to current hormonal therapies for lethal metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. Here we propose the development of novel therapeutics and molecular imaging agents that could be used to treat and distinguish patients with metastatic lesions that express these splice variants. Our studies have important near and long-term clinical value to select patient treatments based on whether they express splice variants, monitor resistance mechanisms, and ultimately provide a novel treatment option to delay or prevent the terminal stage of prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Psychiatric and existential distress is common among patients with life-limiting cancer and effective pharmacologic-behavior treatments are lacking. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on improving the lives of people with life-limiting cancer by seeking to decrease depression, anxiety and existential distress, while improving quality-of-life (QOL). We anticipate this research will help reduce the burden of suffering for persons with advanced cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative p53 is the most frequently altered gene occurring in > 50% of human cancers. Perturbations in p53 signaling are required for development of most cancers. In contrast to other tumor suppressors, the vast majority of p53 alterations are missense mutations in the DNA-binding domain (‘mutp53’), leading to conformationally aberrant highly stabilized mutp53 proteins. Mouse models and clinical data from germline and sporadic cancers firmly established that missense mutp53 proteins not only lose their tumor suppressor function, but often acquire new oncogenic gain-of-function activities mutp53GOF. As major translational advance, our preliminary data established a strong exploitable dependency on continued high expression of mutp53 for tumor growth, maintenance and metastasis in autochthonous models of lymphoma and colorectal carcinoma. Our research program aims to evaluate the therapeutic potential of this concept in liver and pancreatic cancer, elucidate the mechanisms behind mutp53GO-driven tumorigenesis, with the ultimate goal to identify novel therapeutic targets for mutp53 cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Multidisciplinary Research Training Program in Cardiovascular Disease addresses the critical need for more physician-scientists and scientists focused on cardiovascular physiology and diseases. This Program will provide postdoctoral fellows with rigorous, personalized and state-of-the-art research training. The overarching goal is to equip outstanding young researchers with the knowledge and skills required to accelerate the translation of basic science discoveries into new approaches to the diagnosis and management of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public Health Impact The “UCLA-UCI Center for Eliminating Cardiometabolic Disparities in Multi-Ethnic Populations” (UC END- DISPARITIES) will address the inequitable multilevel factors, including structural disadvantage, that accelerate the development and progression of cardiometabolic disease and disproportionately affect low-income and minority groups. The center will function across the highly diverse communities that comprise Los Angeles County and Orange County (combined population over 13 million, more than 46 states). UC END- DISPARITIES will work to prevent cardiometabolic disease, reduce its harmful impact in minority communities, and develop equitable community-partnered research approaches to meet these objectives via three integrated cores, three center research projects, and training programs for new investigators, all working to develop innovative community-relevant approaches to cardiometabolic disease prevention and treatment for southern California's vulnerable communities and at-risk patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: As many as 23.5 million Americans suffer from autoimmune dieses and current therapies are non-curative and often systemically immunosuppressive, increasing the risk of opportunistic infections and cancer. The aim of this proposal is to develop an antigen-specific immunotherapy that upon intranasal administration binds to nasal mucus, passes via paracellular transport to the nasal immune system, and actively programs dendritic cells to generate autoantigen-specific regulatory T cells that suppress autoimmunity. Completion of this project will demonstrate the efficacy of a clinically-viable cure for autoimmunity in a preclinical model of autoimmune myocarditis and establish a platform technology that can be easily modified to treat various autoimmune and allergic dieses as well as transplant rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a very common and lethal cancer in Africa, and as patients with HIV live longer, the burden of HCC may increase. The proposed Consortium will conduct clinical research projects in Uganda and Senegal to investigate if and how treatment of HCC- causing infections may prevent HCC. In parallel, Consortium resources are applied towards developing human and clinical research capacity in both countries to address the growing problem of HIV and HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The discovery of BRAF as a major driver of human cancers led to a substantial clinical success of current BRAF therapies, however, the incomplete understanding of various biological processes that RAF kinases participate has hindered the development of more effective BRAF drugs. We propose to integrate chemical, biochemical, and biophysical tools together with mass spectrometry and cell imaging to address the molecular mechanisms of RAF activation and regulation in normal and disease conditions, specifically cancer. Our findings will provide fundamental insights into how RAF kinases operate at the molecular level and will have an impact on the treatment of BRAF-driven cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Tuberculosis (TB) is now the leading infectious disease threat in the world, killing more people than HIV/AIDS, as reported today by the World Health Organization. The TB RAMP program at UCSF is a collaboration between the School of Medicine, Institute for Global Health Sciences, and Curry International TB Center all of UCSF; the UC Berkeley School of Public Health; and the Center for Infectious Diseases in the California Department of Public Health. The program seeks to catalyze the development of research scientists focused on TB and on addressing the NIAID Strategic Plan for TB Research. This program is committed to developing scholars at the early stage of their careers by offering innovative training on TB disease, access to research opportunities, provision of sustained mentorship, and support for pilot projects to launch their research careers. TB RAMP scholars will be inspired, well trained, and mentored to pursue high quality and innovative research focused on combatting the TB epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal builds on a strong portfolio of data demonstrating potent efficacy of a plant virus nanoparticle immunotherapy to launch adaptive, systemic, and durable antitumor immunity. In this continued research, we propose to develop immuno-combination and targeted therapies for treatment of triple negative breast cancer, which is an aggressive life-threatening disease with poor prognosis. Efficacy and mechanism of action will be studied in mouse models and canine patients with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Virtually all pharmacology studies are based on quantifying responses to drugs in a population of patients, thereby obscuring fundamental individual differences in drug responses. This proposal ushers in the era of personalized medicine to anesthesiology by developing a novel set of parameters that define anesthetic responses in each subject individually. By correlating individual features of responses to anesthetics with degree of decrement in cognitive performance across life span, we will identify unique individual features of anesthetic responses that may confer greater vulnerability to post-operative delirium and cognitive dysfunction that plagues millions of elderly adults who undergo surgical procedures annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular drug delivery is challenging due to the complex structure of the cornea that impedes adequate drug delivery and therapeutic efficacy. This project aims to develop a minimally-invasive, painless, and effective ocular drug delivery platform through the innovation of fully-miniaturized and slowly-biodegradable (over days) silicon nanoneedles built upon a rapidly-dissolvable (within 30 seconds) water-soluble contact lens. This platform can yield a more controllable and longer-lasting drug release profile in a less-invasive manner compared to current gold-standard biodegradable microneedles, thus improving therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. social safety net provides little financial assistance to most patients following illness, and financial toxicity after acute illness is poorly measured and understood. The SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) pandemic has created millions of new survivors of acute illness in the U.S., making it even more urgent that we develop new ways to measure financial toxicity. The overarching goal of this proposal is to 1) use novel data to better measure objective financial burden, 2) use rigorous empirical methods to estimate the effect of COVID-19 infection on financial burden and explore heterogeneity of effects across different groups of patients, and 3) create a COVID-19-specific measure of subjective financial distress, with the ultimate goal of informing the creation of policies to better protect vulnerable patients from the financial consequences of illness.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The cost of illness: The impact of COVID-19 on patient financial outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis remains a surprisingly common and underappreciated suddenly developing and life-threatening disease condition that can lead to death within hours to days, even with the most advanced medical treatment, including powerful antibiotics and organ support systems. While there remains a critical and unmet medical and societal need to develop a safe and effective treatment for sepsis, numerous attempts and failed drugs in a large number of clinical trials of the past keeps discouraging the pharma industry from investing in sepsis research and development. Despite failures of the past, we remain optimistic and propose to continue intensive and improved search for a medical solution to sepsis through identification of novel mechanisms and drug targets that detrimentally contribute to the poor prognosis and high mortality of the disease, and, if successful, promote the evaluation and development of fundamentally new attempts to prevent or combat sepsis with fundamentally new medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) remains a major cause of maternal morbidity and mortality. Inhibition of prolactin with the dopamine agonist bromocriptine appeared to improve outcomes in previous clinical studies of PPCM; however, no randomized trial has been performed in a multi-racial North American cohort comparing bromocriptine against standard heart failure therapy. The purpose of the Randomized Evaluation of Bromocriptine Therapy for Peripartum Cardiomyopathy (REBIRTH) trial is to evaluate whether the addition of bromocriptine to standard heart failure therapy improves outcomes in women with PPCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electroacupuncture works by stimulating various nerves in the body, which can lead to lowering of blood pressure. In this study, we are looking at how a specific combination of nerve stimulation using electroacupuncture can improve the function of the arterial vessels that control blood pressure. Findings from this study may aid the design and delivery of electroacupuncture treatment to help those who are unable to get to their blood pressure to target levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to optimize a new series of drugs to eradicate the dormant liver stage of Plasmodium vivax. Our team will use the results of a novel liver stage culturesystem to drive the optimization of. the new drugs and will use chemical biology tools to identify targets for the drugs. The impact of this work could be the first new drug to treat relapsing malaria in over 70 years and the identification of the first validated targets for new drug discovery for P. vivax.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aggressive types of brain tumors (such as glioblastoma multiforme or GBM) respond poorly to the current treatments of surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. This research proposes to solve this challenge with a multifunctional magnetic nanoparticle agent that simultaneously delivers contrast for a novel bio-imaging technique called magnetic particle imaging (MPI), as well as magnetothermal therapy of the inoperable deep brain tumors. Sensitive and selective image-guided ablation of tumor is possible because these optimized nanoparticles only accumulate in the brain tumor tissue, and we envision that this two-armed approach may have utility with many other types of solid tumors such as pancreatic, lung and prostate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Epigenetics of the autoantibody response in systemic lupus Epigenetic marks “interact” with genetic programs to regulate B cell functions, such as immunoglobulin (antibody) gene class switch DNA recombination (CSR), somatic hypermutation (SHM) and plasma cell differentiation, thereby informing the antibody response. Dysregulation of epigenetic mechanisms in B lymphocytes can result in aberrant autoantibody responses and would compound genetic susceptibility to mediate autoimmunity, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), in which heavily mutated and class-switched (mainly IgG) autoantibodies produce widespread tissue and organ injury. This proposal addresses antibody and autoantibody responses in SLE and underlying mechanisms, with a focus on how Tet2, an important epigenetic factor, upregulates the expression of AID, which is essential for CSR/SHM, and Blimp-1, which is essential for plasma cell differentiation. It will also address how the expression and activity of Tet2 is regulated at different differentiation stages of human and mouse B cells, by estrogen, which underpins the female bias for systemic autoantibody-mediated autoimmunity, such as in SLE. In additional to this hormonal stimulus, this proposal will address the role nutritional and metabolic elements in Tet2 induction/activation, thereby providing the basis for the development of Tet2 inhibitors as therapeutics in autoimmune diseases. Our innovative and rigorous experiments will unveil novel and targetable epigenetic mechanisms that integrate environmental cues to inform lupus autoantibody responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified WRN as a synthetic lethal target for MSI cancers. This research proposal seeks to investigate why WRN is required in MSI cancers, inform rational drug design, and investigate the relationship between the innate immune response and the DNA-damage response following WRN depletion in cancers with MSI. The overarching goal of this project is to enable the translation of our discovery into a clinically-meaningful therapeutic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is, to our knowledge, the first study to investigate the role of human herpesvirus reactivation in a large cohort of people with ME/CFS (presenting mild/moderate or severe symptoms) in comparison to healthy controls, as well as people with Long COVID and people who fully recovered after COVID-19. Our data and sample collection includes clinical phenotype (including symptom severity), markers of viral reactivation, and immune profiling. Our preliminary findings suggest a correlation between herpesvirus reactivation and symptomology in ME/CFS, particularly related to symptom severity; this proposed study and planned combined clinical and lab-based analyses aims to further clarify whether herpesvirus reactivation induces the aggravation of symptoms or is a consequence of underlying immune dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life adversity—reported by over 25% of the US population—is thought to program biological adaptations to stress that contribute to life-long health disparities, including increased risk for chronic disease and early mortality. Interventions to offset these risks in adulthood are needed; mindfulness meditation interventions have been effective for reducing stress and improving markers of physical health, but whether they are acceptable and effective for improving health among people with a history of ELA remains unclear. From a public health perspective, establishing an evidence base for remote, just-in-time mindfulness interventions may help to address health disparities in a wide population.

PHR: Antibodies represent some of the most important tools in biology and medicine, which are used to detect and perturb molecular targets for research, diagnostics and therapeutics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative For many patients with melanoma, treatment with targeted therapies initially shows great promise only for the disease to return, often without any new mutations that explain why the treatment stopped working. This proposal aims to define non-genetic mechanisms that explain how cancers like melanoma become resistant to therapy. By understanding these mechanisms we can unlock new therapeutic strategies to overcome treatment failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug-resistant (MDR) bacteria are among the most immediate threats to human health, causing life- threatening illnesses and, increasingly, infections for which currently available antibiotics are simply ineffective. To help counter this danger, we propose to establish chemokine-derived peptides as novel therapeutics that exert direct bactericidal activity against MDR pathogens, as well as host-targeted bioregulatory effects beneficial to combating wound/surgical-site infections and promoting healing. Our investigations will demonstrate an innovative new paradigm for addressing the mounting burden of MDR pathogens and curtailing the continued emergence/spread of antimicrobial resistance in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD) is characterized by involvement of multiple end organs, resulting in multiple complications including chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD as well as rapid decline of kidney function are common in SCD, and are associated with increased risk of death. We propose studies to identify individuals at high risk for progression of CKD using machine learning models, and to evaluate the kidney-protective effects of voxelotor, a novel inhibitor of sickle hemoglobin polymerization, in individuals at risk for rapid decline in kidney function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is the fourth-leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the United States having the worst prognosis with 5-year survival rate of 10%. In this project, we pursue the development of a sequential therapy using targeted stimuli-responsive drug delivery nanocarriers for the treatment of advanced PDAC. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will develop reliable technologies for the effective treatment of advanced PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is heart muscle disease that can cause disabling symptoms, dangerous heart rhythm disturbances, and premature death. Mutations in the genes that encode the sarcomere, the molecular motor of the heart, are the most frequent cause of HCM, however, there is tremendous variation in disease experience from one patient to the next. This project aims to identify genetic and non-genetic factors that influence disease severity and clinical outcomes in HCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative With the rise in the impact of cardiovascular disease on US and world health, it is critical to train the next generation of investigators in translational vascular research. Stanford University has world-class faculty, the necessary resources, and the collaborative milieu to address the major public health problem of cardiovascular disease. This multidisciplinary T32 training program in Translational Vascular Research is designed to train postdoctoral fellows in clinical, translational, and basic vascular medicine and research and medical ethics, and to foster their development into investigators dedicated to identifying innovative solutions and capable of translating basic research into clinical success to combat vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial ligand-induced murine vasculitis, coronary arteritis and myocarditis is highly dependent of NLRP3 inflammasome activation and bioactive IL-1β release. Here, we will characterize the role of neutrophils and eosinophils infiltrating the inflamed tissues and investigate how the modulation of NLRP3 and PAD4 activity could prevent the vascular innate immune responses leading to vascular inflammation and injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Finding an effective treatment for dry eye is challenging. Topical N-94/C-6 ('Lacripep'), a natural fragment of the tear protein lacritin (deficient in dry eye) addressed sign and symptom within two weeks in the recent phase II trial NCT03226444. Here we work out more fully the mechanisms of action by characterizing the receptor complex, including proximal and distal mediators, and develop a model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Substance use disorder (SUD) is a major, unmet medical condition with a global impact. According to the 2018 National Survey on Drug Use and Health, ~32 million people over the age of 12 in the U.S. had reported using an illicit drug in the past 30 days, and >8.1 million people were addicted to illicit drugs. Cocaine is one of the most commonly abused illicit drugs. Despite the clear and compelling need, there are no FDA approved medications for the treatment of cocaine use disorder (CUD). We have identified a preliminary series of novel, drug-like 5-HT7 antagonists that include compounds, PRA073 and PRA078, which produce a positive impact in the cocaine reinstatement rat model of addiction in our preliminary studies. In this program, we will continue our efforts focused on identifying novel, selective 5-HT7 antagonists suitable for evaluation in in vivo efficacy models of CUD and eventual pre-clinical evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Everman, Elizabeth PROJECT NARRATIVE Mapping quantitative trait variation to specific genes has proved critical for our understanding of the genetic basis of disease in humans, and the same approaches can be used to identify genes and networks that are responsible for variable resistance to metal poisoning in natural populations. Here I will combine powerful, highly replicated genetic mapping with multiple behavioral and physiological assays and whole genome and RNA sequencing to characterize the genetic basis of resistance to copper poisoning. By exploiting an elite model genetic system, this work will provide novel insight into genetic variants that influence susceptibility to metal poisoning in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project narrative: Excessive binge alcohol drinking negatively affects cardiovascular function lasting for several hours. Acute alcohol intoxication is associated with elevated levels of the cardiac endocannabinoid anandamide that exerts important cardiovascular effects and induces redistribution of circulation via activating CB1 receptor signaling. In this proposal we aimed to investigate the role of gut-heart axis in binge alcohol drinking-associated peripheral CB1 receptor activation and subsequent cardiovascular dysfunction by characterizing the cellular source of endocannabinoids and the triggers of their production in the cardiovascular system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vast majority of people with depression worldwide receive no treatment. To address this need, healthcare workers in over 90 countries have been trained in the WHO’s depression treatment guidelines (mhGAP), but often receive no ongoing support to implement the guidelines in their practice. The proposed project develops and tests a blended in-person/mobile phone-based support strategy to help primary healthcare nurses in Zimbabwe to diagnose and treat depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: ICERCH as the Recruitment Resource Center will work collaboratively with each ERN study team and the other HEAL ERN Resource Centers and continue to develop and monitor comprehensive strategies to address barriers to recruitment and retention in the five funded HEAL pain studies and two additional studies, demonstrate their effectiveness in recruiting diverse participants and broadly disseminate evidence on the most effective approaches to recruitment and retention of people who have pain. The HEAL Pain Management Effectiveness Research Network (ERN) is a key component of the initiative and to be successful, these ERN trials will need to efficiently recruit participants and minimize dropouts. To ensure HEAL Pain ERN studies accrue and retain the number and diversity of participants required to assess primary and secondary outcomes, we propose a Recruitment Resource Center to support the development of a robust recruitment infrastructure, complete with the tools, resources, and innovative strategies needed to proactively address recruitment barriers and rapidly identify and mitigate emerging roadblocks across sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The importance of OA disease prevention is evident because we presently have no effective disease- modifying interventions, there are substantial safety concerns associated with many pain medications, and there is no cure. This Phase III randomized clinical trial will test a critically needed primary prevention intervention on females at risk for the development of structural knee OA by implementing a program of dietary weight loss, exercise, and weight-loss maintenance designed for long-term sustainability to maximize health benefits at a reasonable cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most US employees have health insurance with greater than $1,000 deductibles, yet little research has studied how high out-of-pocket costs affect patients experiencing acute cardiovascular emergencies such as heart attacks. The proposed research will advance our understanding of high-deductible health plans’ impact on outcomes from heart attacks, unnecessary hospitalizations for chest pain, and patients’ perspectives on how high out-of-pocket costs influence their care decisions and perceived care quality. Results from these studies will provide important implications for future insurance regulations to minimize unintended harm, reduce the financial burden of care, and align clinical decisions with patients’ value perspectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has been increasing in Western countries as a consequence of obesity. Available immunotherapies are largely unsuccessful for the treatment of HCC. We have shown that miR-15a/16 fully prevented HCC in three HCC mouse models by recovering anti-tumor immunity. We expect that this study will provide novel insight into the immunosuppression mechanism in HCC and facilitate the design of KCs as a new therapeutic target and miR-15a/16 as a rational immunotherapy against HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In recent decades, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified genetic variants associated with a variety of traits and diseases, a critical first step towards understanding the molecular mechanisms that underlie common health conditions. In many cases, however, the functions of GWAS genes, the mechanisms and consequences of their dysfunction, or the relevant cell types in which their dysfunction manifests a clinically significant phenotype remain poorly understood. This application applies a combination of bioinformatic analysis, human induced pluripotent stem cell modeling, and mouse studies to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which the GWAS gene DSP modulates function of type 2 alveolar epithelial cells and contributes to the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The common sexually transmitted protozoan pathogen, Trichomonas vaginalis, colonizes the genital tract and causes hundreds of millions of infections worldwide. Treatment of trichomoniasis is with oral nitro drugs, but they can have significant adverse effects, resistance is a manifest clinical problem, and no therapeutic alternatives are approved. The project will conduct the critical pre-clinical studies to establish proteasome inhibitors as new agents in the therapeutic armamentarium against this common and clinically important cause of parasitic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Understanding the mechanistic factors that contribute to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) progression is essential to promote healthy aging. Pathogens are correlated to cognitive decline but a causative link is lacking. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can result in rewiring of metabolic pathways. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that repeated CMV infection alters blood brain barrier metabolism, accelerating AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand why bariatric surgery is such an effective treatment for obesity with a focus on brain mechanisms. Cerebrospinal fluid neuropeptide, hormone and protein levels will be measured as a surrogate for changes in brain activity in subjects before and after bariatric surgery as compared with subjects before and after diet-induced weight loss. Understanding how the central nervous system responds to bariatric surgery could facilitate the development of alternative nonsurgical therapies for obesity and its metabolic complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a serious chronic lung disease of premature babies that causes life-long cardiorespiratory morbidities and there are no effective treatments available to prevent or treat this disease. Infants who died because of BPD have increased levels of Cellular communication network factor 2 (CCN2) in their lungs. This study will use animal models to evaluate the function of CCN2 in lung cells during normal lung development and during disease, and evaluate whether decreasing the production of CCN2 in lung cells will prevent BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative – MAE-WEST SCORE Overall Women compared to men experience an excess of burden of age-related diseases of the heart, brain, and kidney for reasons that remain unclear. Growing evidence points to the potential importance of chronic inflammation and small blood vessel dysfunction as key determinants of the sex differences seen in age-related disease outcomes. Therefore, we will establish a Specialized Center of Research Excellence focused on comprehensively investigating sex differences in the molecular drivers of chronic inflammation, microvascular aging, and end-organ disease. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative – MAE-WEST SCORE LAC With advancing age, women and men age differently; women suffering more from Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, chronic kidney disease, and frailty. Recent work suggests that small blood vessel-related aging driven by chronic low-grade inflammation may be responsible for these aging disparities for women. The Leadership Administrative Core (LAC) in the Microvascular Aging and Eicosanoids – Women’s Evaluation of Systemic aging Tenacity (MAE-WEST) (“You are never too old to become younger!”) Specialized Center of Research Excellence (SCORE) on Sex Differences will oversee the program operations, communications, budgets and regulatory practices to optimize the translation of findings to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The widespread use of antiretroviral therapy has significantly increased the lifespan of people living with HIV. Despite their effectiveness, there is a growing concern that antiretrovirals are the cause of a variety of comorbid conditions. The current proposal will investigate the role of antiretrovirals on bone loss and fat accumulation, two common conditions seen in HIV patients receiving antiretroviral treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Optimizing pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) access is crucial for ending the HIV epidemic, particularly among marginalized populations; though unhealthy alcohol use is a central modifiable risk factor for HIV incidence, few HIV prevention interventions exist that synergistically address both. Research is needed to understand PrEP uptake among individuals with unhealthy alcohol use and to develop scalable patient-centered interventions that synergistically address unhealthy alcohol use and HIV. The proposed sequential mixed methods study will use co-design methodology, guided by a Community Advisory Board, in nation’s largest provider of both HIV and alcohol-related care to examine PrEP initiation and persistence among patients with unhealthy alcohol use, including those from marginalized subgroups, and tailor and pilot a decision aid to foster shared decision- making to enhance uptake of PrEP concomitantly with provision of evidence-based alcohol-related care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Down syndrome (DS) have heterogeneous developmental outcomes and varying support needs which impact quality of life and contribute to significant family stress and financial burden. Identification of objective early markers, with robust neurobiological underpinnings, of specific cognitive, social, and sensory outcomes is key for advancing and tailoring early interventions for DS. This series of testable experiments described in this proposal will yield physiological biometrics of arousal that are objective, present in infancy, and provide clinically actionable targets for treatment in early life to ultimately lead to improved functional outcomes for those with DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative – MAE-WEST SCORE Project 3 With advancing age, women and men age differently; women suffering more from Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, chronic kidney disease, and frailty. Recent work suggests that small blood vessel-related aging driven by chronic low-grade inflammation may be responsible for these aging disparities for women. Project 3 in the Microvascular Aging and Eicosanoids – Women’s Evaluation of Systemic aging Tenacity (MAE-WEST) (“You are never too old to become younger!”) Specialized Center of Research Excellence (SCORE) on Sex Differences will determine the if the pro and anti-inflammatory responses cause differences in cell and small vessel function in experimental models and human endothelial cells to improve public health by developing new treatment targets for age-related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) remains an incurable and often fatal disease characterized by irreversible vascular remodeling. Leveraging a well-powered cohort integrating the latest omics and computational methodologies is critically needed to identify candidate molecular drivers in PAH lungs as potential therapeutic targets. The proposed studies will utilize a combination of cutting-edge multiomic approaches and experimental biology to provide greater insight into a novel PAH-associated gene set derived from the largest PAH lung biobank to date, and will lay the groundwork for future mechanistic and translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a cancer cell imaging program to probe the mechanisms of metastatic tumor formation in the context of the host environment. This critical step in the development of metastatic disease is likely to be accompanied by vulnerabilities of the cancer cells that could be exploited for clinical treatment. The proposed work will establish novel microscopy with unprecedented resolution while maintaining sufficient experimental throughput to discover the relevant metastasis-driving processes at the single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (Entire PPG) High-density lipoproteins (HDLs), sometimes called ‘good cholesterol,’ help protect against heart disease and diabetes and may help fight infection. The molecular processes that produce the various HDL subspecies is not well understood. These projects will combine human and animal studies with computer modeling and test tube studies to determine how HDL is made and how it may protect against heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to develop an understanding of the biology and functional implications of tissue resident memory T cells (TRM) in the mouth, a barrier mucosal site largely overlooked by T cell immunologists. T cells have recently been implicated in several oral disease and autoimmune states including periodontitis, canker sores, and oral lichen planus, yet currently an understanding of how T cells (in particular TRM) function in oral tissues is limited. Extending our knowledge of TRM biology into the oral mucosa will allow us to conceptualize TRM in oral health and disease and provide a foundation to develop therapeutic approaches that target oral TRM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart rhythm disorder in the United States with 1 in 4 adults at risk of disease development and is linked to serious debilitating complications like stroke and heart failure. For reasons we don’t yet understand, the developmental left/right patterning gene, PITX2, is linked to disease risk and recurrence following intervention late in life. In support of the NIH mission to promote better treatment and prevention strategies, my research study will use recent technological advances to study how PITX2-dependent patterning on the left side of the heart during development is required for a lifetime of normal heart rhythm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Early midlife Black women 35-44 years old have more than double the prevalence of hypertension (HTN) compared to aged-matched White women, 48.3% versus 21.3%, respectively. Early onset HTN among early midlife Black women is linked to a higher burden of HTN-mediated organ damage and cardiovascular disease (CVD) morbidity and mortality; however, causes of these disparate outcomes remain unknown but may be due to the unequal burden of distinct stressors (i.e., racial, gender, financial, job, and social network) experienced by Black women. Repeated exposure to these distinct stressors are suggested to cause stress proliferation and modify the effects of health protective resources such as resilience that may lead to undesirable effects on physical health, thus, this K23 proposal seeks to quantify the impact of chronic stress burden and resilience on biologic and vascular aging using Klemera-Doubal estimation method, whether a person is biologically older or younger given their chronological age, and arterial stiffness, a proxy of CVD risk, in early midlife Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Constructing reliable individualized treatment strategies requires studies with fairly large sample sizes with longi- tudinal assessment of subjects over a relatively long period of time. To this end, we will create a harmonized and curated dataset by integrating data from seven long-term observational and randomized studies in Parkinson's disease. Using this harmonized data, we will develop and apply robust, rigorous and computationally efﬁcient methods for estimating an optimal individualized treatment strategy for Parkinson's disease with respect to var- ious outcomes (e.g., Uniﬁed Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale, quality of life, and Schwab and England ADL score). We will also leverage statistical machine learning approaches to improve the quality of the constructed optimal individualized treatment strategy while providing valid statistical inference.

PHR: Project Narrative    The goal of this training grant is to develop a diverse pool of well- trained cell biologists through high  quality research training and mentored research experiences. Students will be trained to be versant in  scale- crossing experimental approaches used in cell biology from molecules, to cellular organization and   tissue morphogenesis. A deep understanding of cell biology will be an essential underpinning for research  in areas that will impact human health including aging, cancer, and infectious and inherited human  diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Obesity is a key risk factor for gestational diabetes. Although both insulin resistance and insulin insufficiency are two primary underlying mechanisms of gestational diabetes, β-cell dysfunction leads to hyperglycemia. This project is designed to define adiponectin's regulatory effects on maternal β-cell adaptation and the contribution of hypoadiponectinemia in obesity-associated gestational diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Haitian immigrants to the US, who comprise one of the fastest-growing and most-understudied immigrant subgroups in the country, experience high levels of post-migration psychological distress (i.e., depression, anxiety, fatigue, and pain), which contribute to progressive functional impairment, disability, economic burden, and poor long-term health outcomes. Evidence suggests that the gut microbiome (GM; i.e., the collective genomes of microbes living in the gut) plays an important role in the development and persistence of psychological distress and, further, that the GM is modifiable through interventions targeting social determinants of health (SDoH) like stress, lifestyle behaviors, dietary patterns, environmental/sociocultural conditions, and sociodemographic characteristics. The present study will investigate associations between psychological distress, the GM, and post-migration SDoH in recent Haitian immigrants to the US as a critical step in developing culturally responsive, personalized interventions to mitigate psychological distress, improve long-term health outcomes, reduce health disparities, and increase health equity in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Infertility affects one in six couples worldwide, with men and women equally likely to have fertility problems. In men, known genetic factors account for ~10-15% of total infertility cases, whereas the remaining ~35-40% cases have an unknown etiology. Therefore, a comprehensive understanding of the genetic and molecular programs involved in proper germ cell development is required for development of better diagnostics and effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The rapid uptake of telehealth since the coronavirus pandemic has highlighted not only the potential for telehealth to improve access and quality of care, but also how it can exacerbate the “digital divide,” highlighting the need to focus on health equity. Using the largest integrated health care system in the US [Veterans Health Administration (VA)] as a clinical practice network, we will focus on race/ethnicity, poverty and rurality and how they affect use of telehealth, which we refer to as social determinants of telehealth (SDTH). We propose a Center called Telehealth Research and Innovation for Veterans with Cancer (THRIVE), whose overarching aim is two-fold: 1) understand how SDTH impact the delivery of telehealth for cancer and 2) develop methods to address SDTH and thereby improve access and quality of cancer care for all patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Adult survivors of childhood cancer are a growing population who face a number of long-term and late effects secondary to their cancer treatment, which have the potential to profoundly impact their future health, quality of life, and achievement of life goals. This project will examine the initial feasibility, acceptability, and pre- to post- intervention patterns of change in treatment targets of a novel behavioral intervention aiming to address fertility-related information needs and fertility-related distress among adult survivors of childhood cancer. Although this project is focused on the late effect of impaired fertility, the intervention developed through this study has the potential to produce significant public health benefits: it could be applied to address other late effects in this population, which if left untreated, may lead to greater health complications in this growing population later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our NLM Research Training Program in Biomedical Informatics (BMI) and Data Science (DS) has successfully brought the theory and practice of computation, applied mathematics, statistics, data-driven inference and decision-making, and advances in cognitive informatics, to bear on problems in human health and disease that are currently beyond our reach. We will further expand our program to explore and exploit the dynamic interaction of multiple facets of BMI and DS with the current methodologies, tools, and computational approaches of artificial intelligence including machine learning, and their synergistic applications in biomedicine and human health and disease, including precision medicine, clinical decision-making and data-driven health. This program provides the unique opportunity for pre- and postdoctoral trainees to acquire the skills, expertise and intellectual abilities to foster innovative research and prepare them for a wide range of BMI careers that significantly impact basic research, patient healthcare, and public health, by: pursuing core courses in BMI and DS and advanced electives, training in rigor and reproducibility and the responsible conduct of research, professional/career development activities, and dual-mentored inter-disciplinary research projects in health care/clinical informatics, translational bioinformatics, and clinical research informatics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is associated with the breakdown of the DNA in the nucleus of the cells. The broken pieces of DNA are released into the cytoplasm of the cells, where it is sensed by a set of specific proteins that initiate a cascade of events that leads to inflammation and aging of cells, organs, and organisms. Our goals are to identify the sites of these DNA breaks in the heart cells, characterize features of the cytosolic DNA, and block the activated pathway to assess its effects on the biological process related to aging.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes care is complex and requires a multidimensional approach, but interventional programs are difficult to initiate in low-income and minority populations. In the proposed study, we will mentor local clinics via telehealth to initiate our diabetes program, TIME (Telehealth-supported, Integrated CHWs, Medication-access, group visit Education), into their clinics. Mentoring local clinics to initiate TIME is a promising strategy to enhance sustainable diabetes care and reduce disparities in vulnerable minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Understanding how the latent HIV reservoir forms is critical to developing new strategies to eliminate infected cells from people with HIV. Recent data has shown that the majority of the reservoir forms in a defined temporal window that coincides with the initiation of anti-retroviral therapy (ART). In this proposal, we aim to define transcriptional and epigenetic changes that occur in CD4 T cells during ART initiation by characterizing longitudinal samples from a clinical cohort and reveal how the intracellular state of CD4 T cells promotes viral silencing and epigenetic repression of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Chicago (UChicago) Center for Asian Health Equity (CAHE) and the Institute for Population and Precision Health (IPPH) put forth the Chicago AsA-NHPI Cohort CCFS to leverage decades of experience enrolling underrepresented minorities, especially Asian Americans, into health studies and epidemiologic cohorts as a clinic/community field site for the new NIH-funded AsA-NHPI Cohort (NAC). We plan to enroll 2,500 participants from communities in the metropolitan Chicago area with large Asian subgroup representation using a population-based sampling framework. Our long-term partner, the Asian Health Coalition (AHC) has been serving as the national engagement lead for the All of Us Research Program and has set the model for community engaged cohorts tailored to Asian inclusion. In this proposal, the UChicago MPIs and team enthusiastically propose a collaborative approach to meet the milestones; building on prior success and experience working on local, regional and national multisite cohorts with an emphasis on racial diversity, scientific rigor, and innovative approaches to improve health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  This project will examine the influences of neighborhood built and social environments, acute individual and contextual precipitants, as well as demographics and social history, biobehavioral and psychosocial predispositions on physical activity (PA) adoption and maintenance among sedentary Pacific Islander adults in Utah. It will use emerging mobile health technologies to measure PA and its key correlates in real time in the real world. The study will fill key gaps in the literature on important correlates and mechanisms underlying PA behavioral change for this fast-growing, high health risk, yet severely understudied population group, and will provide critical information on how to improve their PA level and reduce obesity and obesity-related health problems. The methodology and findings derived from this study will also provide a new perspective in understanding PA behavior of other racial/ethnic groups with high obesity and low PA levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: LAY DESCRIPTION Brain inflammation play critical role in progression of the Alzheimer diseases. The purpose of this study is to highlight the factors and mechanisms regulating entrance and activity of the circulating neutrophils in the brain that aggravate inflammation in the Alzheimer diseases. This may provide a foundation for developing novel therapeutic strategies to prevent cognitive decline and ravages of Alzheimer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative We discovered a previously unrecognized mechanism by which neurons protect against effects of protein aggregation and dysfunctional organelles—neurons physically throw out their threatening trash in large membrane-surrounded vesicles (exophers) for uptake and degradation by remote cells. We propose that exopher production constitutes a conserved pathway for maintaining neuronal health and we speculate that, with age or excess stress, the exopher pathway inappropriately contributes to neurodegeneration and spread of neurotoxic species. Our planned study of molecular factors that act in, and modulate, exopher formation in an accessible animal model may identify novel targets for future therapeutic benefit in neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Solid tumors are a mixture of cell types that support tumor growth and prevent the immune system from killing cancer cells. We’ve designed a method to reprogram immune cells to target not only cancer cells but also eliminate support cells. We will optimize this therapy through rigorous preclinical testing and then test it in a clinical trial in patients with pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We aim to validate a comprehensive remote neuropsychological toolbox, which would enable researchers and clinicians to accurately and reliably assess cognition and function of older adults who are at risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementia (ADRD) when in-person assessments are not feasible or safe. Remote assessment will facilitate more frequent evaluations at lower cost, potentially improving sensitivity, reliability, and validity of cognitive assessment for observational studies, clinical trials and clinical practice. The diverse older adult cohort afforded through the Bronx community will advance our understanding of disparities in ADRD, which will have implications for intervention and disease monitoring in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide initial validation of multiparametric quantitative imaging and the derived surrogate to assess the liver-pancreas axis of diabetes progression in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. This proposal will further advance magnetic resonance elastography as a practical imaging tool for qualitatively and quantitatively monitoring pathophysiological states of abdominal organs/glands as it becomes increasingly useful for detecting or characterizing important diffuse disease processes of steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis, providing capabilities unavailable with other imaging techniques. Imaging-based risk prediction of diabetes development may allow earlier detection, diagnosis, and treatment, ultimately improving health outcomes for the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration is a common devastating disease that can lead to blindness. We recently found that loss of blood vessels appears to play an important role in the earliest stages of macular degeneration. The goal of this research program is to pursue new treatments for AMD by determining how blood vessel cells respond to immune injury, what factors make blood vessel cells susceptible to damage, and to develop methods to replace damaged blood vessels using stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancers cannot initiate or progress if their subcellular components are unable to overcome the stresses that accompany uncontrolled proliferation and growth. This Center seeks a predictive understanding of subcellular adaptations that must take place to accommodate and subvert the stresses that naturally occur in response to cancer-causing genetic alterations. Successful models of such adaptations will lead to secondary inferences about where cancer cells become vulnerable as a result of their internal adaptations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Adaptive responses of collecting duct intercalated cells are critical for maintenance of acid-base homeostasis. Although extensive work has been based upon the premise that extracellular pH has direct effects on intercalated cell function, we propose revised paradigm in which proximal tubule-derived ammonia in conjunction with regulated reabsorption in the TAL leads to ammonia-dependent regulation of intercalated cell phenotype and plasticity. The proposed studies will investigate this new paradigm in detail using a variety of approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This SCORE proposals aims to gain a better understanding of the role of the gut microbiome and female sex hormones in the modulation of brain gut microbiome interactions in two of the most common disorders of the gastrointestinal tract, irritable bowel syndrome and chronic functional constipation. To achieve this goal it will study these interactions in 1) female patients during low estrogen states (perimenstrually, post menopausal); 2) by comparing these interactions between female and male patients and healthy control subjects and 3) by studying gut microbial and brain mechanisms underlying the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy. Results obtained from the proposed studies are likely to lead to significant improvements in the treatment of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The Data Processing and Analysis Core will provide the advanced microbiome, metabolomics and neuroimaging tools and technologies necessary to analyze the interactions of neurobiological and molecular mechanisms underlying the brain-gut-microbiome axis, sex differences in this system, the influence of hormones on this system, and how cognitive behavioral therapy alters this system. Elucidation of brain-gut- microbiome pathways cannot be achieved by analysis of microbiome and neuroimaging data sets in isolation. Integration of these distinctive `omics data sets to find biologically meaningful relationships, represents a frontier in bioinformatics that will be critical to identify novel diagnostic and therapeutic targets for IBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In addition to genetic variants, a series of epigenetic, network, and genome organizational perturbations, and their complex interplays, have been reported to contribute to Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRDs), so dissecting such multiple-scale gene regulation rules is the cornerstone to informing new cellular etiologies in such complex disorders. The recent single-cell revolution, especially the multimodal genomic profiling within the same cell, allows us to scrutinize ADRD dysregulations at the finest possible resolution, but its computational modeling is still in its infancy due to its ultra-high dimensionality, complex feature interactions, and high vulnerabilities to numerous confounding factors. This research aims to develop a suite of interpretable deep learning models and open-source software tools to construct personalized regulome via flexible single-cell multiome integration and highlight multi-scale dysregulations contributing to ADRD with detailed mechanistic explanations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This grant will provide new insights into the cause of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and constipation, which are common conditions that affect women more than men and are associated with a poorer quality of life, increased health care visits and costs and a lack of effective treatments. This research project studies the altered communication between the brain, gut, microbiome, and estrogen that are associated with more severe symptoms in women with IBS and constipation. Our findings have the potential to lead to the development of new treatments for these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Addressing substance use and sexual health disparities among urban American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) and Black youth requires multilevel approaches that address the underlying structural conditions that promote inequities; however, researchers rarely employ this complex approach likely due to lack of or inept use of theoretical frameworks. Developing and operationalizing a strengths-based conceptual framework grounded in the socioecological model is critical to inform a multilevel intervention to reduce these inequities. The proposed research study will examine associations among structural contexts, interpersonal level factors, risk and resilience to substance use and sexual risk-taking among Black and AIAN youth to inform the development of a comprehensive conceptual model to be used to guide the development of a multilevel intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Even though IBS is now considered a brain gut disorder, the underlying biological mechanisms, and the role of sex related differences are incompletely understood. We propose to study sex related differences in the structure and function of brain networks that are relevant for IBS, and characterize the modulation of these networks but gut microbial metabolites and estrogen. The results from the proposed studies are likely to identify novel targets for IBS drug development with particular relevance for female patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The first cell differentiation in mammals produces two cell types, the inner cell mass (ICM) and the trophectoderm (TE), which give rise to the embryo proper and the placenta, respectively. Investigating the mechanisms that regulate the specification of these cell types is therefore critical for understanding early pregnancy and the factors that contribute to infertility. In this proposal I investigate how mechanical properties of the nucleus contribute to the specification of the ICM and TE, shedding light on this important early developmental period, and having broader implications for generally understanding cellular transitions during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Cognitive behavior is an effective therapy in IBS, but the biological mechanisms underlying its effectiveness, and the role of sex as a biological variable are not known. The proposed studies aim to study the role of the gut microbiome and its interactions with brain and brainstem regions, as well as clinical and behavioral variables, and determine the role of SAVB in these interactions and in clinical outcomes. The results from these studies have the potential to identify subgroups of patients highly responsive to therapy, as well as underlying biological mediators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Every 30s someone in the world has a limb amputated, with ~300-500 each day in the United States alone, with an estimated total around 2.1 million people living with amputations in the U.S. Sophisticated robotic prosthetic limbs have dramatically increased the level of control a user could have, but evoking naturalistic sensation, such as touch and sense of where the limb is remains a formidable challenge. We propose the development of a highly selective regenerative peripheral nerve interface that uses small electrodes, and molecularly guided sensory subtypes to improve neural interfacing of amputated nerves that will hopefully allow users to touch and feel their loved ones once again.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccination is a powerful intervention to reduce the burden of influenza infections, yet how repeated vaccination shapes the long-term development of protective immune responses to influenza is not clear. This research involves measuring immune responses of participants in a randomized, clinical trial of the inactivated influenza vaccine and using such data to fit predictive models of how vaccination and infection change immunity to influenza over time. This will provide important basic information for improving vaccination strategies against influenza.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the importance that mitochondria play in controlling cell metabolism, few studies have addressed how mitophagy regulates the metabolic state associated with functionally differentiated cells in vivo. Determining the interconnections between SIM2, mitophagy, cell metabolism, and differentiation will provide a better understanding of normal development and associated pathologies. We expect results from these studies will help define the mechanism of mitochondrial adaptation in multiple processes, including normal development and lactation disorders, and breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using a focused implementation research framework, the EPIS (Exploration, Preparation, Implementation and Sustainment) model in a type-2 hybrid design, we will conduct this study in 3 phases: 1) A pre-implementation phase that will use the Exploration and Preparation domains of EPIS to: a) explore barriers and facilitators of CF-CS use, and b) develop a culturally-tailored CM strategy for CF-CS use; 2) An Implementation phase that will use the Implementation domain of EPIS to compare in a cluster RCT of 32 periurban communities (640 households), the effect of CM vs. a self-directed condition (i.e. receipt of information on CF-CS use without CM) on adoption of CF-CS use; and systolic BP reduction; 3) A post-implementation phase that will use the Sustainment domain of EPIS to evaluate the effect of CM strategy vs. self-directed condition on sustainability of the CF-CS use in 640 households across the randomly assigned 32 periurban communities in Nigeria. University of Ibadan working with the MOH will oversee research coordination in Nigeria. The

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep is a critical behavior that is essential to human health, and yet sleep dramatically deteriorates with age. The fundamental question that I will answer in this proposed research program is how sleep impacts brain resilience late in life. Findings from this work will change how we think about the long-term health impact of sleep and provide a novel yet accessible treatment to rejuvenate the aged and diseased brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Summary Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) a genetically dominant progressive muscular dystrophy associated with inappropriate expression of the DUX4 gene. This application focuses on understanding how DUX4 functions and how it perturbs cells, on investigating mechanisms of disease in human cells, and on testing a new therapeutic intervention in a new DUX4-based animal model. This work thus helps us understand the disease and also has the potential to lead to therapies for FSHD based in inhibiting DUX4 activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is an aggressive cancer with unique metabolic rewiring making it highly refractory to the current standards of care. We have shown that these tumors become reliant on particular metabolic pathways creating metabolic bottlenecks. In this proposal we will comprehensively define the metabolic dependencies of PDA tumors in vivo and assess the therapeutic potential of these pathways in mouse models of cancer.
