IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  This R01 application proposes conducting a fully powered trial to test the effectiveness of a patient navigation intervention for Black/African American (B/AA) men who have sex with men (MSM) on PrEP initiation, adherence and retention in care. This study is informed by an R34 pilot intervention that was associated with improvements in PrEP initiation, adherence and retention in care for this population. The objectives of the proposed study are to conduct a fully powered randomized controlled trial and to estimate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the intervention for improving PrEP care outcomes among B/AA MSM in real-world community health center settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bile acids, which are important for promoting fat digestion in the intestine, are made in liver and circulate repeatedly between liver and intestine through the bile and the blood. The transport of bile acids must be tightly controlled, because excess levels of bile acids in blood or tissues can be toxic. We have found that bile acid transport is regulated by the hormone insulin, and this grant is designed to determine how this regulation occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida albicans is a commensal fungus that colonizes the intestine of most healthy people but has the capacity to cause infections and exacerbate inflammation in susceptible people. Immune status determines risk for C. albicans-associated disease, but the impact of immune environment on C. albicans inherent pathogenic potential is not well understood. This proposal aims to comprehensively define the impact both homeostatic and pathogenic immune environments on C. albicans pathogenic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Iron deficiency is the most common single nutrient deficiency in the world and all preterm infants  need enteral iron supplementation to prevent iron deficiency and iron deficiency anemia.  Iron-rich environment can stimulate the growth of enteric pathogens and suppress the growth of  beneficial bacteria. This project will clarify the effects of enteral iron  supplementation on the developing microbiome and intestines in preterm infants and this knowledge  will potentially impact not just the care of preterm infants but also the care of children, and  adults with anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Even though strong scientific evidence shows that self-measured blood pressure monitoring helps patients with hypertension control their blood pressure, less than 1 in 5 hypertensive patients in the United States routinely measure their blood pressure at home, and more than 40% have uncontrolled hypertension. The goal of this proposal is to apply human-centered design to refine an implementation strategy, and then implement and evaluate a telemonitoring-enabled, nurse-supported self-measured blood pressure monitoring intervention (Remote Patient Monitoring for Hypertension) in a primary care network. If successful, this project has the potential to accelerate a change in the paradigm for hypertension management from the clinic to the home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative - Patient Derived Cancer Model (PDCM) Finder Patient derived Cancer Models (PDCM) are developed by taking tumors out of cancer patients and processing them to create cell lines that grow in a dish, “organoids” that recreate a min-version of the tumor in culture, or patient derived xenograft mouse models where the tumor is transplanted into a mouse that lacks an immune system. All three models are used as tools to study how tumors grow and give scientists and doctors the opportunity to test new therapies. This project proposes to collect and combine data across all three model types to allow researchers to find models for their own research and to reuse existing data to enable new discoveries into tumor biology and understand why cancers develop resistance to drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most prevalent problems in children with sickle cell disease are silent cerebral infarcts, small regions of the brain where cells are injured or dead. Silent cerebral infarcts lead to serious problems such as future strokes and learning disabilities, but we do not currently understand why they happen and therefore do not have good ways of preventing them. This proposal will use MRI to measure blood flow throughout the brain in children with sickle cell disease to understand how changes in blood supply may be related to the development of silent cerebral infarcts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A subset of individuals with SARS-COVID-2 infection suffer from long term consequences (Long COVID). The core symptoms are remarkably similar to chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) including debilitating fatigue and dysautonomia. The disease onset shows remarkable interindividual variation and can be triggered by mild disease. This grant contributes to our understanding of the underlying and possibly shared genetic risk factors behind Long COVID and CFS and the impact from infectious triggers on disease risk. The findings will elucidate genetic risk factors and enable the development of prevention strategies for CFS and Long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: COVID-19 pandemic highlights the impact of emerging infectious diseases and the global socioeconomic impact. Alphairuses such as the chikungunya virus (CHIKV) has re-emerged along with many arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses), which continue to pose a significant threat to global human health especially with recent vector expansion into non-endemic regions with no approved therapeutics. Our work will define and develop lead host directed therapeutics to address this gap through virology and medicinal chemistry efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will investigate the ability of vascular normalizing therapies to condition the tumor microenvironment in a manner that is conducive for the development of specialized tertiary lymphoid structures that foster tumor- infiltrating T cell fitness and local diversification in the protective anti-tumor T cell repertoire. Furthermore, based on remarkable gender/sexual dimorphism observed in this operational paradigm, we will investigate the capacity of androgen synthesis inhibitors and androgen receptor antagonists to improve co-therapy outcomes to define novel combination immunotherapies for future translation into the clinic for the more effective treatment of female and male patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will identify an elusive metabolic process centrally governing the immunosuppressive function and expansion of myeloid cells in tumors, which could significantly increase the efficacy of promising approaches for cancer immunotherapy. Specifically, information gathered from this effort is expected to: 1) provide insights into the metabolic signals underlying mitochondrial adaptation and immunoregulatory polarization of myeloid cells in tumors; 2) set the foundation for the development of novel systems to functionally reprogram myelopoiesis in cancer; and 3) boost the effectiveness of immunotherapy by transforming “cold” tumors into “hot” malignancies highly infiltrated by reactive T cells and reprogrammed myeloid cells that sustain anti-tumor activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project studies how cells that die, in particular those neurons dying of necrosis after injury, are recognized by engulfing cells, an event that leads to the internalization and digestion of these dying neurons. During stroke, cancer, and other traumatic situations, many cells undergo necrosis and apoptosis after injury; the swift removal of these cells prevents tissue injury, inflammatory responses, and auto-immune responses, clears the wounded area, and promotes tissue repair. Understanding the mechanisms controlling the recognition of necrotic neurons will have important therapeutic implications in fighting chronic inflammatory and auto-immune diseases, and in treating neurodegenerative diseases and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Porcine islet xenotransplantation is a promising treatment for type 1 diabetes (T1DM), provided that an appropriate genetically-modified donor pig can be identified, and a clinically available and tolerable immunosuppressive regimen can be developed to ensure successful engraftment and rejection-free survival of the transplanted islets. The overall goal of the proposed studies therefore is to use our established preclinical model of islet xenotransplantation to study strategies of porcine islet modifications and recipient immunomodulation that will promote porcine islet engraftment and survival. We hope to advance porcine islet xenotransplantation for T1DM from preclinical studies to clinical reality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Stiffening and disorganization of the extracellular matrix (ECM) can serve as important cellular cues that can promote degenerative processes. The proposed study will determine the relevance of substrate stiffness and topography on the activation of the mechanoreceptor TRPV4 in annulus fibrosus cells and will elucidate whether TRPV4 regulates ECM synthesis/remodeling. Investigating cell-substrate interactions in the annulus fibrosus is of high significance as it will help to properly understand mechanotransduction processes underlying spinal health and disease (e.g. intervertebral disc herniation) and advance tissue engineering approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Hematopoietic Stem cells (HSCs) must balance self-renewal and differentiation to give rise to all the mature hematopoietic cells and sustain the longevity of the organism. This proposal will ascribe an etiology to the heterogeneity within in the stem cell compartment by attributing differences in stem cell behavior to the actions of a dose-dependent, homeodomain-containing transcription factor, CUX1. An understanding of the molecular cause and cellular consequences of HSC heterogeneity could provide methods to modulate stem cell behavior to treat hematopoietic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is an immune-mediated chronic disease in which T cells produce high levels of inflammatory cytokines. This study aims to understand how rare genetic variants and abnormal signaling pathways cause JIA T cells to make high amounts of the inflammatory cytokines, interleukin 17 and interferon gamma. These discoveries will identify how inflammatory cells and cytokines develop in JIA with the goal of generating novel therapeutic targets and improving diagnostic and therapeutic decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: RELEVANCE: This project will result in the development of cluster/cloud scale HistoTools to enable curation of large-scale digital slide data lakes via (a) timely identification of poor-quality slides and slide regions, (b) quantitative metrics driving optimized cohort selection for compensation of batch effects, and (c) generation of highly precise and relevant object annotations and labels. The employment of HistoTools will facilitate (a) the creation of companion diagnostic assays in the cancer, kidney disease, and heart rejection space via curation and release of over 14k WSI, and (b) external collaborators validating the tools on 100k WSI, thus helping drive global onsite curation of well-curated data lakes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because OSA is a major health concern that is inadequately treated with existing therapies. The NHLBI 2011 Sleep Disorders Research Plan states that “studies are needed to identify clinically meaningful subtypes [of OSA], and algorithms informing the selection of optimal therapeutic strategies.” The proposed research directly addresses this important component of the NIH's mis- sion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative From 2005-2014, the rate of alcohol binging among the elderly rose 20% overall and by 50% in women only, and Alcohol use disorder (AUD) in mid-life is shown to be a significant, independent predictor of late-life dementia, particularly vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) including the Cerebral Amyloid Angiography (CAA) subtype. CAA VCID is accompanied by disruptions in the toxin-clearing flow of fluid in the brain, and there is reason to believe that alcohol abuse can compromise the fluid flow through the brain and worsen the CAA and dementia, particularly later in life. Therefore our goal is to learn how and why (i.e., biochemical regulators) the fluid flow is disrupted and if it can be improved as a potential way to help people with VCID, especially those who engage in risky levels of drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Currently used conventional metrics for sleep apnea assessment has many limitations including insufficient consideration of acute cardiovascular response to sleep apnea event. We propose to study whether the degree of acute blood pressure elevation associated with sleep apnea can help better identify people with higher cardiovascular risk and a more favorable response to therapy. We will also investigate whether there is a racial difference in the degree of blood pressure elevation, which may explain cardiovascular health disparity in African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) remains a major cause of maternal morbidity and mortality. Inhibition of prolactin with the dopamine agonist bromocriptine appeared to improve outcomes in previous clinical studies of PPCM; however, no randomized trial has been performed in a multi-racial North American cohort comparing bromocriptine against standard heart failure therapy. The purpose of the Randomized Evaluation of Bromocriptine Therapy for Peripartum Cardiomyopathy (REBIRTH) trial is to evaluate whether the addition of bromocriptine to standard heart failure therapy improves outcomes in women with PPCM.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Procreation is a fundamental aspect of life that occurs when a sperm fuses with an egg. The disrupted formation of sperm and eggs, also known as germ cells, can result in infertility, spontaneous abortions, and birth defects, yet many aspects of germ cell development remain poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to study the regulation of meiosis, a specialized cellular division that is required to produce haploid sperm and eggs, using mouse as the model organism, and discoveries made from this work will provide insights that are relevant to human health and fertility. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major contributor to peri-operative morbidity and mortality experienced by patients undergoing on-pump cardiac surgery is ischemia reperfusion injury to the myocardium and other organs caused by aortic cross- clamping to isolate the heart from the systemic circulation. The proposed NAD+ Augmentation in Cardiac Surgery Associated Myocardial Injury (NACAM) trial will be a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo- controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of oral nicotinamide for the prevention of peri-operative myocardial injury in 304 patients. The primary endpoint in this study is the serum cardiac troponin T concentration Area Under the Curve (AUC) as a marker of myocardial injury, with secondary outcomes being incident acute kidney injury and the urinary quinolinate/tryptophan ratio as a mechanistic marker of impaired de novo NAD+ biosynthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how underlying disease mechanisms in overactive bladder contribute to the development of urinary symptoms, including urinary urgency and urgency incontinence, is highly relevant to public health. The proposed, interdisciplinary research that includes experts in Urology, Psychology, and chronic pain research will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of how psychology relates to bladder sensitivity and to psychological burdens in people with overactive bladder and how this can be measured effectively. This will allow future studies in which interventions to improve bladder health and incontinence can be implemented and outcomes recorded, with the goal of improving bladder health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biological patterning relies on the coordination of cell-cell communication events across large and small distances, and defects in patterning can lead to human disorders and disease. Cytonemes are one example of an active cell process that coordinates cell signaling for many patterning events during vertebrate and invertebrate development. The goal of this work is to understand both how cytonemes are regulated at the cellular scale and how they contribute to the overall progression of patterning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organism survival is dependent on proper tissue and organ function, which requires a significant amount of energy to ensure correct organ-to-organ communication and maintenance of tissue stem cells. We propose to take advantage of the excellent model my lab has established using transcription factors and stem cells in the fruit fly ovary to understand how inter-organ communication maintains tissue behavior. Our work will generate new insight into how disruption of organ communication might lead to tissue abnormalities in many organisms, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE African-Americans are disproportionately burdened by disrupted/misaligned circadian rhythms, disturbed sleep and specific sleep disorders, such as sleep apnea, which is likely contributing to the high burden of adverse cardiometabolic health in this population; yet the underlying determinants are unknown. The proposed study investigates the impact of multilevel socio-environmental factors (household and neighborhood-level) on psychosocial factors, circadian and sleep disruption, and subsequently adverse cardiometabolic health in African-Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite substantial advances in our ability to collect genomic data and catalog genetic variation, understanding how the collection of proteins in an organism create phenotype is difficult to determine because phenotype emerges from a hierarchy of protein interactions: proteins interact to create complexes, pathways, and phenotypes. To date, no method exists to elucidate a hierarchy of protein interactions. Using bacteria as a model, this proposal seeks to develop and validate a novel statistical approach that defines hierarchically layered networks of protein interactions that describe the emergence of complex phenotype from a `parts-list' of proteins from genome sequence alone. In the emerging era of `big-data' in biology, such an approach substantially aid in relating genotype with cellular behavior, and may be a generally effective framework towards parsing high-content, complex biological data.

PHR: Project Narrative: Early sensing of mucosal barrier damage by migratory group 2 innate lymphoid cells (iILC2) during helminth infection is important for the induction of type-2 immunity and barrier repair. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex assembly of hundreds of proteins and a critical regulator of cancer progression. Compared to other proteins, ECM proteins are understudied, mainly because of challenges posed by their chemical properties (large size, insolubility, broad dynamic range). The proposed project will harness these challenges and focus on the development of transformative proteomic technologies to study with great depth the protein composition and architecture of the extracellular matrix of cancers. By doing so, we believe we will be able to better understand the mechanisms leading to cancer progression and thus identify novel proteins that can either better predict cancer outcome or be targeted therapeutically to treat cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The explosion of genomic and biological information is poised to transform the practice of medicine, but its impact will be determined by the clinician’s ability to absorb, assimilate and translate this body of knowledge. Dr. Florez has dedicated himself to advance genomic and metabolomic discoveries in type 2 diabetes and related metabolic traits, and previously generated useful resources and established a training pipeline. He now seeks to continue attracting and mentoring a cadre of highly trained investigators who will be empowered to lead the application of these findings to the clinical setting, by 1) expanding an infrastructure of pertinent genomic and physiologic datasets, 2) maintaining a rigorous training pipeline embedded in a cutting-edge clinical and scientific environment, and 3) guiding the investigation of clinically relevant hypotheses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is designed to establish academic and continuing education (CE) courses in emerging technologies specific to site biological/infectious agent safety. This collaborative, multidimensional educational experience will facilitate not only skills development and field application, but also create opportunities for innovative, cross-disciplinary research experiences and curriculum development on emerging technologies. The specific aims of this project are the successful development, implementation, and evaluation of 1) a continuing education (CE) certificate program focused on site biological and infectious agent health and safety, 2) a collaborative research-oriented academic course, and 3) a field practitioner course that utilizes the research products from the research-oriented academic course emphasizing emerging technologies in biological and infectious agent health and safety, offered collaboratively between the partnering institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. People with Down syndrome (DS) display profound immune dysregulation, which could have myriad negative impacts on their health, including the development of various immune and neurological disorders. Multiple lines of evidence indicate that hyperactivation of interferon (IFN) signaling drives immune dysregulation in DS. This proposal aims to complete a clinical trial in adults with DS and immune skin conditions, using a pharmacological inhibitor of IFN signaling, which is expected to have multidimensional therapeutic benefits in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The physical properties of the tissue environment play an important role in numerous diseases/disorders spanning cancer, pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. Changes in these physical properties alter how nanotherapeutics interact with cells, while creating new opportunities for targeting diseased tissue. This proposal seeks to understand how extracellular stiffness and dynamic forces alter nanoparticle efficacy, and then leverage these propertes to design novel nanoparticles that have improved targeting and trafficking in dysfunctional tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The sexual stages of Toxoplasma gondii contribute to high toxoplasmosis prevalence and severe disease in immunocompromised individuals. Our lab discovered that the fatty acid linoleic acid enables growth of T. gondii sexual stages outside the definitive cat host. The proposed work will help us understand how linoleic acid affects host and parasite to support T. gondii sexual development, with the goal of using that knowledge to prevent T. gondii transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The use of anesthesia to block patients’ traumatic experiences during surgery is one of the most remarkable innovations of mankind, yet how these special drugs affect the brain to disrupt conscious experience is not fully understood. Using advanced imaging and other real-time measures of brain function in human subjects, the proposed neuroscience research will determine how and where in the brain different anesthetics work to prevent the experience of pain and to block formation of unwanted memory. Understanding how complex interconnected brain systems are affected by different anesthetics, particularly when used together, will improve the ability to provide the optimal combination of medications to patients needing anesthesia for otherwise painful procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Contemporary diets are rich in sodium chloride and low in potassium, which in combination can cause salt- sensitive high blood pressure due to maladaptive mechanisms that originate in the kidney. A family of enzymes called WNK kinases participates in this process. In this project, we will explore a novel mechanism that organizes and activates WNK kinases in salt-handling kidney tubule cells as they shrink during stress. The proposed studies will advance our basic understanding of how WNK kinases function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE While the Pap test has been routinely performed for over 50 years to screen women for cervical cancer, there is currently no reliable method to screen women for ovarian cancer. Our preliminary data suggest that proteins shed by ovarian cancer cells are present in the residual Pap test fixative and on cervical swabs, and that these proteins can be quantified by targeted mass spectrometry-based proteomic techniques. This study lays the groundwork for incorporating the routine Pap test or a self-administered cervical swab into a clinical assay that can be used to identify 21,000 new cases of ovarian cancer annually in the United States, thereby saving the lives of women by earlier detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a common inherited disorder accounting for ~5% of the dialysis and kidney transplant population in the US. This grant seeks to determine new genetic causes of this disease, develop cellular and whole animal systems to determine the significance of variants found in genes causing ADPKD, explore treatment options that take advantage of increased understanding of the ADPKD mutational mechanism, and determine the importance of genetic events within cystic cells to disease development. These studies will result in a better understanding of the causes of ADPKD and improve diagnostics and treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the Zika virus (ZIKV) infection has been linked to congenital glaucoma, the molecular mechanisms of the disease are still unknown. Thus, elucidation of pathological mechanisms underlying TM dysfunction in ZIKV- induced glaucoma is of paramount importance to identify key pathways that can be targeted to develop new therapeutics for the prevention of infectious glaucoma. This study will use human primary trabecular meshwork cells (HTMC) and mouse neonate pups and congenital infection models to investigate the role of ZIKV infection in the pathobiology of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We focus on understanding fundamental mechanisms governing immune modulation and progression of disseminated tumor cells at the metastatic sites, both of which carry immense clinical relevance in treating metastatic disease in women with triple negative breast cancer, for which there currently is no cure. Moreover, the proposed studies focusing on tumor-derived exosomes carry a high translational potential in the development of liquid biopsy-based biomarkers for noninvasive detection, and discovery of new targets for immunotherapy and prevention of metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed Penn Implementation Science Center in Cancer Control (Penn ISC3) is to advance the science and practice of implementing evidence-based practices for individuals with cancer. The creation of the Penn ISC3 will leverage the deep expertise and resources at the University of Pennsylvania in implementation science, behavioral economics, and cancer care delivery research to address strategic priorities emphasized in the National Cancer Institute Moonshot Blue Ribbon Panel. Specifically, our focus and grand challenge theme is to test implementation strategies informed by behavioral economics to improve uptake of evidence-based practices within our Implementation Laboratory, Penn Medicine, including those from traditionally underserved populations, to improve the lives of individuals with cancer. Penn ISC3 will produce new knowledge with the potential to reduce the research-to-practice gap in cancer care and improve outcomes for millions of Americans. PHR: Project Narrative Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a highly aggressive, recalcitrant and deadly cancer with no effective treatment. We have found that SCLC leads to production of neoantigens and autoantibodies, the binding sequence of which can be engineered into chimeric antigen receptor T cells (CAR-Ts) that could provide a badly needed new avenue for SCLC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Precise optical scanning of 3D whole body shape is now possible with cheap commercial scanners available on smart phones and tablets. These cheap and accessible scans may hold a heretofore-untapped wealth of health- related information that can be utilized with machine learning. In this proposal, we use the technology to study the physiological and psychological effects in subjects with severe obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Pain is the hallmark of sickle cell disease (SCD), and is the leading cause of hospitalizations, emergency room visits, missed school, and is associated with an increased death rate. We found that patients with SCD and pain had low levels of the amino acid arginine in their blood, and we also demonstrated that arginine supplementation during acute pain events significantly reduced the amount of opioids needed to treat sickle cell pain in children and dramatically improved pain scores at discharge compared to placebo. We propose to investigate the benefits and safety of arginine for the treatment of patients with SCD and pain in a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial where neither the patient nor the clinical team know which therapy the patient is receiving, since Arginine is a promising nutritional therapy that could change the way we treat acute pain in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A detection technology based on evanescent field scattering of protein oscillators will be developed to detect and identify proteins, and to analyze protein-protein interactions. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are reapplying to include the Wisconsin Infant Study Cohort (WISC), involving a critical rural underserved population, in the next phase of the Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO) program. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Emergency department (ED) providers admit nearly all patients with acute heart failure (AHF). Some tools exist to aid in identifying AHF patients safe for discharge, but they are largely unused due to poor validation and lack of effective deployment and implementation. We developed and validated an AHF tool to safely facilitate ED discharge, and this study aims to overcome implementation barriers through a clinical decision support-based implementation strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Modern human genetics has provided remarkable insights into the molecular basis of cancer, but many genetically-defined cancer targets lack chemical probes and are even considered potentially undruggable. The goal of this research program is to leverage our lab’s pioneering chemical proteomic technologies to radically expand the druggable content of human cancer cells for the creation of chemical probes and, ultimately, therapeutics for biologically compelling human cancer targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The accuracy of conventionally available R2*-MRI for liver iron quantification is negatively affected by patient motion and a high concentration of iron as commonly seen in patients with transfusion-induced iron overload. Accurate liver iron quantification is critical for managing iron overload and evaluating the efficacy of chelation treatment aimed at reducing body iron stores while minimizing adverse effects of chelator administration. This project will develop a rapid, motion-tolerant, and free-breathing abdominal R2*-MRI method, providing high- resolution volumetric liver R2* images for accurate iron quantification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Narrative  There is a need for simple, rapid, and cost-effective methods for detecting and differentiating infections that present with similar symptoms but require different treatment and management strategies. This is particularly important for respiratory infections, including COVID-19 and influenza, which can spread quickly through the population. We propose to develop a simple-to-use and cost-effective respiratory panel suitable for use in urgent care clinics and physicians’ offices that will rapidly identify COVID-19, influenza, and other viral/bacterial infections directly from nasopharyngeal swab samples with no required sample preparation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Prevention of postpartum hemorrhage using antifibrinolytic therapy, specifically tranexamic acid, has great potential in the field of obstetrics. We will conduct a clinical pharmacokinetic study to find the lowest drug dose that will be needed for optimal hemostasis when tranexamic acid is given prior to delivery so maternal benefit is maximized and fetal/neonatal risk is minimized. Ultimately, this translational research is critical to better understanding the role tranexamic acid will have to prevent postpartum hemorrhage and maternal deaths worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Inherited and acquired forms of muscle weakness lead to significant morbidity and mortality. At present, 50% of patients have variants of unknown significance in genes associated with inherited forms of muscle weakness. This proposal will develop tools to assess genetic variants for potential pathogenicity and understand the phenotypic progression of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasing prevalence of pregnant and postpartum women affected by Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) in the US is highlighted by the growing number of babies referred to the NICU for Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome after birth. Despite recent advances in integrating mental health and substance abuse treatment into adult healthcare settings, no current treatment models exist to integrate maternal OUD treatment and referrals into the pediatric care setting making it unlikely that mothers will be able to access care. In order to preserve the dyadic bond, improve maternal functioning, and provide a more stable environment for the infant, we now embark on a study utilizing steps from implementation mapping to identify facilitators and barriers to integrated maternal OUD treatment and referral in the NICU, adapt existing evidence-based models of co-located OUD care to the NICU setting, refine our new interventions, and examine the feasibility and acceptability of our new model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The Vision Research Core Grant will provide crucially needed expertise/instrumentation to enhance research related to the visual system under normal and diseased conditions. To achieve this goal, facilities, services and shared instrumentation have been organized into three modules: (1) Visual Function Assessment; (2) Histology and Imaging; (3) Gene Expression/Proteomics. These modules will enhance the capability of vision researchers to engage in high impact research/discovery for patients suffering from blindness and visual disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Lumbar spinal stenosis, a common condition in older adults, can cause pain and difficulty walking (i.e., intermittent neurogenic claudication - INC). Patients with INC not infrequently undergo spinal surgery that fails to help them 1/3-1/2 the time. The purpose of this multi-site feasibility study is to prepare for the conduct of a randomized controlled trial to test the efficacy of manual therapy, exercise, and intramuscular electroacupuncture in reducing pain and improving walking ability for those with INC, and ultimately limiting the need for surgical referrals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The size and shape of the ocular lens are essential to proper health and function. However, the mechanisms governing adult lens shape have not been characterized. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal aims to define molecular mechanisms regulating formation of specific subcortical circuits that potentially mediate visually-driven defensive behaviors. Proper neuronal connectivity within specific circuits underlies appropriate behavioral responses, and defective developmental wiring often disrupts such behaviors in a variety of neurological disorders. The success of the proposed project should provide new insights into assembly of the neural circuits conveying reactions to the visual threat and help us understand both function and dysfunction of fear-related brain circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Picornaviruses are significant pathogens worldwide, causing some of the highest levels of human morbidity of all known viruses. These RNA-containing viruses include human rhinovirus, poliovirus, coxsackievirus, enterovirus 71, enterovirus D68, and many others. The project described in this application will explore how rhinoviruses hijack specific nuclear proteins during infection of human cells to carry out functions essential for viral replication in the cytoplasm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is associated with significant micro- and macrovascular complications, increased risk of shortened life span, and impacts on the brain and cognition that lead to significant personal costs and public health burdens that are likely to increase in line with increased T1D incidence. The CLARiFY study will document the mid-adult outcomes of childhood-onset T1D in a cohort followed at intervals for 30 years from diagnosis, and use these collective data to define which metabolic insults are most detrimental to the brain/cognition and at which age/stage of neurodevelopment. This information will allow clinicians to offer optimal clinical management designed to achieve good metabolic outcomes, while at the same time protecting the developing brain and preserving cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Children with multisensory vision and hearing loss (DeafBlindness) experience extreme delays in exposure to language, negatively impacting cognitive development and quality of life. This project aims to test whether a new, fully tactile language called protactile, used in interactions with DeafBlind adults, can support DeafBlind children’s development. Results will inform future early interventions for DeafBlind children and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 is an ongoing global pandemic affecting millions of patients who survive but are at risk for developing ongoing cardiopulmonary symptoms. COVID-19 has been shown to be capable of causing cardiac injury, but long-term clinical consequences including duration of symptoms, effort tolerance, and prognosis are unknown. State-of-the-art cardiac MRI exams will be performed in a multiethnic New York City registry of COVID-19 survivors to address key knowledge gaps concerning clinical prognosis after infection which are critical to guide surveillance, risk stratification and targeted treatment for at risk COVID-19 survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine how sex as a biological variable impacts the progression of both aortic root aneurysm and coronary artery pathology in the context of the hereditary condition Marfan Syndrome. This work will identify how women may be resilient to aneurysm severity but more vulnerable to spontaneous coronary artery dissection events. Our findings will inform potential novel therapeutic targets and sex-specific strategies for both men and women with arterial disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE A fundamental challenge for the scientific community in the 21st century is learning how to turn data into evidence that can inform decision-making about improving health and preventing illness at the individual and population levels. Real-time infectious disease forecasting is a prime example of a field with great potential for leveraging modern analytical methods to maximize the impact on public health. The goal of the proposed research is to develop statistical modeling frameworks and pipelines for making forecasts of infectious diseases in real-time and integrating these forecasts into public health decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficiencies in peroxisomes have been associated with a variety of disease states, including inherited neuropathologies, aging, heart disease, cancer, and diabetes. Experiments outlined in this proposal seek to elucidate the importance of UBXD8 in maintaining peroxisome homeostasis and the subsequent impact on cellular pathways involved in the development of lipid metabolic diseases. Results from this proposal will inform novel molecular mechanisms by which peroxisome abundance is regulated thus bringing us closer to potential therapeutic targets for treating lipid metabolic diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Succinate dehydrogenase is a mitochondrial complex with critical roles in metabolism and. Inherited loss-of- function variants in the succinate dehydrogenase genes are causative in several human cancers, and tumors have been linked to DNA damage. This proposal aims to accurately characterize the phenotypes and tumor biology associated with succinate dehydrogenase germline pathogenic variants, to develop improved risk estimates and evaluate potential targeted therapies for patients who progress to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance In all living organisms, a molecular machine called the ribosome synthesizes proteins, and decodes the genetic code of messenger RNA (mRNA) in the process of translation. Some mRNAs are translated orders of magnitude more efficiently than the others for reasons that are poorly understood. Translational control by mRNA structure plays an important role in cancer development, and is critical for the infectivity of human viruses such as immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and SARS-CoV-2, which causes the COVID-19 pandemic. We study how structural signals in mRNA regulate translation. Our studies will provide the basis for future development of antiviral and cancer therapies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Structural Dynamics of Translation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: With development of preventative and therapeutic interventions, we were able to extend human life, but the final years or even decades of life are riddled with diseases and disability. Aging is a common risk factor for all aging-related diseases, therefore, if we could delay aging, we could extend the part of the life that is lived in good health. Our study aims to discover if broken functioning of the hypothalamus, the brain region that regulates hormones and metabolism of the entire body, is a reason for faster aging in some people, as these discoveries could lead to future therapies to delay aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertension (HTN) is especially morbid for rural individuals, who experience limited health care access, geographic isolation, low health literacy, and health-related disparities. The proposed research is relevant to public health by improving HTN treatment and management in disadvantaged rural individuals with this common, chronic condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (IAD) are at high-risk of premature relocation to long-term care settings primarily due to caregiver burden and concerns with functional capacity and safety. We propose to develop and test a smart home-linked assistive robot, Mobile Assistive Robot with Smart Sensing (MARSS), to support care of IAD in their own home, as well as optimize the behavior mechanism leading to its adoption. This research will contribute to the knowledge on innovative (yet real world) technological solutions to promote independence, health, and safety of IAD to sustain living at home, as well as the behavioral mechanisms involved in adoption of such technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for effective substance use disorder prevention strategies for high-risk youth; currently, few evidence-based services exist, particularly within the context of the patient-centered medical home. We propose to pilot test and optimize a parent-youth dyadic intervention that aims to increase family resilience, strengthen coping skills, help families plan for the future, and improve youth outcomes. Our findings will directly inform the preparation of a randomized efficacy trial of thoroughly field-tested intervention model, with a long-term goal of preventing or reducing illicit and nonmedical prescription drug use among youth whose parents are in recovery from substance use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Prognostic biomarkers support precision-based treatments yet are lacking for patients with chronic lower back pain. Here, I aim to use advanced electroencephalogram-based neuroimaging strategies to identify and characterize biomarkers of dysfunctional brain networks (resting-state, cognitive, and emotional) in patients with chronic low back pain across time. The information gained from this study will increase our understanding of the neural processes underlying chronic pain and inform future patient-oriented research and solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the urgent need to develop novel pharmacological treatment for alcohol use disorder (AUD), and the promising preliminary reports of the fast-acting and long-lasting effects of psychedelic compounds, we propose to investigate the therapeutic potential of psychedelic N,N-dimethyltryptamine (DMT) plus a brief course of psychotherapy (including Motivational Enhancement Therapy (MET)) on alcohol use disorder (AUD) in a proof- of-concept, randomized (1:1), placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel group, laboratory study and clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fungal infections resistant to current antimicrobials is a growing public health concern that has received much media attention. The proposed project seeks to address this problem by characterizing and further developing a novel therapeutic – peptides derived from a bacterial protein with efficacy against human fungal agents in multiple animal models. Specifically, the goals are to understand and improve the efficacious features of the peptide and elucidate its mechanism of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Signal Transduction by Engineered Extracellular Matrices Gordon Research Conference (STEEM GRC) will focus on the interface of biology and engineering and gather multidisciplinary scientists to disseminate state-of-the-art research in highly active areas including single cell biology, multi-scale modeling, mechanobiology, and engineered extracellular matrices (ECM) to investigate and control cell function. The resulting multidisciplinary education will benefit our diverse colleagues as they advance our understanding of how ECMs interface with cellular signaling networks, both in regenerative medicine and in understanding and treating human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anti-retroviral therapy (ART) has saved many patients with HIV infection, which now is a treatable disease. Increased cardiovascular risk in long-term HIV survivors on ART with no detectable virus load, however, is projected to be a global health burden. Despite its clinical impact, underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Inflammation plays an important role in the development of atherosclerosis. The HIV-associated protein Nef appears to promote inflammation. We will use a multi-disciplinary research platform to discover novel mechanisms for accelerated atherosclerotic vascular disease in HIV survivors and to provide molecular bases for new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative With the expansion of cochlear implant candidacy, the pool of people who are likely to qualify now includes children and adults with more residual hearing including those with single sided deafness or asymmetric hearing loss. Expected CI outcomes are characterized by a fuller hearing experience that includes spatial hearing, listening in noise, access to environmental sounds, and enjoyment of music as well as associated benefits like cognition in older adults and quality of life in recipients of all ages. The CI conferences will explore these topics, addressing how CI professionals can best provide appropriate clinical services and reach underserved groups while still maintaining a sustainable clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative A core mission of the National Eye Institute (NEI) is to support research on the retina and early visual system in order to build scientific knowledge that facilitates the development of novel therapies for blindness. The FASEB Science Research Conference on “Retinal Neurobiology and Visual Processing,” held biennially for 30 years, is the premier meeting in the field and supports the mission of the NEI by assembling a diverse group of early-career and established scientists to openly exchange new theories, techniques and research findings on the retina in a secluded setting. The meeting supports early-stage trainees and junior faculty, with an emphasis on women and members of underrepresented groups in science, and includes interactive workshops on novel methodology and career development; opportunities to present research findings in formal oral and poster presentations; and informal opportunities to interact with peers and form new collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project proposes to identify novel biomarkers that predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) and new therapies to enhance ICI efficacy in patients with gastric cancer. The proposal is relevant to public health because the expected results will help improve patient quality of life by avoiding futile therapy given to patients who will not benefit from ICI and increase survival by improving the effects of the therapy. Thus, the proposal is relevant to the NIH’s mission to reduce illness and lengthen life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  For 63 years, the Society for Birth Defects Research and Prevention (BDRP) has promoted basic and clinical research to understand the causes and mechanisms of birth defects, the potential effects of drug, chemical, infectious, or other exposures on the developing embryo/fetus, improve reproductive health, understand developmental origins of adult disease, and translate these discoveries into clinical practice. The Annual Meeting provides a forum for scientists, clinicians, and science policy regulators from academic, industrial, and government sectors to present cutting-edge research, exchange ideas and information, and engage in discussions among established experts in the field, new researchers, and students. The goals of the BDRP align with the goals of NICHD in advancing the knowledge on reproduction and embryo-fetal and postnatal development, as evidenced by the theme of the 2024 Annual Meeting, Addressing Disparities in Birth Defects Research and Prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Relevance: Individual differences, social factors and sex are variables that influence vulnerability, maintenance and treatment outcomes in human drug addiction. The research proposed in this application will utilize socially housed female and male monkeys self-administering cocaine to further explore behavioral (alternative reinforcers, impulsive choice, punishment, cognition), pharmacological (chronic drug treatments) and brain changes using positron emission tomography. Results from these studies should aid in the development of personalized medicine strategies for cocaine use disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal seeks funding to support increased participation from a diverse group of early career scientists, researchers and clinicians during three in-person Congresses of the International Society of Electrophysiological Kinesiology (ISEK) and four virtual conferences over a five-year period. Funding will be used to support travel and family caregiving costs, augmenting the programming ISEK has developed to enhance scientific, networking, and professional development opportunities for all our early career researchers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 2024 FASEB Science Research Conference on Trace Elements in Biology and Medicine will bring together researchers performing the latest, cutting-edge research that advances our understanding of the roles of trace elements in biology, nutrition, health, and disease. Trace elements such as iron, zinc, copper, manganese, and selenium are essential for life, and imbalances in their uptake, distribution, storage, or excretion result in a large number of nutritional and metabolic disorders. This conference plays a critical role in bridging basic and applied research in trace elements and in training the next generation of scientists in this exciting and expanding field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Economic choice is observed when individuals choose between multiple options based on subjective preference – for example out of a restaurant menu. It is specifically impaired in several clinical conditions including schizophrenia and drug addiction. Our current goal is to dissect the neural circuit underlying economic decisions using a combination of two-photon calcium imaging and optogenetic stimulation in mice. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Health Relevance Statement The goal of this research is to develop new statistical methods for the comprehensive analysis of Substance Use Disorder (SUD). By integrating diverse data types from human and model organism samples, these methods aim to identify affected cells, driver regulators, and gene regulatory networks associated with SUD, thereby advancing our understanding of addiction at a systems level and contributing to future efforts in addiction prevention and treatment. The relevance of this research lies in addressing SUD as a critical global health issue with significant risks to physical and mental well-being, as well as economic burdens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To avoid potential harm, we are equipped with brain circuits that allow detecting, learning, and responding to perceived threats in our environment. Dysregulation in these processes often denotes psychopathological conditions such as post-traumatic stress and anxiety disorders. This study examines how specific neuronal populations process perceived threats to guide behavioral defenses, thus providing novel insights into the neural mechanisms underlying threat processing in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Neuromodulatory systems, such as acetylcholine and norepinephrine, play a profound role in regulating the activity and function of cortical circuits. However, little is known about the spatiotemporal dynamics of neuromodulatory release during behavior and cognition. This proposal will use novel imaging techniques to determine the state-dependent pattern of noradrenergic signaling in the intact cortex, the impact of norepinephrine on cortical activity, and the coordination between different neuromodulatory systems. We expect our findings to provide important insights into neuromodulatory signaling in the healthy brain and to identify potential therapeutic targets to ameliorate pathology in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The 3’,5’-cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) and 3’,5’-cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) pathways, which are regulated by cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterases (PDEs), modulate a number of critical physiological processes. As such, targets within these signaling cascades have long been of high interest to drug discovery efforts. This meeting will bring together scientists from a wide range of disciplines to discuss cyclic nucleotide signaling across numerous organs to promote cross-field fertilization of ideas, collaboration and the identification of novel mechanisms by which these signaling cascades can be harnessed for therapeutic gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of novel anti-tau protein therapies is a critical need in the pursuit of interventions for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias. Here, we will develop and test (in a mouse model of tauopathy) a novel immuno-gene therapy approach involving AAV-mediated expression of a single chain variable domain from an anti-tau antibody, called TNT2, that binds an N-terminal motif displayed in a conformation-dependent fashion and is closely linked to tau toxicity. This work will allow the initial development and validation of a novel anti-tau therapy that could have a significant impact towards treating AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The meeting will bring together diverse researchers investigating the process of extracting diagnostic information from medical images to render accurate and efficient diagnostic decisions. Opportunities for advanced, interdisciplinary training of young scientists interested in medical image perception research and its relevance to disease prevention and treatment are often quite limited. Since 1997, 128 trainees have been awarded MIPS scholarships, having a significant impact on the field by creating opportunities and offering supportive mentoring at this formative stage in the trainee’s career to enhance their research potential and likelihood of success as independent basic science and clinician-scientist researchers.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The goal of the current application is to characterize functionally distinct non-coding regulatory elements in major neuronal types for which rare and common variant risk loci are most enriched in neuropsychiatric disorders, identify their target genes, and elucidate how noncoding variants affect the transcription of key genes for neuronal cell identity and activity-regulated signaling networks. The proposed research has the potential to develop an innovative approach and unravel the neurobiological functions of the vast but in the brain largely unexplored non-coding sequences of the human genome, which is relevant to the mission of NIH to acquire new knowledge to help prevent, detect, diagnose, and treat disease and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to address the need for robust, rigorous and computationally efficient methods for optimizing Just-In-Time Adaptive Interventions (JITAIs) to prevent and treat substance use disorders (SUD). Although the proposed methods are motivated by micro randomized trials (MRTs) in SUD, they can be extended to observa- tional studies and employed to develop effective JITAIs in other health domains as well. The methods developed in this project will help SUD scientists to more effectively leverage emerging technologies (e.g., mobile and wear- able devices) to deliver support in a timely and ecological manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Collagens are a major component of the pancreatic cancer microenvironment, which has been implicated in the regulation of tumor malignancy. Our research focuses on understanding the function of a unique collagen receptor, known as DDR1 (Discoidin Domain Receptor 1), that transmits collagen signals in pancreatic cancer cells, mediating metastatic progression. Our studies deploy a synergistic team of experts focused on dissecting the roles of collagen-stimulated DDR1 in pancreatic cancer signaling and metastasis, with the future goal of targeting this signaling axis for improving pancreatic cancer patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Minority populations, which constitute a growing fraction of the total US population, experience a significantly higher risk of death or disability from heart disease or stroke, and have historically been medically underserved, in part due to a lack of minority cardiovascular researchers. The goal of this R25 program is to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities pursuing careers in cardiovascular medical research by providing undergraduate underrepresented minority (URM) students with a short-term mentored research experience in the laboratories of Stanford Medicine’s Cardiovascular Institute. Participation in mentored research increases the degree to which URM students identify as scientists, which in turn increases the likelihood that URM students persist in research careers.

PHR: Project narrative The International Conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer Assisted Intervention (MICCAI) is the premier meeting in the medical image computing and computer assisted intervention communities. In this proposal, we request funds to support the participation of US-based students and early career investigators with focus on underrepresented and minority groups in the MICCAI editions of 2024, 2025 and 2026. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Motivated states have profound influences on behavioral selection. While decades of work have focused on the neural mechanisms underlying motivation for specific drives like hunger and thirst, we know far less about how the brain generates motivation for specific social drives. This study will determine whether and how the brain may encode divergent socially motivated states at the neural, behavioral, and molecular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and the sequelae of immunosuppression have been a major barrier to the success of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT), which can potentially cure hematological cancers such as leukemia, lymphoma and myeloma. Id3, a transcriptional regulator, regulates the formation and maintenance of tissue-infiltrating T cells that are critical for GVHD maintenance and leukemia control through coordinating the expression of genes engaged in effector differentiation and memory T cell development. The investigations proposed will define the effect of tissue-infiltrating alloreactive T cells in mediating pathogenicity of GVHD and leukemia control, characterize the role of Id3 in these cells during GVHD, and establish the beneficial effect of ID3-engineered chimeric antigen-receptor (CAR) T cells on eliminating leukemia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Rates of depression are very high in persons who have had a stroke and treatments are generally not effective. We will study the efficacy of combining aerobic exercise and non-invasive brain stimulation (repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation) in treating people with post-stroke depression. Our goal is to use the information collected to help design optimal treatments for many of the common consequences of stroke, something that would be incredibly valuable to people who have had a stroke and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The Fungal Genetics Conference brings together fungal biologists working on most major fungal systems and promotes communication and collaboration between those working on fungi related to human health including Medical mycologists, working on fungi that cause diseases of people and those working on food security as well as others working on plant pathogens, saprobes and symbiotic fungi. This interaction allows students interested in mycology to find and pursue opportunities for research careers in Infectious Diseases and other areas towards reducing the impact of fungi on human health. Fungi also serve as important model systems to understand basic processes in cells that when altered result in diseases of people based on the presence in fungi of many genes and metabolic and regulatory pathways relevant to those altered in people impacted by these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric obesity is an epidemic that is disproportionately experienced by children from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, underscoring the need to identify novel, modifiable risk factors for obesity prevention, particularly for those at greatest risk. Mounting evidence suggests that enhancing children's sleep may represent a novel target for prevention approaches that may be particularly well suited for delivery by allied health professionals in primary care settings, thus having potential for high public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to establish NR4A1 as a valid therapeutic target for melanoma. Using Proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) technology, this project will develop first-of-its-kind NR4A1 degrader to potentially treat melanoma. Using in vivo models and cancer specimens, we will determine the mechanisms how NR4A1- targeting PROTACs work to promote an immune active environment and whether NR4A1 PROTAC is a useful tool for treating melanoma as a single agent or in combination with other frontline therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Summer Training as Research Scholars (STaRS) at Boston University is a summer Research Education Program for outstanding undergraduate and early medical school students from traditionally underrepresented groups in the biomedical sciences. The goal is to help ignite a passion for a career in biomedical research through immersion in authentic, faculty-mentored research experiences, supplemented by individualized career development planning (e.g., apply to and be accepted in graduate and medical programs). The program aims to promote a sense of belonging to the greater scientific research community among scholars, with the ultimate mission of retaining these scholars in research careers to diversify the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Completing these studies will 1) provide mechanistic insight into how gut bacteria engage with the local gut and gut-distal immune system to impact Plasmodium-induced humoral immunity, 2) provide translational relevance to African children, and 3) identify how antibiotic treatment alters interactions between the gut bacteria-host immunity-Plasmodium triad to prevent severe malaria. These studies are poised to support the use of antibiotics to prevent severe malaria-related mortality in African children. Of note, antibiotic treatment has been tested for malnutrition in African children, providing a conceptual framework to use antibiotics to prevent severe malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Narrative This study aims to develop a new generation of Zn-based drug-eluting bioresorbable cardiovascular stents that possess sufficient mechanical strength, stability, and ideal biocompatibility without toxicity. The use of these novel stents would improve patients’ quality of life by providing a better recovery experience and eliminating the need for a second surgery and long-term complications due to their full biodegradability, particularly for young children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is leading cause of death in the United States and represents a significant burden to the national health system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a recalcitrant subtype of lung cancer for which there are limited treatment options. This study will employ novel mouse and patient-derived models of SCLC as well as state-of-the-art technologies in single cell genomics and lineage-tracing to determine the function of NEUROD1 in SCLC. This work is relevant to public health and the NIH mission because it is aimed to improve the quality of life and survival of lung cancer patients by increasing our understanding of SCLC molecular subtypes and their associated therapeutic vulnerabilities.
